description:
I found out about this place because one of my favorite youtubers recommended this place. My boyfriend and I first went to the other location but it was closed for a private event. I originally didn't have time to try this place out but I am so glad I made time for it because this veggie chinese food is bomb! I could eat this for the rest of my life! 

My boyfriend and I got the crispy fragrant chicken, a side of rice, and the sliced fatty pork with mustard greens & napa cabbage to share for dinner. The crispy fragrant chicken was so good you couldn't even tell it wasn't real chicken. The sliced fatty pork was also delicious. If you didn't tell me I honestly would think it's real meat. 

The service here is fast so probably not the nicest people but they always say thank you and so on. I think the lunch menu is really worth it! 
If I came back to SF, I would most deff come back to this place!!
author: Flora L.

description:
The portions were generous for lunch, and all items are $10.99. Unfortunately, the quality of the food does not even compare to the price, especially for a vegetarian only place.

I ordered the spicy ma Po tofu and it was just cubes of tofu mixed with frozen carrots and green peas in a mixture of cornstarch and soy sauce. Couldn't even find a single Sichuan peppercorn.

Don't bother stopping by, unless you're looking for a step down from Panda Express.
author: Rishi G.

description:
You know those cravings for Chinese you get when you're sitting at home in your PJs and watching your favorite rom com? 

This place satisfies those cravings with the added benefit of it being vegetarian. 

I really like the pea sprouts with ginger, crispy tofu, crispy chicken, and chicken chow mein. 

It's kind of pricey, but what isn't these days? 

Oh! Almost forgot, I also love the complimentary red bean sesame balls YUM.
author: Kathleen C.

description:
My mom recommended this place for a lite dinner on our way home from Mission. She'd had a good experience here a few years ago. (My mom is vegan and I'm vegetarian.) First impression was positive: bright, clean, nicely decorated interior, with a neat array of small tables. We seated ourselves and were given tea and menus immediately. 

My mom and I were both looking for something healthy and refreshing, so we ordered steamed vegetable dumplings, small vegetable and tofu soup, and pea sprouts with ginger. My favorite was by far the dumplings; perfectly cooked, bite size, filling tasted fresh and bright. The soup and pea sprouts were both too oily. I know Chinese dishes are usually meant to be eaten with rice, so tend to be on the oily and saucy side, but the soup especially tasted quite greasy. I also expected a larger portion of vegetables; although we ordered a small, I believe it was still $5-6. We also didn't receive any pumpkin, which was part of the soup's description, and I was not expecting the tofu to be fried. However the soup did have a pleasant, lightly savory flavor. 

No complaints about service; our server was great and the dishes came out quickly. I don't have any strong opinions about this restaurant because our experience, although underwhelming, was fine and we didn't try the most popular dishes like the duck. Based on other reviews, it seems their food does tend to be oily, but if you don't mind or order rice, I'd still give this place a chance.
author: Tiffany Z.

description:
Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant 

Complimentary spring rolls and tea. 

I asked and basically everything on the menu is vegan. 

I am for sure L46 and L22 are vegan. As well as the spring rolls. 

Wow. Wow. Did I just say wow twice? Yes wow, this place was amazing. I mean you couldn't even tell that what you were eating was Vegan! 

Located in The Chinatown area of San Francisco I would highly recommend stopping at this place if you like Chinese food. The place is busy but we got seated right away and the service was prompt and the food was served superfast. And they give you free hot tea and free spring rolls when you arrive? Uh yes, Count me in! 

I could hardly even choose what to eat because almost everything on the menu is vegan I asked what was it big and she said all of the items I was looking at were. 

First off the hot tea was awesome as you got towards the end of the pot it was even more full of flavor.

Spring rolls those are awesome too. They were crunchy filled with veggies and the dipping sauce was really tasty.

Oh and did I mention that they were free? Yep I did but I just wanted to make sure you read that again.

Kung pao soy chicken with peppers and broccoli - mmmmmmhmm. No complaints on this dish only thing I want to wish for is less peppers and more of the food itself. The portion that :-) small Ford size in my opinion but that might've also been because we order the lunch special I assume that if you ordered the full-size a dinner or vice versa would've probably been larger. The taste of the soy chicken really had to text her that I would have never even imagined it could have. I haven't had chicken and a very very very long time but from what I remember it tasted damn near like chicken. 

The Thai style spicy and sour soup made with udon noodles was great too. I probably wouldn't have ordered this one again just because I love the soy chicken with broccoli so much and there are so many other amazing options I wanted to have tried but it was really tasty the broth as flavorful and the vegetables were delicious I just wish there was a tad bit more of tasted it but it definitely was a huge portion I could definitely have seen my cell sharing it with two or three other people specially because the other lunch portion seems kind of small having this with a few of the other lunch specials would've been just right.
Right now I'm currently dreaming of still being in San Francisco and being able to eat all of this delicious Chinese food at this lovely restaurant they had so so so so many options. 

 

As always, go vegan ( or at least try )!
author: Peyton C.

description: I got reishi medicine soup and it was watered-down and expensive. It's nice that they don't add msg though.
author: Jason S.

description:
Great menu selections and flavorful, sattvic food. I would avoid the spring rolls.
Service can be more personal, instead of rushing us with lack of courtesy and care.
author: Bobby G.

description:
Food: It was pretty good, although the new year dumpling left something to be desired. There seemed to be something wrong with the rice, and they just gave us plain soy sauce with it. The boiled dumplings had celery inside, were small and tasted good, although the dumpling sauce left something to be desired. The spicy eggplant was not spicy at all, despite its location on the spicy menu. The fried tofu over pea sprouts was our favorite here, because of the pea sprouts. The tofu was soft inside and perfectly crispy outside.  
Logistics: There isn't really any parking as it's in the heart of Chinatown. No bike racks. You can walk in and sit down.
Service: The food came out quickly, but even though we were the only ones there, the waitress was not very attentive.
Atmosphere: It's a quiet place; at least, it wasn't busy when we went in.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Vegan Meets Mediocrity at Best

I had high hopes for Enjoy Vegetarian, but what seemed to be a cozy nook of healthy yet enjoyable food turned out to be a recipe for oily and unseasoned disaster.

To provide some hope for prospective diners, I will start off on a positive note. When you immediately enter the restaurant, you will notice that the restaurant is very clean and organized. Points for presentation. The service for this restaurant was also timely. Once my friend and I ordered food, we received our meals within 10minutes. A+ on providing efficient service. 

A highly appreciated aspect of this restaurant is that they serve hot tea that is complimentary to all meals. The tea was not brewed to perfection; however, it was a nice touch.

In regards to hospitality, the restaurant could use some rehabilitation. When my friend and I first walked in, no one greeted us, so we sat down on our own. This wasn't a big deal for us; however, considering it was slow and many diners are likely new to the area, having someone to immediately greet and seat customers would be admirable. Something we sensed was that the server seemed very hostile towards customers. I do not expect overly enthusiastic employees for any restaurant, but the level of hostility seemed uncanny to say the least. The waitress made minimal eye contact (if any), used a very brief staccato tone, and she failed to hand the check directly to either party. It was simply dropped onto the table.

On the contrary, food presentation was unexpectedly suburb. Aesthetically, the entrees were very pleasing and could sell themselves. Nonetheless, do NOT judge a meal by its cover.

In regards to the actual quality of the food, there is much room for improvement. Between my friend and I, we ordered the Combination Platter, Veggie Duck, Steamed Dumplings, and the Spring Rolls. 

The first thing I noticed was that while the Veggie Duck had a decent texture and looked very similar to actual duck, it lacked a desirable flavor and was very oily. It was tolerable and had an unexpected taste, but if you are looking for a veggie friendly alternative to duck, look elsewhere.

The dumplings appeared normal, but with one bite, our initial expectations proved to be wrong. What you'd expect to be delicately flavored dumplings turned out to be oil bags of flavorless lettuce and dough. I was highly disappointed with this item, considering the simplicity of it and price-size ratio.

As far as the spring rolls are concerned, they were decent but tiny. For the price, you'd expect the standard proportion found at any restaurant servings rolls, but these were extremely small and overpriced.

The combination platter is really where things truly went wrong. If I weren't in Kansas anymore, this platter would've be the wicked witch of the East, dead before you ever got a chance to m(eat) it. To start, the portion was microscopic. The BBQ "pork" tasted alright, but the soybean sheet and tofu were  extremely oily and tasteless. I can understand that as a health promoting restaurant, they'd want to keep the sodium consumption limited, but this was beyond bland. The sweet and sour wheat gluten was the worst of them all. Finally, I thought, the restaurant managed to present something full of sweet and savory flavor, only to create a soggy red substance. Do not be deceived by it's appearance. From this platter, I believe I was most impressed with the BBQ "pork" for having decent taste and texture, but the majority of this palette was oily and tasteless.

Potential areas of improvement:
* Increase Appetizer Portions
* Experiment with more balanced and flavorful seasoning
* Improve Texture 
* Decrease oil usage !!!

A major deal breaker apart from flavor is the pricing for small portioned items. For example, Enjoy Vegetarian charges $8 for six "chicken" nuggets. Perhaps if it were an upscale delicacy, catering to the wealthy and middle class elite, $8 would have been worth it, but not for the average joe, and definitely not for the flavor and size. 

Based on my first time experience dining at this restaurant, I would not recommend it for well-seasoned and oil free food. As for its service, I would give this restaurant 3 stars. They're efficient in serving their customers yet lack effectiveness in overall quality.

Enjoy Vegetarian is by no means a "terrible" restaurant. Perhaps today was simply a bad day for the server and sodium-withholding cook. Gathered from previous reviews, their main entrees tend to have a better reputation, so I recommend steering clear of appetizers if you are considering eating here for the first time. Nevertheless, it is unlikely that I will be dining here again. Best of luck to future diners, and may the odds for well seasoned and texturized food be ever in your favor.

"If anyone would like to start a GoFundMe to supply Enjoy Vegetarian with some much needed salt, I will gladly be the first to open my wallet and donate to this WORTHY cause." -- My Friend.
author: K. W.

description:
There are many Chinese restaurants in San Francisco that has few vegan/vegetarian options, but for this restaurant, it's a sigh of relief for most devoured vegan & vegetarian lovers around! This Chinese restaurant named, "Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant" serves authentic and naturally made vegan/vegetarian Chinese cuisines every year! The atmosphere is very laid back and calmer as I welcomed there. The concept is much like visiting to your local Chinese restaurant across the U.S. although for this location is much small and compact, yet it's very clean and well spaced inside filled with Chinese heritage and modern decors across the whole room.

The employees from servers and cookers are doing a good job for making the customers like me a fine service despite the busiest environment. No cons!

Now onto the food! Since it's quite cold and breezy outside in San Francisco on 2/17/2017, I did managed to get a shared table successfully despite the tonight's Chinese New Year dinner crowd. At this point, I ordered the Veggie Chicken, Green Vegetables with Noodle Soup. As I ate it, that vegan noodle soup tasted very interestingly delicious! I really loved the faux chicken strips idea cause it tasted like chicken, yet in a tofu taste ways! What a treat it was! The rest of the ingredients from assortment vegetables (broccoli, carrot strips and small bok choys), noodles and vegetable broth all tasted outstanding, and I didn't feel any hidden MSG around! Beautifully presented and irresistible vegetarian dish that I've ever eaten in years. Lovely!

Parking at Enjoy Vegetarian Chinese restaurant can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface metered street parking nor the parking garage if it's available. Likewise, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant is the finest and well simple local Vegan/Vegetarian Chinese restaurant that I've ever visited for the first time right here in San Francisco's Chinatown. Perfect for friends, family and co-workers gathering especially special occasions too. A well received! My rating: 4 solid stars
author: William L.

description:
Came here for christmas eve dinner. I had the drumsticks and the beef noodle soup. i love this place so much- so many options. i always want everything off the menu. I always get the chicken legs and they are so so good. 

this is a vegan/veggie head paradise. I enjoy the rice cake with ham as well. ive been to all the locations. keep up the good work
author: Amanda M.

description:
Good place for vegetarians. They have a lot of varieties to cover the menu.

I went there twice. First time I ordered friend spring rolls, spicy mapo tofu and house chow mean. Spring rolls were not that good, but, other two things were good (4 star out of 5).

What amazed me is the "spinach & cashew fried rice" which I ordered the second time I went there. I absolutely loved it and will definitely go back for it.
author: Swapnil G.

description:
Christmas evening and a trip to Chinatown was the logical choice to find open restaurants. Unsurprisingly, the place started to fill up as soon as it opened, but we managed to get a table nonetheless.

Was considerably hungry, deciding to order the Drumsticks ($8) and the Veggie Sticky Rice Dumpling ($6) for appetizers. The drumsticks come in four pieces with a stick through the middle to act as a bone. A little chewy that needs some help with the sauce provided. Sticky rice is a giant mass of dense rice that's supremely dry (couldn't finish). For the main course, ordered the Veggie Chow Mein ($11) and the Twice Cook Pork ($14). The chow mein wasn't too greasy and had a nice flavor of veggies (no sauce necessary). Twice Cooked pork is served on a bed of cabbage - with the faux pork meat actually being tender and easy to eat.

Service here is efficient (though they brought our appetizers and main course at about the same time). Good option for the vegetarians out there who need something in the area.
author: Shaji K.

description:
My friend and I decided to try out Enjoy for lunch before going to Union Square for some Christmas shopping. I'm a vegetarian and my friend is non-veg, but we both thoroughly enjoyed our food. Considering the restaurant is in Chinatown, I was surprised at how clean the interior looks. No complaints about the service - staff were friendly and efficient enough.

We decided to share a couple dishes and a small soup between the two of us. I ordered the Basil Soy Chicken with Mixed Green Vegetables ($12.99). I absolutely loved this dish! It tasted exactly like the popular Taiwanese dish "3-cup chicken". The soy meat had an amazing texture and flavor - it was definitely one of the best fake meats I've ever tried! My non-veg friend couldn't believe that the "meat" was made of soy; she said it tasted exactly like chicken. My friend ordered the House Special Fried Rice ($10.99), which came with veggie BBQ pork, veggie ham, peas and carrots. The fried rice was delicious, and the veggie meat was also very good. Lastly, my friend ordered the small Thai Style Soup ($7.50), which came with a nice mix of tofu, broccoli, pineapple, and bean sprouts. The soup was a bit too sour and spicy for my taste, but my friend really enjoyed it.

The two minor complaints I have are location and price. It took us a good 15-20 minutes to find parking and another 15 minutes to walk to the restaurant. Also, prices were a bit higher than I expected, considering it's in Chinatown. However, portion sizes were decent enough. We were both very full and had some leftovers as well. I can't wait to come back and try other dishes!
author: Tiffany L.

description: On 10/5/18, my friend and I split the BBQ pork chow mein and Kung Pao Chicken, didn't like the food and I thought I would get sick. I did get sick and I won't be back
author: Katelyn K.

description:
I have been to other vegetarian Chinese restaurants that use faux meats, so I was very excited to check this place out, especially after reading the other reviews. Unfortunately, it left me severely underwhelmed, both in service and in food. 

From the moment I walked in, I felt uncomfortable here. The empty tables were set, and there was no sign to wait to be seated, so I stood for a bit, totally ignored. I walked back to the register where the servers were congregated to ask if I should take any table, and one of the servers growled at me that it was very busy and I need to wait. Ok, fine, but I was just trying to be polite. I could have just sat at a table. Or you could have a sign. Or you could have a decent personality. All options. 

Once seated, I ordered "house" chow mein with faux "bbq pork" and "ham." It was complete underwhelming and unforgettable. I do wonder if I perhaps ordered the wrong thing, but I thought I was ordering a house specialty. 

The overall dining experience was weird and uncomfortable. At the end of the meal, I gave my credit card to one of the servers, and she never brought it back to me. The woman who had yelled at me when I first walked in came over to ask me if I had paid, which I assumed was her way of saying "stop holding the table and leave." I told her that I was waiting for my card back. She did find the card and returned with a much more pleasant attitude, but the damage was done.
author: Chanele R.

description:
Yes, please! The best Chinese vegetarian restaurant in Chinatown and a solid candidate for best overall Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. Their clear broth soups, eggplant, and most of their fake meats are on point. I'm not as over the moon for the imitation pork or fish but the soy basil chicken usually hits the spot. I love their veggie wonton soup.

The winner every time is an order of Golden Knots. Tofu, mushroom, and veggie filler wrapped in tofu skin sheets, with a side of bok choy. One of my favorite dishes everywhere, healthy and filling and flavorful all at once. Their brown rice is decent too.

One area for improvement: For a veggie place, they have relatively few unadorned regular presentations of vegetables. Last time I tried a straightforward serving of pea shoots and they were spectacular. It's a shame there's not more. They could do good things with broccoli. No need for everything to be imitation something-it's-not (meat) when many folks coming in won't mind veggies served as veggies. Still, there are a lot of solid choices.

Expect authentic, abrupt, but efficient service. No complaints there. They try hard and they have a good product, in a spare but pleasant enough room in great proximity to FiDi.
author: James D.

description:
We stopped here after a long day of showing family around town.  My cousin's girlfriend is a strict vegan, and she was craving Chinese food.  Since they aren't from SF, they didn't know how important it was to make a reservation on a Friday.  By the time we got here, we were beyond starved, and I was just glad to find a vegan place that fit our needs.

My overall, quick and dirty?  I loved the various menu choices, vegetarian AND vegan options, and the fact that they don't use any onions or MSG in their food.  Being allergic to onions is typically hard when dining in a Chinese restaurant.  The food was good and flavorful, but overly saucy and salty.  

We had the crispy salt and pepper tofu, which honestly will keep me coming back.  It was perfectly seasoned, crisp, and had a kick of jalapeno flavor.  We also ordered the spring rolls, taro cakes, kung pao tofu (which packed a nice kick), sweet and sour chicken, and eggplant basil tofu.  Most memorable next to the crispy tofu was the eggplant.  The flavor was good, the tofu was a perfect texture, and it had a nice basil flavor.  It was a little saucy though.

We ordered sides of rice, and I'm not kidding when I say there was nothing left.  The 4 of us ate EVERYTHING.  Our vegan out-of-towner was thoroughly impressed with the food, and she said she was going to go home and recommend this place to all of her vegan friends when visiting San Francisco.  My girlfriend normally hates Chinese food because of the saucy and saltiness, but even she was pleasantly surprised.  

I had to knock off 1 star because we downed water despite the reduction of salt when we went to bed, and because I would have appreciated less sauce in each dish.  I would recommend this place to any vegetarian/vegan who is craving a good Chinese meal in SF.  It's clean compared to some Chinatown spots, the staff is friendly and attentive, and like I said, I appreciated their various menu choices.
author: Ashley S.

description: It's overwhelming to have a menu where I can eat anything! And it's a big menu. The food portions were large and delicious and something for every one whether you like eggplant n tofu or love (fake) Mongolian beef and broccoli. The tea was light and tasty and quickly refilled - dinner for two was $25.
author: Zara S.

description: This place is in Chinatown which is great. We got the fried springs rolls that were good, the kung pao chicken and the singapore noodles. The noodles were my favorite, not too greasy either. Pretty good food and pretty good price
author: McKenna S.

description:
It must be nice being a vegetarian in the Bay Area... because you get access to lots of vegetarian options across different cuisines. Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant is one delicious example that has creative ways of mimicking meaty favorites. Rest assured, despite the name of some dishes, everything here is 100% vegetarian but still as satisfying as the meat equivalent.

So when I had a vegetarian friend visiting from out of town, my group of 3 decided to have lunch here. It wasn't too busy for a Saturday afternoon - we were promptly seated and served hot tea. They even serve boba tea made by the place next door, but you can order at the restaurant to enjoy with your meal! Service was friendly and attentive about taking our orders and giving us water to drink. We got the following items and shared family style:

7. Drumstick w/ Sweet and Sour Sauce: This was the main reason we came here - we were curious how vegetarian chicken tasted like. Turns out their version was very good - crispy on the outside with moist, chewy layers of "meat" on the inside. The "bone" is actually a regular wooden stick. I can't really tell what it was made out of, I think some kind of wrapped bean curd? Either way, it was very flavorful and went great with the sweet and sour sauce. Tasted like chicken, and had the same salty appeal Chinese fried chicken has.

15. Veggie Duck: I'm not a fan of regular Chinese duck, but this vegetarian version was delicious. I think it was bean curd wrapped over a bunch of times, fried, then cut into slices to get that texture and crispy outer layer. Where the bone could have been was filled with some kind of marinated mushroom. It had a pleasant chewy texture but was really savory and juicy, kind of like regular Chinese duck, yet without the gamey-ness.

25. Braised Spareribs w/ Broccoli: This was certainly an interesting dish... it was a very saucy dish. Mixed with the broccoli and "beef", it was very good and had an interesting, complex flavor that reminded me of the spareribs from Din Tai Fung - sweet, savory, and peppery? Definitely reminiscent of regular beef and broccoli. The "beef" nuggets were soft and tasty - they really soaked up the sauce well. I think they were made with a mix of mushroom and soybean? Either way, were I enjoyed it.

87. House Special Fried Rice (BBQ Pork & Veggie Ham): Of all the dishes I had, this was the most suspicious vegetarian dish - not only was it good... but the ham and pork really tasted like ham and pork. The ham was more like spam, and it had that saltiness. The pork had the red outer layer you see in Chinese pork, and the texture and taste are spot on. Don't get me wrong - the fried rice was great. But I'm still baffled that this is a vegetarian dish given how meaty the toppings tasted!

All in all, as a meat eater it was fun to come here and experience vegetarian creativity in Chinese cuisine. I'd highly recommend coming here, as the servers are friendly and the quality of the food is great. Nothing tasted too greasy and it was all quite satisfying. Portions were good too for the prices.. Will definitely be back to explore more of the menu.
author: Alyanna C.

description: Awesome vegan food!  We shared the Kung Pao "chicken" and Mongolian "beef" and they were great!!  Oh yeah..... don't forget the fried chicken nuggets :)
author: Marc W.

description: This place is a great option for vegetarians and vegans out there! While their soy meat does not have the exact texture of real meat, it's pretty flavorful on its own. I've had the pei pa tofu before. It was tasty and not too greasy like other Chinese restaurants. This time I came with a friend around lunch and got their soy sauce chicken and honey walnut prawns. I really enjoyed the soy chicken which came with bok choy. My only complaint is that the honey walnut prawns were a little too soggy and had a slight sour/lemony taste to it. Overall, I would come back to try some of the other dishes.
author: Sui N.

description:
One of the decent vegan places in Chinatown and conveniently located across from the Hilton.  

I came here a couple of times and I remember ordering veggie "lamb" curry, dumplings and vegan "salted fish and chicken" fried rice.

Service: Typical Chinese restaurant.  They won't say much, but you'll get your food quickly and once you finish eating, they expect you leave your table within a few minutes.  Standard Chinese restaurant practice.  

Decor: Not bad.  Clean.  Nothing special, but not too dingy either.

Food:  

Dumplings - skin was perfect, but filling was pretty plain. Just veggies.  Not much taste, but perfect texture.  

"Lamb" curry - this was great.  The texture of the mock lamb mimicked real lamb and even the taste did too. It wasn't a lackadaisical attempt at calling any mock protein "lamb" and just adding flavors. They took the time to get the taste and texture. The curry was pretty decent.  Now, don't expect super aromatic flavors from Chinese curry, but this was fairly good and had a light kick to it.  

Salted fish & chicken fried rice - are you kidding me?  This wasn't real meat or fish???!!!!!  I practically grew up on this dish and I've missed it since becoming a vegan.  After a couple of bites, I was addicted.  The chicken was bang on and so was the salted fish flavour.

Verdict: If you love Chinese food and are in Chinatown, this is a must try spot.
author: Bernie C.

description: Out of all the amazing food in city, we would not return to this restaurant. Completely forgettable experience. The waitress was curt; sat us and disappeared. We were never given water. The cabbage dumplings were boring, flavorless. The hot n sour soup was just ok. For entrée we split the sesame beef and that had some flavor and decent texture. Overall, food was cheap and arrived quickly, but I wouldn't expect too much from this place; including water.
author: Daniella L.

description:
Our regular Chinatown vegetarian restaurant was closed so we decided to check this one out instead. It looks like standard Chinese food but it's all vegetarian (or more likely vegan from what I can tell from skimming the menu) so you can order what you want to your heart's content!

We started with the Wonton Hot and Sour soup (the small split well between two people as an appetizer). Just as we were finishing this up, our entrees were placed down. We ordered the Black Bean Sauce with String Beans and Chicken (which came out really crispy) and the Broccoli Beef, both being well-sized servings with enough to share between the two of us. I loved the crispiness of the chicken, something you don't get often in fake meat, and the beef was very tender and full of flavour.

Complimentary tea is also served.

The food was delicious and the prices were just right for the quality and location. Service was fast and polite and overall I was really happy we came and checked this place out. I'll happily come by again for delicious fake meat options!
author: Cassandra J.

description: My boyfriend and I love this place. He's a vegetarian and I'm not, so a lot of times when we eat out, one of us have to give up. It's either the place that I enjoy or he enjoys, it's a rare case that we'll go to a restaurant where we'll both equally enjoy. This place however, is a different story. Everything taste great even from a meat eater perspective like me. I especially love the chicken curry fried rice and the golden knot (or something, I forgot the actual name). One time I also ordered a mongolian beef, seasonings wasn't that good although I do enjoy the beefless beef. Texture was on point. Overall, I'd definitely recommend this for both vegetarian and non-veg.
author: Ni Luh Putu Eka W.

description:
I ordered food here on Eat24. My food was ready in less than 20 min and the process went very smoothly. I can't talk about the sit down service, but the restaurant seemed very clean and modern when I stopped by to pick up my food. 

I was looking for healthier Chinese food options in Chinatown and found this place on my Yelp search. I had the Eggplant and String Bean Lunch Special ($9.99 which includes rice and a vegetarian egg roll). The food was very fresh and you can tell that there was no MSG. I also love that brown rice is an option! It's definitely a nice turn from the usual Chinese food you can get in Chinatown, which is normally way too greasy. You obviously have to pay more for your meal, but it's totally worth it to be eating food that is good for you. 

I'm actually super excited to try their other dishes. I've never had soy chicken or beef so I'm up for trying it soon. So glad that there's an option to eat healthy Chinese food in Chinatown!
author: Kelly N.

description:
I had searched for the vegetarian restaurant around Chinatown and i already found 2 places!  
This resto have many interesting menu and i would love to go and try other dishes for sure! 

The atmosphere is nice and claim. They open Chinese praying song. It made me feel very calm while i was eating. 

Iono how to recommend foods here cos all dishes i have tried were so marvelous! 

Check it out!
author: Tiratiwan L.

description:
I decided to get the Black Bean Sauce w/ String Beans & Veggie Chicken ($9.99) after taking a look at the lunch menu. My friend got the Twice Cooked Veggie Pork ($9.99). 

I noticed there were over 30 items on the menu! It was interesting that the menu stated that onion, garlic, and MSG were not used in any of the dishes. 

I was having a hard time deciding on what to eat. I really like bean curd, but lotus roots sounded so good on that Monday afternoon! I ended up going with the string bean dish though because I love green beans. A lot of Asian restaurants use super crunchy and fat green beans.

I liked my dish a lot. It was not very saucy although the fake meat was a little dry. My lunch meal came with a free egg roll and a  small bowl of rice. My friend did not like his Twice Cooked Veggie Pork at all. He could not finish the whole thing and said that it tasted very bland. He stated that it could be because he had the real dish before that typically contains meat. His expectations were different. Both of the portion sizes were decent for the lunch price.

The service seemed kind of brisk to me. The waitresses did not smile. They seemed to say "thank you" a lot to the other tables and did not pay attention as we were walking out the door. I hope it was because there were a lot of customers. It seemed like we were the only Asians in our age group. I noticed that the two identical receipts we received had different tip suggestions for 15, 18, and 20%. The difference was really small anyways (~30 cents). Even though the waitresses seemed a little cold to us, at least the food was good.
author: Kristina M.

description:
I love vegetarian Chinese food. Chinese food is usually a good option for vegetarians and this place has all the traditional Chinese offerings with a veg twist. Lunch special prices are reasonable for the area.

I have been here three times and have gotten the tom yum noodle soup twice and basil tofu with mixed greens once. Both were very favorable. Love that the tom yum soup is not sweet and that there are tons of veggies and pineapple slices. I would like to come back and try their other offerings. 

Solid lunch spot.
author: Joan S.

description:
My coworkers and I tried this spot because one of us is a vegan -- and even though I wasn't too excited to eat vegetarian -- omg YUM.  

To start, we got the fried wontons, which were okay -- not the best and wouldn't get again.  BUT then we also got the drumsticks with sweet and sour sauce and HOLY MOLY.  These things are good.  Definitely give these a try -- they taste like chicken and have the texture of chicken.  So good!  However, please note there's a wooden stick inside the drumstick, which obviously makes it a drumstick...my coworker was a bit eager and didn't notice...and bit the stick.

We also got the braised spareribs - and WOW.  Seriously, looks, smells, and tastes like spareribs.  Very strange how delicious and real tasting these were.  The sauce is to die for and the texture is on point!  Highly recommend. So flavorful.

What also makes this place cool is that we were able to order boba from Etea at our tables, which is right next door.

I will definitely return here, as a non-vegetarian, it really doesn't matter because it really tastes like meat...Totally worth it!
author: Michelle S.

description:
On Kearny Street, I walked pass by this place numerous times, but never really took notice of it until I decided to one day just try some vegetarian Chinese food. It doesn't help that one of my favorite places to eat in Chinatown, Chong Qing Xiao Mian, is a block away from this place. Anyways, I came here on a weekday evening with a friend since I really wanted to try out this place after finding out about it. When we went inside, it was at roughly 70% capacity, and we took a seat near the counter in the back. This place seems to have greater appeal to non-Chinatown residents since I saw a lot of tourists and what I suspect to be Financial District employees. Anyways, after scanning the menu, we decided to share a small Veggie Shark's Fin Soup as an appetizer and get our own main dishes. I decided to get the Curry Tofu Udon Soup with Vegetables as my main dish. 

The veggie shark fin soup arrived and the server ladled out the soup into two small bowls for us. A small veggie shark fin soup in the large bowl translates to roughly 5-6 small bowls of soup if I recall correctly. I took a sip of the veggie shark fin soup and it was remarkably flavorful to my surprise. I never had shark fin soup before, but I remember thinking that this is probably on par with the real thing, since I'm not sure how the real version could improve the taste. My curry tofu udon soup arrived next, and I was brought back down to earth after tasting the soup. The soup tasted somewhat bland, with a hint of curry powder. The vegetables, tofu and the noodles were okay, and this dish overall was alright in my opinion.

Overall, I would give the shark fin soup a five and the curry tofu udon soup a three if I had to rate the dishes individually. I sort of wish that we ended the meal with the veggie shark fin soup since it had an extremely good aftertaste. The disparity between the two dishes was somewhat amusing to me, and I would take this as a sign that this place has some things they are great at, and some that they aren't. Also, there aren't that many places in Chinatown that are exclusively vegetarian, and I'm willing to concede that it's probably way harder to make Chinese vegetarian dishes taste as good as their non-vegetarian counterparts. I think this place is an overall four after taking everything into consideration, and I would come here again for the veggie shark fin soup, but if they can make their other dishes taste as good as the veggie shark fin soup, then this place has the potential to be a solid five.
author: Nelson X.

description: I came here for lunch. Got the wonton noodle soup. Absolutely delicious. The wontons are tender and yummy, and they added strips of some sort of soy meat into the soup. I am not a fan of meat replacements, and I could not get enough. The place is clean, very nice staff, and definitely vegan approved!
author: Julia C.

description:
I've always passed by this place but was skeptical on trying it since I do love my meat. However, my friend (a fellow yelp elite) recently tried this place and had good reviews on it so I decided to give this place a try. 

Came here today (Tuesday) for lunch at around 1pm  and did not have to wait. We were seated right away and was quickly offered tea and the menus. We decided to do it family style and share three of the lunch specials which were only $9.99 including rice and an egg roll! We ordered the braised spareribs with broccoli, Ma Po tofu(spicy) and the beef string beans. They were all pretty good! I really liked the egg roll, wish the lunch special came with more than one, lol. I also really like how we get to choose between a bowl of brown rice or white rice. I chose the brown but my coworkers went with the white rice. 

The braised spare ribs tasted just like real meat! I was really surprised. The texture and flavor of the spareribs were so accurate. I probably wouldn't even be able to tell that it was faux meat if I didn't know better. The broccoli that came with the dish was a little bland, but still fine as long as you put some of the sauce on it from the spareribs. 

The beef string beans were really good as well. The beef was very flavorful and tasted just like real beef - this dish was my coworker's favorite. 

The Ma Po tofu had some mushrooms bits and some peas in it and was very flavorful. It also was not too spicy so it was good for me since I can't handle too spicy. Also goes really well with rice! 

Overall, it was a great experience eating at a vegetarian restaurant for my first time. Pretty cool how their faux meat tastes just as good as real meat. I will probably come again and try other items on the menu. I'm really glad I gave this place a try! Also very convenient because there's a new boba place connected to this restaurant (E Tea). There's always room for boba! ;)
author: Bailey L.

description:
This place has definitely impressed me. Being a meat-eater and lover, I find it a bit difficult to eat meals without meat being my main source of protein. But I suppose it's a different story eating here.

As mentioned in many of the other reviews, you can't even tell the meat is faux (well, you can, but it's preeetttyyyyy good for what it is, which is faux meat). The place is fairly busy at lunch time, but luckily, I did not have to experience a long wait. 

My friend and I ordered the lunch deals, which were exactly just that- a deal! We shared the Kung Pao Soy Chicken w/ Pepper & Broccoli and the Sliced Fatty Pork w/ Sweet Mustard Greens & Napa Cabbage.

The lunch deal came with a spring roll (not to be confused with Vietnamese spring rolls, as these were fried) and your choice of either white or brown rice. Both dishes were really tasty! No lacking in flavor. The portions were decently-sized as well. My friend and I were satisfied from the food and ended up boxing some leftovers. For $9.99, you definitely get a good amount.

Will definitely come back as the menu seems to have an endless list of options. I'm sure you would be able to find a dish you love. Great vegetarian option!
author: Meghan J.

description:
The food here is so so. I did the spicy thai (hot and sour) noodle soup with vermicelli which was flavorful, but the flavor didn't bind to the noodle, so I felt like I was eating plain noodles and drinking soup.

My friend got the sticky rice dumpling which was just really dry. 

Service was kind of terse but reasonably swift. It's clean and close to FiDi, and I appreciate everything being on the cheaper side and vegetarian, but not a spot I would really bring friends to.
author: Annie J.

description: I was surprised to find that there was an asian vegetarian restaurant as most asian food has meat. Eating at Enjoy Vegetarian, I tried the Spicy Mapo Tofu, green beans, and Fried Taro Cake. I love the Fried Taro Cake the most but the Mapo Tofu was a bit too spicy for me. The Won Ton Soup was absolutely delicious! Overall I loved it and I'm looking forward to returning here again to eat!
author: Chris W.

description: In a word delicious!  We are in San Francisco on a business trip and we came up on this restaurant. We are quasi-vegan which means we do not eat meat. The food here is spectacular. The flavors burst. I highly recommend this place.
author: Joe D.

description:
Overall the food was very bland and boring. The lotus, ginkgo, pea and black fungus dish was especially disappointing. It desperately needed flavor - garlic, ginger, scallions, something people. The vegetables themselves were fine but they needed something. The rice cakes with fermented mustard greens were ok - flavored saved by the mustard greens but could have used a lot more of them. Also had the spicy eggplant which was the best of the lot but one of the worst preparations of this dish I've had. The eggplant was cooked ok but the sauce was way too sweet. 

I've had much better vegetarian food at regular Chinese restaurants.
author: Marco M.

description: One of my new favorite restaurants! I came for lunch and couldn't decide amongst all the incredible vegan options so I selected two items: wonton noodle soup (L42) and braised "pork" and broccoli (L6). Flavors are incredible, food is fresh and beautifully prepared. Quick service. Spring rolls were fresh, crispy, and delicious. Will definitely be back!
author: Christin J.

description:
Ever since I decided to go vegetarian, I have been on the hunt for good vegetarian restaurant.  This place definitely looked interesting based on the yelp review and I was eager to try it out for myself.  Starting from when I first approached the door, it has the no meat sticker on the door, cute subtle touch.  

We were there on a Friday night, and there was only 2 other parties eating in the restaurant, a little empty but I didn't mind.  As we were given the menu, I was a little intimidated by the wide range of selections.  So many dishes made to look like meat, but aren't meat.  My husband was a little confused since he was never exposed to vegetarian cuisine before.  After studying the menu for a good 5 minutes, I decided to play safe and stuck with my tofu selections for my first try at this place.  

We started with dumplings and hot and sour soup, for entries we ordered the coconut taro and pumpkin and the satay tofu and eggplant, plus 1 bowl of rice to split. 

The food came very quickly after our order and I was very pleasantly surprised by how good the dumpling turned out.  The filling is made of mixed vegetable (which includes mushroom) and it was very flavorful.  The hot and sour soup was a little too thick and not sour enough, but I still liked it.  As for our main entrees, my husband is a big coconut fan so he liked the coconut sauce in his entree, but complained that the taro was too dry.  I have to agree with him after I gave it a try, seemed like it wasn't cooked very well.  As for my eggplant and tofu dish, it was a delight, everything I have hoped, very flavorful and meaty (in terms of chewy texture).  

I really enjoyed the food, but I have to say for a vegetarian chinese restaurant, this place is not cheap.  Each entree was around $10.99 and they charged $2.50 for the rice.  I think I would definitely give this place a try again, but I would probably want to explore some other vegetarian place first for comparison.
author: Young N.

description: Super good. The chow Mein and the braised spareribs with broccoli were both great! Spareribs had so much flavor and they didn't skimp on the broccoli! Highly recommend
author: Tessa M.

description: Great little spot! Long story short we stumbled upon this place. Just hungry in china town, one of our phones died and the other didn't have yelp. Tried to find something vegetarian. Ended up here and it's my new favorite place! Gigantic menu (all but a few items are plant based/vegan) my friend completely not vegan loved it too! We were formulate enough to sit next to a couple who frequents the place and then help us narrow down the huge menu and we took their advice and got their favorites! Dumplings, won ton soup, lettuce wraps, and chicken bites (can't remember the name, they're an appetizer). First let me say, the service was friendly, and FAST! secondly, the servings are huge, you can definitely share! And the food was flavorful but not overly greasy (find this to be a problem at vegan places, too much sugar or fat) but not here! They also have a dessert menu and little boba shop. We were too full for dessert but will be returning!
author: Taylor T.

description: I'm not a vegetarian, I love meat, but the food here is amazing. So much flavors, great balances of sweet, salt, and spice. Ordered the crispy tofu, Singapore rice noodle, and twice cooked pork, and everything was so delicious. However the only knock against one of the dish is the veggie pork really tasted like tofu pork, better off without it in the dish. Overall this place is really good, great place to take your vegetarian friends or family members.
author: Duck S.

description:
My friend and I decided to try this restaurant after reviewing the photos in the menu on the window. This little place was neat and rather pleasant. I wouldn't categorize it as hole-in-the-wall. It was lunch time. One table was occupied by a family with two toddlers - playing with their food and squeaking from time to time. Then many other 2 person tables were seated by office people eating alone. Many nationalities which I think was a good sign. The wash room was clean, reflective of kitchen condition in my opinion.

This is definitely not a restaurant you would immediately fall in love and nothing resembling high street experience. There were only two lady servers who were doing their job but not particularly customer friendly.  The lunch specials were $10.99 for a dish of your choice accompanied by rice (white/mixed grain) and one spring roll. The menu was very extensive even for the lunch specials. So, we ordered fried (faux) chicken nuggets ( which were actually mushrooms), mixed veggie deluxe (#13) and soupy vermicelli with chicken (#44). My friend was not impressed by her vermicelli. But I liked the rest. Because their deep fried was crispy and the dishes were not greasy. Quit flavorful. I actually finished all of them... portion was on the small size. We paid $38.

Well, today's experience was enough for me to try out more from their interesting menu in future....see if I can update to 4-star.
author: C K.

description:
I always appreciate a vegetarian only place where you don't have to pick through the menu to order since I could eat everything they serve.  I had high expectations for this place but was let down as the fried rice was too salty and the vegetable lo mein had a lot of noodles, tasted bland and only a small amount of vegetables.  The eggplant dish we had was good and was the saving grace of the meal.

Here is why I won't come back.  During mid meal, the waitress asked me to move my chair in.  I was confused since there is a wide walk way.  Then I realized that they were wheeling large trash cans (2) through the restaurant.  I'm pretty sure that violates the health code.  Why would you wheel 2 large trash cans through the middle of the restaurant while people are eating?  I mean, sure this is Chinatown and I usually don't have much expectations for cleanliness but come on, this is totally ruined the mood for the meal.
author: Yue L.

description: Came here for lunch with the coworkers on a day that one of them couldn't eat meat so it was perfect -- we had faux meat instead. I'm not from SF area so I can't really judge all the restaurants against each other in the area, but I have had vegetarian restaurants back home in LA, and I have really liked all of them. What set this one apart from all the other Chinese restaurants is that they offer a choice between white rice or brown rice which was perfect for me since I no longer eat white rice. Since there were 4 of us, we ordered 4 different dishes: the rice cakes with mustard greens, spare ribs with broccoli, green beans with sea bass, and tofu & veggies. The meal came with a starter of an egg roll for each of us. All of the food was pretty good; I especially liked the rice cakes and the sea bass actually tasted like real fish. They are connected to a tea shop next door, which is owned by the same owners and we had actually tried the tea there a couple days prior to coming here. The tea was pretty good too. Overall, I would come back to try all the other dishes especially since they have a long list (front and back page) of lunch special items.
author: Victoria Y.

description:
Probably the best fake meat I've had ever. The idea of fake meat may be gross to some - but to me it is fascinating. I love the creativity that has to go into fabricating different textures and flavours from something as humble as soy and gluten. I like to imagine a crazy vegan scientist concocting fake gluten animals in a weird lab somewhere. 

Of the four dishes we ordered I think my favourite was the fake fatty pork with taro. Granted it has been 8+ years since I've eaten real fatty pork but they actually managed to get the different layers of 'fat' and meat' into some facsimile of real pork. Amazing!

My brother is a big fan of the walnut coconut prawns thing. I am not the hugest fan of mayo and I've never had regular walnut coconut prawns but it was quite tasty and I can see most people really enjoying this one. 

If fake meat weirds you out - don't worry there is plenty of regular non-pretender food options that are also delicious. But you should definitely give it a try! You may find yourself pleasantly surprised!
author: Jenny L.

description: My favorite veggie place ever!! Their veggie tastes like meat and are so healthy too. No msg.
author: Cindy X.

description:
Not worth the time, money, or calories to eat here. Food just not good. 

Steamed dumplings were mis-cooked. The dough was undercooked and and unpleasant.  The filling was just some green vegetables and was a strange sour flavor.

It is pretty rare to get such bad dumplings. Not edible. 

The fried taro cake was a round batter fried tasteless lump, no seasonings. The veggie sticky rice dumpling (a dish I love at other restaurants) was dry, crumbling, tasteless. 

Everything tasted off. It seemed like there was no trained cook in the kitchen. It also tasted like the owners are buying cheap not-fresh ingredients.

The service staff was all young women that seemed like they could care less. We mentioned politely that the food tasted bad, and we had left most of it. The girl just looked at us blankly and said nothing.
author: Kristy M.

description: Kung pow chicken and chicken nuggets were both amazing! Absolutely love their menu the few items that are not vegan are actually disclosed as not vegan in the menu. if you're in town looking to take in some amazing vegan or vegetarian food you should definitely give this a try!
author: Taia H.

description: Friendly, unpretentious neighborhood eatery. Lots of Chinese favorites on the menu, but all vegetarian! I especially enjoyed the hot-and-sour soup with won tons 酸辣湯 + 雲吞. Dinner ran smoothly. Many other dishes on the extensive menu to try -- definitely worth a return visit.
author: Kevin H.

description: This is an awesome restaurant!! I took a bunch of non vegans and they all loved it!! The service is fast and complimentary tea is provided. Food is very good. Try the Kung Pao chicken it's delicious. They take credit card as well.
author: EatVegetarian F.

description:
I love vegetarian Chinese food complete with all the weird fake meats, but sadly, I've been disappointed with everything I've had here:

Really bland wonton soup, including the wonton fillings but especially the broth - it had a light spinach flavor but not much else. Really made me miss Loving Hut's veg wonton soup.

Sticky rice had way too much chalky bean filling and not enough of the other ingredients, and was not helped by the included sauce that seemed like just soy sauce. 

Pan fried noodles were like deep fried noodle crackers.

Entree with tofu and wheat gluten was quite bland - there was salt and not much else.
author: Victoria W.

description:
So for the past 2 years since I've been working in FIDI, I've pretty much avoided this place because it's vegetarian and there's absolutely no meat. They have "vegetarian meat" on their menu. I would joke with my friend about this place when we passed by, like "haha, yeah right, like we would ever eat here."
Well, fortunately some of my coworkers don't pig out like I do every lunch and dragged me out here for a healthier alternative one day. I was very surprised with the taste of everything we ordered.
The fried rice, the tofu dishes, the greens, and the vegetarian meats. The meat tasted real! They seem to have lunch specials as well that won't break the bank, so I may start ordering take-out from that menu on days I have to eat alone.
I believe there shouldn't be any barriers with language here either, as I know some of the restaurants in Chinatown don't speak very much English at all.
author: Mike O.

description: The food here was great, and I really liked being able to have the experience of a more typical Chinese restaurant while still having delicious vegan options. I brought two meat eaters here, both who enjoyed there food as much as I did. Would definitely have to recommend this place after the fast service, fair prices, and delicious food. Thank you!
author: Charlie Y.

description:
Highlights
- My favorite Chinese vegetarian restaurant! It's the one that I take my vegetarian visitors as I know they will appreciate this restaurant as much as I do. How do they make the food taste so darn good without using leeks, onions or garlic, and msg?!
- Lotus Root, lily, fungus, peas & ginko Nuts: This is the dish that keeps me coming back. Lotus roots are sliced thinly and sauteed so it has the perfect crunch. 
- Spinach & pine nuts fried rice: fragrant, flavorful, and delicious. Unique offering that I haven't seen at any other vegetarian restaurants. 

Improvements
- I came recently and portion sizes have gotten skimpier, since my previous visits. 
- Won ton soup w/ vegetables and mushroom: mushy vegetable filling of the wontons left me just a mediocre experience with this dish
- Mongolian soy beef w/ peppers & broccoli in a spicy sauce: yes, this dish delivers on the spicy side of the spectrum and flavor is on point, but the texture of the soy beef always leaves me with something less to be desired, my personal preference. Haven't experienced a good vegetarian dish as of yet. 

Tips
- Parking is relatively easy with a parking garage nearby or you can test out your luck with the street parking.
- Never a wait when I came several times for weekday dinners.
author: Tracy T.

description:
I want to start off by saying that this place doesn't have the best service. In my past experiences, my servers have been very serious and grumpy looking. They don't greet you nor smile. They just take your order and walk away. In fact, I felt so intimidated that I didn't even feel comfortable to ask for a fork. (chopsticks are the primary utensil in this restaurant) Maybe its just me...but I like to feel welcomed when I eat a restaurant. 

Despite the mediocre service, THE FOOD IS AMAZING. My partner is a non-meat eater so we were very happy when we found out about this place. We fell in love from the first time we ate here. It's so great to eat a restaurant where they have meat alternatives other than tofu. The fake meats are very tasty and taste very similar to real meats. 

I recommend the black pepper chow mein with chicken as well as the mongolian beef. Both "meats" taste so real! I also had the kung pao chicken and it was alright. I wish there was an Enjoy Vegeterian in the Santa Cruz area. I would eat there all the time!
author: Andrea C.

description:
I love this style of Chinese/Taiwanese vegan food. The menu is diverse, with lots of yummy faux meats (wheat gluten, mushroom etc.) and delicious tofu.  

The restaurant itself is lively, pleasant and comfortable. Service is good.

 I could eat here every day and never get bored.
author: James E.

description:
Yay for veggie food! Very affordable and they have my favorite soup-veggie shark fin. Sounds awful and they should really rename it to mushroom soup with clear noodles. The vinegar they provide to add into the soup is a nice touch.

It is normally busy but never a wait over 10 mins. All of the entrees I've had are really good. Nuggets and spring roll appetizers are easily a win. Soy basil protein nuggets also another favorite. Comes with broccoli and other vegetables. 

Love to support restaurants like this.
author: Stine H.

description:
I went to this restaurant for dinner with my friend, but both of us were very disappointed about their poor service. One of the waitress was extremely rude and yelled at us "if every customer did like you we would lose our business!!!" when we tried to switch to a bit bigger table because we saw lots of available tables. I looked around, we had been sitting for about 10 mins and we were still the only customers in the restaurant. The business was pretty slow around 5 pm when it just opened, why made it so harsh to the customers? In addition to that, after she yelled, she ran to the tables where we sat at earlier kept banging the empty chairs on the floor furiously and angrily by making loud noises.

That was a very bad experience for us.  Our mood was totally ruined during the dinner. The waitress didn't know to respect customers at all.Besides, the food was ok but not good as expected. The foods are overpriced  with small portion. We will never go back to the restaurant and we don't recommend it to any one of our friends!
author: Jesse L.

description:
Food: Extensive vegan friendly menu with many tofu/tempeh/soy meats. Many dishes to choose from! I had the Veggie Delight and fried taro cakes. Both were delicious. The taro cakes were savory and sweet, served with a yummy syrup sauce. The Veggie Delight was good, especially the mushrooms. 

Service: Very attentive and accommodating.

Ambiance: Super clean. I was thrown off at first - didn't expect the food to be good because most of the time, it's either the place has nice decor OR the food is good. Lucky for me, Enjoy Vegetarian is both clean and serves great food!

Overall, four stars.
author: Shannon H.

description:
I ordered the tofu dish ,also rice.
The restaurant is very calm ,they have Chinese music playing in the background.
The tofu is a little too spicy 
,The rice I ordered was brown and a little on thick side .  Next time I will try to order something else .  For desert ,I ordered the Winnie the Pooh , also I ordered the banana with vegan cherry ice cream ,soooo good .I would recommend this restaurant also they have two other locations to choose from
author: Jennifer G.

description:
CNN Travel named Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant as one of the top 50 Chinese restaurants in the country! M-F from 11am to 2pm there is a lunch special for $9.99 that includes an entree with brown or white rice along with a spring roll. Complementary tea is served yet didn't have it as I avoid caffeinated beverages. 

Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant is the second all vegan Chinese restaurant I've been to recently in San Francisco's Chinatown. The biggest challenge here is too much choice as there are 50 items to choose from for the lunch special & all of them are vegan so it is truly a vegan heaven!

One of my favorite things about Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant is that the menu has pictures of each of the entrees so this gives you a good sense of what you order. I've often gone to other restaurants & what I think I'm ordering turns out to be something quite different.

I decided to order- L37 Kung Pao Tofu w/ Pepper & Broccoli宮保豆腐

As the picture menu showcased this entree had lots of broccoli & bell pepper which was what I wanted along with a good amount of tofu. The Kung Pao Tofu entree also comes with peanuts. 

The Kung Pao Tofu was listed under the spicy section yet didn't find it that spicy yet the flavor was great & you can always ask for it to be more spicy. If you want more of kick there is hot sauce on the table to make it more spicy yourself.

Portions here are hearty so bring your appetite or bring a friend to share or bring your own tupperware to take home leftovers. Eating lunch here will give you some plant powered fuel to conquer the surreal epic hills nearby that makes San Francisco so famous & fun to explore.

Also worth checking out nearby is the oasis in the city & one of my favorite bookstores on the planet "City Lights Bookstore" which is just a four minute walk away. 

I look forward to returning to Enjoy Vegetarian to try out some more of the 50 entrees. You can almost come here once a week for a year getting a different entree each week!
author: Shane S.

description:
The lettuce wrap was to die for! Order it!!!

The "chicken" noodle soup hits the spot on a day you want some broth to make you feel better.

I've come back many times.

Don't forget free egg roll with your lunch special.
author: Lily V.

description:
I left this place impressed! I've tried other vegan/vegetarian chinese places in the past and it's made me a little hesitant to try more. However, my friend told me about this place and we ended up having dinner here around 6PM on a weekday night. 

Right near the Hilton hotel in Chinatown/on Kearny it's an easy place to find. I docked the review 1 star because the service was a bit slow and inattentive. Right when I walked in I wasn't sure whether I was to wait for someone to seat me or sit down myself since the workers were near the cashier in the back so I tried sitting at a table but was asked to move to another table. 

TBH I was still a little hesitant when ordering but we ended up getting the broccoli beef (had carrots) and rice cakes w/ mustard greens. Both were DELICIOUS. The veggies were perfectly cooked/crunchy and the fake meat was flavorful. I can honestly say it's some of the best, if not the best i've had so far. The rice cakes were also a new fave in my book. They give you tons of greens with the rice cakes so it doesn't feel too heavy and it adds a nice change in texture to the dish. They give you plenty in portions as well! For 2 people we had tons left over and left feeling full.

I was greatly surprised and will definitely be coming back here/bring my friends! Don't worry if fake meat isn't on your list to try because they have a large variety of noodles, veggies, and tofu dishes.
author: Keizzel C.

description: Went here recently. Got a bunch of dishes. Overall I liked this place and was happy to see a full vegetarian Chinese dish menu. There is a lot of fried stuff but I tried to get some non fried things. I enjoyed the tofu dishes. The service was pretty good. Overall I thought it was a pretty good place for what it is. There are not that many of these places around that I have seen.
author: Johnson B.

description: Decided to go here for lunch with my sister because she's vegetarian. Only came here because of the comments but not that great.  My family is Chinese and vegetarian and my mom makes way taster food than here. Fried tofu with salt & pepper was good but Kung Pao Chicken with broccoli don't get it, sauce is gross. Waiter forgot our tea until I ask her and she had an attitude about it and also gave me a dirty napkin. Would have never came here if my sister wasn't with me.
author: Angie L.

description:
This is a great place for all the vegetarian and Non vegetarian. 

I have been here many times and finally got the chance to write reviews for them. 

I am not a vegetarian but I really enjoy their food and I would bring my vegetarian friends here and they enjoy it as well.  

Food: My to go would be their spinach pine nut fried rice: DELICIOUS!!!! MUST GET!!!
their egg plant with tofu sauteed with basil sauce is fairly good too.  
chicken with taro over coconut sauce is very tasty too.  the texture of their chicken and flavoring its very close to be real chicken.  Kinda fool me a little. 
had their mongolian beef once and it was quite tasty. 
i forgot the name of it and it was serve in the bamboo basket and it was ok.  not the best.  don't think i would get it. 
there are more to name but I have to say they are all fairly good.  

Service: its good, but can't be little slow.  Beware they do get pretty busy during lunch rush.  

atmosphere: very cozy feeling and roomy.  Their decor is fairly new and modern.  its a nice hang out spot during lunch. I just wish my lunch break is longer so i can just hang out there.
author: Candice Y.

description:
Good food, but skip this spot. Wait staff use deceiving upsells. 

Ordering my meal and response was "White or brown rice?". In a tone that was clearly intended to deceive the individual into assuming it came with the rice. Then I learned it wasn't included and cost $2. 

Listen, I don't care about $2, but some people do. Don't use deceiving tactics to inflate your revenue.
author: Jake R.

description: Got takeout tonight and wanted something healthy. Decided to try the golden knots and.....Who knew vegetarian Chinese food be so good?! Steamed beancurd stuffed with tofu and mushrooms and bokchoy. A meal that was meant to be split but I killed all by myself. #sogood #chinesevegetarian #beancurd #maybeicouldtrybeingvegetarian
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Meh. I've experienced better hence the 2 stars. 

The crispy chicken was good, but it was not mind blowing. I had the garlic knots and I absolutely love bean curd, but the dish all together.....tasted like mush. It tasted like baby food or food that someone chewed and then decided to spit out and wrap in bean curd. It was very bland and the texture was so gross.

I will not be back because I know there is better out there.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Let me begin by saying that this is hard as I rarely have poor experiences at restaurants. However, I did not enjoy the food or service received at EVR. The vegan appetizer and first vegan entree were flavorless. So bad, I ordered a second entree (vegan curry noodles) and it was equally bad. So I paid my bill and said to myself "no worries". I just won't go back and chalk it up to a bad choice. I own it. But when my secretary prepares my expense report she calls me the charge and the receipt don't match. She called EVR and they faxed back another persons bill but with my signed portion of the receipt was altered for almost double the amount. I compared my receipt vs. theirs and clearly was falsified. So we're working with EVR but it's taking a long time and calls back are not happening as they should. I plan to dispute the entire bill now with the credit card company. 

- Disappointed in San Francisco
author: Ives Z.

description: not the best vegetarian restaurant but i would come back to try the rest of what they have to offer.  i went with a friend and we ordered thai vermicelli soup and a dish with basil, eggplant and tofu.  the soup tasted average, though it was a large portion.   the basil, eggplant and tofu dish was tasty but quite oily.
author: Thuy P.

description: Love this place. Service is always good and fast. Food is great. Really healthy options.
author: Nathan E.

description: I like this place a lot, for me the noodles were the best part because personally I'm just not that big a fan of tofu and it's natural form
author: star f.

description:
While I prefer real meat to faux meat, I love that there's a Chinese food restaurant I can eat at in my neighborhood where I don't have to worry about any shellfish being present. Having an allergy to shellfish in this city can be a real drag :) 

The food is also quite delicious, and the staff is always very kind.
author: Leah C.

description: Great vegetarian food! The dishes come out hot in temperature and very tasty in both take out and eating there. The service is friendly. I've mostly been ordering take out lately and I've been very pleased with the quality. The portions in the take out are big.
author: Jen L.

description: OK food but really bad customer service. Asking for soy sauce is met with a look of distaste and requesting another beer is met with "really, you want me to wait on you". First and last time coming here.
author: Elzabeth G.

description:
Good vegetarian food. Not the best Asian faux meat I've had but it was definitely good.

Extensive menu. Decent prices. Service wasn't particularly friendly but it wasn't nasty either. 

Lunch specials only applicable during the week.

I was just happy to find a wall charger to charge my dying phone!
author: Maria E.

description: Delicious, healthy, fast. Love this place and so glad it's near my office. Great lunch special with lots of options. Exactly what I was hoping for.
author: Andrew H.

description: So delicious! Thankfully they were open on Christmas so I was able to eat my birthday dinner here while in town. Thought it was funny my girlfriend saw "chicken" and "beef" dishes and was confused as to how this was a vegetarian restaurant. Had to explain it was all imitation. Neither of us are vegan or vegetarian but thoroughly enjoyed the food. The flavors are amazing and service was good as well. They were nice enough to swap out the curry vermicelli for a different vermicelli dish. Had a funny encounter with the people eating at the table beside us who were equally as confused as to if their sea bass was actually sea bass. They learned it was eggplant and were beyond disappointed. Haha who orders sea bass for Christmas dinner?
author: Dominic R.

description:
Enjoy Vegeterian has many faux meat options but i passed them up. went for something simple. 

dining area is more upscale in ambience than most Chinatown eateries.
eats: singapore style rice vermicelli noodles with curry(9.99)
-has some veggies, average taste, faint curry flavor,
-slight aftertaste, portion average.

take outs:
-large menu
-lots of choices for lunch specials (M-F)
-food came out quickly.
author: Victor G.

description: It's really sad that the food is Soooooo good here. The service is absolute shit. Our waitress snatched menus out of our hands, and had complete attitude.  Then when we payed our bill she had the nerve to come back and slap my money on the table and say "the tip isn't included". And walk away, leaving the tab and the money. First of all, I was going to leave a tip. But when you come to me and demand it, fuck that. I left my money that was good for the bill and walked out. I'll order to go next time. Y'all suck a fat one.
author: Dee H.

description: This is so good. The menu is amazing and their selection of dishes is extensive. I can't recommend this place more than 5 stars
author: Kasey B.

description:
lettuce wrap !!!!!
lettuce. wrap. 
lettuce wrap filling was the best faux meat i've ever had. 

i also got the bean curd and chives. 10/10
steamed dumplings were also full of flavor and herbs, better than most !!

i also ordered the duck which was a weird texture but very tasty. Overall best vegan i had in sf so far !!!
author: Audrey L.

description:
I had searched few vegan restaurants around  downtown  sf. This was the closest one. 
Food was great, service was okay, parking was terrible.
author: Baji J.

description: We truly enjoyed the vegetarian duck, chicken and lotus root with gingko, peas and mushrooms.  Cheerful service
author: David W.

description: Given all the food options in Chinatown, I'm very pleased that we decided on this place. Not only is the menu completely vegetarian, but the food was delicious! The meat substitutes were impressive. The service was fast, and the prices were fair. Check it out if you get the chance!
author: Victoria C.

description:
Vegetarian shark fin soup, faux chicken nuggets, and round after round of beer on Christmas day make Enjoy the ideal place for a girl's night out for my bestie and I. 

Enjoy Vegetarian knows how to do it up and what better way to celebrate the birth of the Messiah than with a meatless outing with my bestest? Ok, just kidding about the messiah part. There's no religion in my life but we did for sure enjoy celebrate having the day off work, even if it did involve the union of Church and State. 

Enjoy is more of a no-frills than flashy place but it gets the job done and the menu will surely have you torn between several items so I'd recommend going with a friend or two and going hard on the sharing.

My bestie and I are both kiving a no-meat lifestyle so having sucha  large and veg-exclusive menu felt luxurious even though the ambience here ranks only slightly above hole in the wall. 

We split a few things, including the... 

** Vegetarian Shark Fin Soup - which was pretty tasty and perfect when loaded with my favorite diner-style table pepper.

** Veggie Potstickers - we both agreed we could have eaten 3 more orders of these. Delish and great for sharing. The portion is more than fair, though the size of the potstickers overall is on the smaller side. 

** Veggie Chicken Nuggets - I mean, they didn't round out a balanced meal or anything but we'd had a few beers by this point and the not-chicken nuggets were everything we could have dreamed of and more. 

Service was pretty on point for how busy they were and I loved that no one tried to wish us a merry Christmas because it's absolutely my least favorite holiday out there. 

Our bills was under $30, even with alcohol and hot tea, so it was a nice wallet-friendly nightcap for my fellow penny pincher friend and I.
author: Candice G.

description: This place is so good - I don't typically like fake meat dishes but their spareribs with daikon and green beans with chicken are really good.  Been here like five times and always get the ribs.  The house fried rice was nice as well.  A few of the other dishes were decent, but come back for the two mentioned above.  Non-veggie kids and wife really enjoyed this place as well.  Win win.
author: Rick K.

description:
Have only been here two times - but so far, so good. I would've never really cared to step foot in this place if not for Mealpass and from hearing about it from my coworkers (they're mainly non-Chinese though so I was still a bit skeptical..)

My diet is mostly vegetarian so it's nice to not have to ignore the non-meat items on the menu for a change as EVERYTHING is vegetarian. Generous portions, cooked properly, flavorful, filling, and .. somewhat healthy - not TOO oily like most Chinese food, but more saucey than I'd like.

$9.99 for their lunch special is a steal for the (borderlining) FIDI area. I'm surprised not more people come here! It comes with a spring roll, about 2 scoops of brown or white rice, and choice of entree (so much variety!). It's enough to make 1.5 or even 2 meals for me. Everything is flavorful and seasoned properly, so you won't even miss the meat. I've read the meat substitutes are actually pretty good, too - I haven't tried it yet, so I can't speak to it.

So far, I've gotten the string beans + eggplant and bean curd rolls with vegetables. Their other items are probably just as good, judging from the execution of both.

I've only gotten pick-up orders and the service is prompt and efficient - they know both English and Chinese.
author: Emily C.

description:
ENJOY vegetarian restaurant..? My experience was anything but enjoyable. Came to this restaurant because of the amazing Yelp reviews but don't let that fool you. I gave this place 2 stars (instead of 1) because the food was half decent - but it surly didn't make up for the horrible service. 

When I arrived to the restaurant we were quickly seated but it took a while for the lady to take our order, she had to be reminded several times to bring our drink order before it actually arrived. Also, she never once smiled! 

My friend ordered a dish (which tasted very bland) so she asked to return it. The owned approved, but when we received our bill, to our dismay she told us she won't be taking off the dish we returned  (costing $13.99 + $2.00 for extra for a small side of peanut sauce) but instead she will just take off one of the appetizers we ordered (costing $6.99). We looked at her with confusion but she just walked away. 

We payed the bill and left - but we definitely went be going back.
author: Tiffany A.

description: Love their vegetarian chicken noodles soup. Very nice flavors and the egg noodles are very chewy. Also like their sour and spicy soup. Great for a cold day if you want to get warm
author: Yuan Z.

description:
This place is awesome place. I would say it's about 99% vegan, have 1-2 dishes vegetarian. Not sure why, but oh, well.
