My favorites are the wheat gluten-combo, the fragrant chicken and the veggie duck. I know, my choices are a bit on the greasy/fried side, but I love these and don't get very often.

Sad they closed 1 of their 3 stores. My favorite is Chinatown location!
author: Chad J.

description: So freaking good! The soy chicken chow mein is ridiculous!  I love it so much. Also the sweet and sour soy chicken is fantastically full of flavors. We had ours delivered to our room so no view of the restaurant but the food is a vegans dream.
author: Melanie S.

description: I've dined here a number of times with friends and colleagues, for both business and informal purposes.  Extensive menu that is as lengthy as a dissertation.  Food is generally quite good, some dishes being better than others.  What can be annoying, however, is the fact that during certain periods of time, dishes arrive at our table that's anything but piping hot.  Doesn't make for a pleasurable dining experience at an otherwise decent Chinese vegetarian eatery.  BTW, the medicinal soup (#23) is the one thing needful on a cold day or night, or if you're feeling exhausted or fatigued.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
Not that many places do chinese style vegetarian dish. We spend our Friday night at this restaurant. It wasn't packed during our stay. We tried several dishes:

1) fried taro - too dry, not much flavor
2) assorted appetizer  - I recommend this one, you would get a variety of starter. If you like any of them, you can order more.
3) beef stew and lamb stew - they are essentially the same "meat", not much flavor and quite chewy
4) house fried rice - quite oily and salty

I probably wouldn't repeat, I would try another vegetarian spot. They don't offer stamp for the portsmouth parking garage at this restaurant =(
author: Gary C.

description:
For those who complain about lack of flavor, I disagree and think Enjoy uses just the right amount.  The gluten, mushroom, tofu and vegetable dish was perfectly prepared, with pillow-soft tofu, a medium-bodied yet delicate sauce, and crunchy carrots and broccoli.  This dish was the star of my meal and easily earns 4 stars.

However, I ordered that dish only after the other dishes oddly came out one at a time and I wasn't able to truly have a meal.  The sticky rice dumpling was simply a version of bah-san that tasted okay, but was rather dry (perhaps overheated in the microwave).  It would have been more enjoyable if it really was freshly steamed.  The nicely flavored veggie duck seemed quickly heated in the pan, as well.  I did arrive near closing time, but it was a good hour beforehand and these dishes just felt like "day-old" offerings.  The steamed veggie dumplings were obviously freshly steamed and looked good; however, I couldn't eat them once I realized there was celery inside.  I barely took a bite of one; I'm terribly allergic to celery -- as in stomach-churning vomiting kind of allergic without even having to taste it.  The waitress looked understandably annoyed and I said it wasn't her fault, but the bill came with dumplings still being charged to me.  Since I'm staying in a hotel and attending an all-day conference tomorrow, I wouldn't have been able to carry it around all day and then reheat at home even it didn't have celery in it.  Overall, the food didn't make up for the typical unfriendly Chinese restaurant service, and I left very unimpressed.
author: Sherri C.

description: If you're vegetarian or vegan and want all the awesome flavor and spice of Chinese food, this place is awesome. I ordered Tom Yum soup and Kung Pao "Chicken". Great!
author: Guillermo M.

description:
One of my favorite lunch spots because of their $10 lunch special (entree served with rice and spring roll)

You really can't go wrong with anything on the menu but here are some of my favorites:  Eggplant in Spicy Chilli Sauce, Singapore Style Chow Rice Vermicelli, Curry Tofu Udon Soup w/ vegetables, and Pai Pa Tofu Balls w/ Broccoli & Mushroom
author: Jessica H.

description: Delightful vegetarian food for both veggie and meat lovers. I usually eat meat but here, I like the food so much that I don't even miss it. When you look at the menu, the dishes that are listed as meats are actually meat-free, with tofu-based gluten seasoned and prepared to resemble beef, chicken or pork. I recommend going with at least a couple of other people and sharing dishes.
author: Lucy L.

description:
I came in roughly 10 minutes before they were closing for lunch with the intent to order takeout. But the gal that initially greeted me invited me to dine in if I chose to. That was really sweet of her to offer but I had a few people in tow: the meateater BF, my meateater auntie, and meateater mom who was taking bites of a meaty pork bun when we walked into this vegetarian restaurant which clearly has a "no meat" sign on the front door. Imagine my embarrassment. So the BF politely scooted my mom and auntie outside for a walk while I waited for my food.

Even though they were about to close, the gal never made me feel rushed. I asked for recommendations and the gal spent some time looking at the menu with me offering great suggestions. Even the patrons who were finishing up their dine-in lunches were friendly to offer suggestions!

There was one particular employee who did rub me the wrong way. Call me overly sensitive but sternly yelling "HEY!" at a customer is not a very polite way to catch someone's attention.

Luckily, the friendly gal that took my order was the same gal that delivered my food and I left on a good note. She was even sweet to point out that I was given a Veggie Spring Roll which is included with the lunch special: http://bit.ly/1AuzAec

Per her recommendation, I ordered the Kung Pao Soy Chicken with red bell peppers, large chunks of broccoli, and peanuts in a spicy chili sauce with brown rice. Tasty tasty stuff! I liked the bit of kick in the sauce, the fresh al dente-ness of the broccoli, and the equal amounts of soy chicken to vegetables. For this $8 lunch special, it was good portion size. Since I couldn't finish, leftovers made a great meal for later. http://bit.ly/1KfD99J

Definitely a fan! I plan to return and check out more menu items :)
author: Harmonie T.

description: Not sure if I just ordered the wrong item, but within 5 minutes of taking my first bite of Basil Soy Chicken with mixed vegetables, I experienced painfully debilitating heartburn like I've never experienced before in my life.  I thought it might be the fake meat, so I pushed all of it to the side and focused on the vegetables, to no avail.  I ended up eating about half of the dish before getting up and walking out.  I dealt with the aftermath for the next several days. I would have loved to add a new vegetarian place to my repertoire, but after that experience, I will not be coming here again. If you're not into heavily processed, fake-meat, and thick sauces containing who-knows-what, give this place a pass.
author: Reece P.

description:
great lunch menu which includes brown rice at no extra cost

I enjoy their curry dishes and anything with lotus root in it.

For takeout, I treat myself with Chinese rice tamale, which I can heat up for future meals.
author: Veggie G.

description:
If you work at one of the myriad tech companies in the City, then you know the vegetarian options are often reduced to some random tofu dish--whether baked, fried or firm--that attempts to poorly emulate one of the main entrees that the carnivores seem to have a much more pleasant encounter with. This is, of course, an insult to tofu--a versatile weapon in the kitchen--it is reduced to being little more than a token gesture.

Enjoy is a pleasant reminder that vegetarian takes on meat-based dishes can be done without sacrificing flavor. It has no airs about itself; its dishes are pleasant and filling versions of standard dishes one would find at many Chinese restaurants presented as-is; its service is standard for most Chinese restaurants: blunt and to the point (you're here for the food, not the service). Being just a short walk away from the Financial District, it is definitely worth keeping on a list of restaurants should one have any vegetarians in the lunch crowd.
author: Erwin T.

description:
This is a pretty good restaurant on Kearny Street, which means that you cannot miss it as it is on the main street .

My colleague, her husband, my husband and I had a gathering there. We enjoyed the basil eggplant so much and we definitely want to come back.

And one thing special about the restaurant is that their employees are very honest. There's a dish called glutinous rice ball, boiling sweet rice wine. They served a dish of that to us but it didn't taste good. The waitress later explained to me that it was because the kitchen didn't prepare it well.

I appreciated her honesty. 

Four stars :) 

yours,
Jun
author: Jun L.

description: Best vegetarian Chinese food in San Francisco! Get the fragrant crispy (vegetarian) chicken, you will be amazed. Also the Kung Pao tofu is awesome!
author: Seth W.

description:
I let my sister choose where to eat lunch one day and she mentioned Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant. I was hesitant about eating here because at heart, I am a carnivore but I have nothing against veggies and am always open to trying new foods. I checked out the Yelp profile as well as their website and saw that they offered a variety of dishes, including many with meat substitutes. After seeing photos, I wanted to try the "chicken" drumsticks for sure. 

We came on a weekday at around 11:45am and there was only one other customer. The restaurant felt clean and bright. We sat at a four-person table but the waitress asked us to move to a two-person table, as she did with other single and couple customers. Moving was no problem but I was assuming the restaurant was going to get very busy yet by the time we left about 45 minutes later, I would say only half of the restaurant filled-up. A group of 8 folks came in so if you're interested in visiting with lots of people, they can accommodate larger groups. 

We indeed ordered the drumsticks to start. I decided to order the won ton noodle soup with veggies and veggie "ham," and my sis ordered the braised "spareribs" with daikon and other veggies. The lunch dishes each came with a basic veggie spring roll but I was a bit concerned because my spring roll was straight cold and old, and my sis' spring roll was hot and fresh out of the fryer. Despite this, I have to say that all of the food was flavorful. The veggies were fresh and I really enjoyed the braised daikon which was so tender. The "meats" were as meaty as could be in light of they fact that they weren't actually real meat. The ham in my soup was smoky and the drumsticks and the spareribs had meat-like texture in which they would shred as if you were biting a real piece of chicken or rib. Overall, I found that the food was satisfying!
author: Maya S.

description:
This place is more for meat eaters because the plant based meat tastes exactly like meat! I am blown away by quality and taste of every single dish I tried on the menu! You'll see different type of people in this place who enjoys vegetarian food, from Wall Street executives to local techies to foodies from all over the world.
Humbled establishment, but everything does right!!!
Much love!!
author: Ana S.

description:
Solid vegetarian restaurant. Always so surprised how meat-y everything is. Service is not spectacular but it gets the job done. No lunch specials on the weekends. Would recommend for vegetarians and meat eaters alike. 

Also--they are pretty skimpy on rice and charge by the bowl.
author: Anna H.

description: Came here for a late lunch. Wish they had lunch specials, but no dice - so I ordered a wonton noodle soup. Tasty enough, though not the most flavorful. $10+tax, so a bit pricey given what you're getting. Staff are decent, though not friendly. Solid place, but there are better vegetarian Chinese places in SF's Chinatown.
author: Matt B.

description: One of the better choices for the vegetarians. Love the spinach rice. Service is very friendly and super fast. Their coconut curry with pumpkin & taro is quite unique. Must try for veggies.
author: Sudhakar K.

description: Tried eat 24 for the first time today and they sent my order to the wrong enjoy location. I explained the error to the young lady at the restaurant and they quickly made my order. Good customer service.
author: Jingo Django J.

description:
This a pure vegetarian/vegan serving chinese cuisine.
If you are trying to go all veg, or are a meatatarian this place will actually work for you. The mock chicken dishes taste identical to the real chicken ones.
If you a pure vegan you'll be enjoying the same veg dishes you'd order at any chinese restaurant but without any possibility for cross contamination. 
The decor is more sophisticated then many other chinese style resturants, however it's dangerously close to being ticky tacky.
the staff are spot on, to the point of being over attentive, but that's better then being ignored.
I'd say this is one of the better all vegetarian restaurants in the area, and is perfect for new vegetarians or mixed groups vegetarians and non vegetarians needing a group dinner.
author: Steven W.

description: A group of us met there and had a nearly private space which was very nice. Everyone enjoyed the food; we ordered 7-8 shared dishes.
author: Leslie K.

description: Good Chinese food. We were pleased to see so many vegetarian choices in the heart of San Francisco Chinatown. Loved the steamed dumplings.
author: Savinay D.

description: The dumplings were good but the only things that were wrong was when I wanted orange juice all they had was apple juice and then I did not eat the rest of my meal
author: Jaxon M.

description: Vegan Chinese food, need I say more? The food is delicious and will fill you up! They're Buddhist and do not cook with meet or onions, garlic, leeks, etc. but you would hardly know by how good the food is! They have your favorites like sweet and sour "chicken" or "beef" and broccoli. They also do take out (the food is ready in like 10 minutes - so be ready so it doesn't get cold!) or delivery through a couple 3rd party companies which is also pretty fast (about 30 minutes). In addition, if you don't eat in, they will send out complimentary red bean buns as a dessert with your order. How sweet! :) The service is quick and attentive. I go nearly every week, and I don't see that changing any time soon.
author: Madeline F.

description: They food was pretty good. Not amazing but we still enjoyed it. The location is very interesting. You can take your kids to the amazing play ground next to the civic center. And if you have any food left, you can share it with many homeless people in that area.
author: Olga Y.

description: Ay. Where to begin. The soup was way too hot -- scalding -- and the entree colder than room temperature and almost congealed. The staff was friendly enough but overworked and busy waiting tables and busing the dirty dishes. The portions are generous but the quality was not of similar proportion.  We definitely will not return.
author: Anne M.

description:
Would recommend if you love meat because their fake meat is so alike, you could not distinguish the difference! Really loved the lotus, pumpkin, and coconut cream- all worked really well together! The string bean and eggplant was great too but a little bit too oily- the rice will balance it out! 

The free eggless spring rolls were to die for!

Oh and I would not recommend the medicine soup!!! It tasted horrid, I really didn't want to waste it but I just could not stomach it in- it tasted so bizarre!!
author: Natalie G.

description:
After reading some of the negative reviews I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed Enjoy. The steamed dumplings were so fresh and flavorful. Beef and broccoli also had a lot of flavor, though I found the "beef" to be lacking in texture. And the house spexial chow mein was perfect! Some reviews said there is limited vegetables here and while I find that to be true to many Asian restaurants, I thought they had a nice selection of fresh veggies.

You will see on the menu that they don't use any garlic or onion and we were fortunate enough to have the owner of the Enjoy chain serving us and she explained that Buddhist don't use them because it causes heart burn and other stomach issues that intefere with meditation and daily activity. For not using some of the most widely used ingredients for flavoring this food is so delicious!
author: Camille R.

description: The staff didn't seem too enjoyable to be there, and as such the environment was slightly uncomfortable. However, the food was very good, and my family and I were comforted that it was all vegetarian. Despite the unfriendliness of the staff, we will definitely come back.
author: Ajay J.

description: This place serves a variety of delicious Chinese/Asian vegetarian food that will wow vegetarians. I ordered a vegetarian duck for appetizers and a wonton noodle soup with veggies and veggie ham, and I know I'll come back again for weekend lunches! Food is served fast and nice despite its popularity.
author: Tony C.

description: All vegetarian but soy meats taste exactly like the real thing! My soy chicken and veggies tasted similar to real chicken! The lunch portions are large and come with brown or white rice and a spring roll. Only for $10! Quick service and fresh food! Gets really busy after 12pm so try to come a little earlier. I surely enjoyed my lunch and so will you!
author: Noor S.

description:
I've been here a few times since it's close to my office.

The food is not good nor innovative.  I must have had over 5 different items from the menu and they have basically the same veggies (chopped carrots & celery, frozen peas, etc).

I'm still on the hunt for a great vegetarian restaurant that serves hot food (and not starchy pasta, rice, etc).
author: Susan C.

description:
I am not normally a vegetarian but thoroughly enjoyed my dinner from here.  The textures and flavors were excellent, the non-meat proteins were creative and well prepared, and the food wasn't overly salty which has been my experience with some other vegetarian restaurants.  

The atmosphere was casual and felt ok going in wearing shorts and a tshirt.  The food was ready very quickly.  There was abundant water and hot tea available to accompany my meal.

The green veggie fried rice was fantastic.  I will definitely return for another meal before I head back home!  It was the best tasting and most affordable meal I've had in San Francisco to date. 

If you have the opportunity to check it out, even if you aren't a vegetarian, please stop in!
author: Jeff B.

description: I give this place 3.5 stars. The service could be improved as the staff make you feel rushed and while there are one or two who smile and appear friendly, the others are curt, stoic, and seemingly impatient. Their prices are also high compared to Lucky Creations just up the street. However, their hot and sour soup is the best vegetarian hot & sour that I've had and I prefer their taro rolls to those at Lucky. We also enjoy their eggplant and string beans in black bean sauce (though we wish it were saucier) and their chow mein and Singapore style noodles (we request it without the curry flavor, which they accommodate).
author: Janjri V.

description:
This location is near Chinatown and close by one of the City College campuses. 

A waitress will seat you and bring you a menu and a hot pot of tea. I don't know why but they only hand you the main menu. You have to ask your server for the drink and dessert menu. One would think they would want to sell more of the iced teas but unless you know they have drink menu, you wouldn't even know they exist. I usually order them with the popping boba but the last visit wasn't able to because the waitress said they don't have them anymore. I hope they bring them back.

There are book shelves with Buddhist literature for your viewing pleasure if you find yourself alone. Everything on the menu is vegan. They don't cook or use garlic or onions in dishes because they follow the Buddhist rules of vegetarian eating. Near the cash register, they sell some packets of mock meat. The bathrooms are close by the cash register. 

I have had the wonton noodle soup and enjoyed it with a friend. They brought out a ladle and small bowls along with the big bowl of soup. There were plenty of vegetables in the hot soup. The soft wontons were stuffed with veggie filling. The soup had a mild flavor which is fine for me but you might want to order something different if you want more of a punch in flavor. I think it is a good choice for warming up in the winter. I usually order the basil soy chicken. It has carrots, broccoli, bell peppers, basil, and faux chicken simmered in a savory broth. I have never ordered dessert so I can't comment on it. 

My friend, A., has tried the braised ribs, fatty pork slices, and golden knots. He liked the braised ribs best. The golden knots were his least favorite. My friend, S., had the walnut prawns and didn't like the creamy sauce that came with it. He only ate half of the dish. He did say the faux prawns were ok. 

For most of my visits, the service was either polite and friendly or indifferent but still somewhat attentive. Unfortunately the last visit had poor service and the server acted like she didn't want to be there. She barely came around and looked annoyed when I asked for the drink menu. She also gave my friend and I the wrong drinks. I can understand dealing with people can get tiring so perhaps she was having a bad day. Hopefully this poor service won't happen again. 

Next time, I am going to try the braised ribs.
author: S A.

description:
Their bean curd, soy ingredients and vegetarian dishes that looks like meat, are deceiving to the eye and tasted mighty fine!  

I loved the starters that looked like fried chicken and curry samosas!

The clay pot that looked like beef, was well-made.  I would say that the sweet and sour bean curd entree was the best of all the entrees.  Their cabbage wrapped mu-shu vegetables, were commendable as well.  Make sure to get the longevity noodles for long life!

If you have room, their sesame balls are freshly fried.

Service was above average because they came around taking the plates away and refilled our waters constantly.

This is one of the better vegetarian spots that I have been to.
author: Tiffany D.

description: The foods are bomb, however the service is just OKay.
author: Erica T.

description:
Do yourself a favor and don't go here. Terrible service. Not talking the kind where your water isn't refilled. This is the kind where they scold if you take more than 2 mins to decide (they have a huge menu and all of it sound great so I needed some more time to decide). Grumpy service later it was time for the check. I added the total directly without writing the tip amount separately and the server came by scolded me, quite loudly for not adding atleast 10%. I had, she just had to do the math. 

I do not eat out to be embarrassed and scolded so if you're one of those, skip.
author: Dagny T.

description: I loved my experience here. Place is very cute, huge selection on vegan/vegetarian options. Food is REALLY GOOD. Recommend to everyone doesn't matter if you eat meat or not - you will like it here! My picky bf lived his cho main, we also got some appetizers and spinach fried rise with pine nuts and coconut vegan chicken. Delicious, and portions are also pretty big. Love love love!
author: Nia V.

description: By far, this is one of my favorite restaurants to go to.  It is unique because Enjoy Vegetarian offer a variety of dishes that also, includes the Buddhist style of cooking.  I love ordering the Shark Fin Soup there because it is the only place that I know of that serves vegan Shark Fin Soup.  I definitely recommend going to Enjoy Vegetarian.  Be sure to check when they are open though because they are only open for certain hours for lunch and dinner.
author: May D.

description:
I certainly enjoyed this Enjoy vegetarian cuisine. The foods we ordered are promptly prepared. 
I found their ingredients used are well mixed. Not greasy, which is a plus. Such was a healthy choice.
author: Monarch T.

description:
One great dish (spicy eggplant) and one not so great (toro and coconut and something else). We should not have ordered the second dish - we like spicy food and the waitress explained that it might not be our best choice from the menu. The menu is huge and everyone around us seemed to love the food.
Not pretentious, good boba.
I would good back.
PS - I am a vegetarian
author: Michael R.

description:
We walked into this restaurant at 2 pm on a Saturday afternoon. We knew the restaurant would close at 230, but assumed that they would serve all customers who walked in till 230. The waitress took our order for 5 items. She seemed a little rude and told us several times to hurry up..but, we let it pass. After a few minutes, we got 3 items. We asked for the other two items. The waitress informed us that those 2 items can't be made! 
Then one of her colleagues walked towards our table and told us we can't place any new order as it was almost their closing time. We said we didn't want to place a new order, but were expecting to receive items we had already ordered. She checked with the waitress who had taken our order, came back and grudgingly asked us if we still wanted the items. We said no! She seemed relieved to hear our response and came back with the cheque. 

Overall, everyone at the restaurant seemed impatient and rude. If 230 is a hard stop, they should not accept walk-ins after 145 or 2 pm. It didn't seem right to let people walk in and then make them feel unwelcome. The food was decent - but, their attitude and service will never make us want to go back.
author: Rashmi U.

description:
I really liked this place! Nothing fancy, but very good food overall. We got the crispy tofu w/ salt and chili peppers for appetizer, and the pan fried vegetable chow mien (crispy noodles). The tofu was very delicious and had great texture. The noodles had amazing flavor! I've only ever had pan fried noodles served with the sauce on top, but this place served the sauce separately so it allowed us to keep the noodles crispy. MIGHT be the best pan fried noodles I've ever had -- it was really good.

Although I will say service was a bit subpar, took 3 tries to finally get our waters, but I don't really care too much about service at a place like this.
author: Hannah K.

description: Great selection of soup... Everything vegetarian... amazing ... Hot n sour soup today... Will try Thai spicy soup next time... Server said they are the 2 best seller!
author: Hana R.

description: As the name suggests, it truly is a place where vegetarians can savor so many delicious dishes. Loved it. We had the Twice Cooked pot and it was amazing.
author: Ankita P.

description: This restaurant has become one of our regular eat-out places. It is a medium-sized place, very friendly and clean, located in the heart of Chinatown. They do vegan Chinese food, which is the traditional Chinese dishes, only with soy and tofu instead of meat. I have not been to many places that have so many options for vegetarians and vegans. Soups are huge and the duck is the best I had in years. Very cheap, very fresh, good quality, nice service!
author: Danielle B.

description: The service can verge on the brusque, but you won't find better vegetarian food anywhere else. My go-to Chinese veggie joint in the City.
author: Hugh K.

description:
Ok, I like meat, so I had put off trying Enjoy Vegetarian. I jog past this almost everyday so my curiosity finally peaked. I have to admit their their faux meats had some novelty value.

Here is what I tried:

The vegie dumplings were good.

The faux fatty pork belly was a riot on so many levels. I really liked it as well.

The faux chicken drumsticks were also amusing and pretty good.
 
The green beans with faux pork were ok.

Well worth a visit
author: David T.

description: The service was great and the food was tasty. I recommend the chicken bites. My non-vegetarian boyfriend couldn't believe it was meat-free! The restaurant is spacious and the menu is extensive. Also the tea place next door is worth a visit.
author: Mary S.

description: Love how vegan friendly this place is! Came here the first night i moved to the city and was surprised by how good the food is. Food comes out shortly after you order. However, service isnt always that good. i have been sat down and not given a menu for 10 minutes before. Wish i could give more stars but sadly ive had poor service more than ive had good service here.
author: Taylor A.

description: I can only review the take-out experience, but I'm not a big fan of their food. It's not bad but it's weird. Perhaps it's too authentic for my uneducated in Asian cuisines self but I didn't really like my veggie fried rice and the bokchoy soy chicken.
author: Anastas B.

description: Incredibly rude customer service.  I was there close to closing time where they yelled at several people who tried to come in 30-60 minutes before closing.  Food was okay.
author: Anjali B.

description:
So we came here after having a terrible dimsum experience at Golden Eastern dimsum around the corner and it was seriously the highlight to our dimsum experience at Golden Eastern because otherwise I would have gone home cranky and hungry.

The restaurant is extraordinarily clean with cozy lighting and an ambiance that I thoroughly appreciated better than Goldern Eastern. Ordered a few dishes and they were all so yummy that I think I could do this vegetarian thing if I got to eat here every day.

With all the chinese restaurants in the area, this place is extraordinarily delicious, will be coming again
author: Zoe H.

description:
I'm not a true vegetarian, but I enjoy my fair share of veggie meals. This place was bomb in terms of variety and flavor. My favorites were the eggplant/string beans and lettuce wraps. Plus points for offering a brown rice option. Unfortunately, this place is in the middle of Chinatown (near R&G) so no parking, and they do not validate for parking in any of the lots.

Knocked off one star for being too heavy-handed with the oil and salt. The oil is understandable (most Chinese restaurants use way too much), but the salt..? We requested light salt on all of our dishes and they were still quite salty (but within acceptable range). I can't imagine how salty the food is at a "normal" salt, but to each their own.
author: Melinda W.

description:
We came to the one in chinatown! 

This is my new favorite place in San Francisco to eat - this is the best tasting vegetarian food Ive tasted in a while! We had the chicken nuggets & dumblings to a start - yummy! And then #65, 67 and 91; the 'chicken' and 'lamb' taste a lot like how i remember the taste of the real meat. AMD all Of it really has great spicey and flavor! Rice w spinach & pine nuts is SO good - what a great combination. I will come back for the food, i will order delivery from here - but i dont understand why they close at 9pm on saturdays... Note - you should come for the food, its not really a special cozy/charming place in my opinion.
author: Marie V.

description:
This is a good place to go with several people so you can eat family style and sample several dishes. The individual dishes are too pricey to order several things for one person. I would go for lunch for their special which is about $10 for rice, entree and spring roll. 

I got the mapo tofu which was advertised as spicy but wasn't really, and honestly not that good. Next time I want to try the pine nut rice! 

Service was great.
author: Hannah K.

description:
Good place for vegetarians, but not my favorite. 

Some of the the things we tried here are:

1. Salt & Pepper Fried Pumpkin - was too oily and literally guzzling oil. Could not really eat more than a piece of this. 
2. Veggie Sticky Rice Dumplings - this was delicious wrapped in a leaf and filled us big time! If you order this little thing, be ready to get filled!
3. Eggplant & String Beans w/Black Bean Sauce - was moderately tasty but again too oily!
4. Salty Fish, Chicken & Soft Tofu - this was simply lot of tofu in a tasteless watery sauce. Highly avoidable
author: Rocking V.

description:
When Jamie W. and I decided to dive into a plant-based diet head first, we thought we should try the vegetarian restaurant CNNGo named as one of the Top 50 Chinese restaurants in the country. Oh yes, Top 50! Really... Really? This place is better than Eric's or San Tung or even Henry's Hunan? Really? I don't think so. Truth be told, we came on a whim on our way to Hunan Homes thinking maybe an all-veg meal wouldn't be so bad. After all, we had some good luck with a couple of Thai vegetarian places in the city, and advance word was so good despite the lackluster Yelp reviews. Well, I should have listened to my Yelp brethren (and sistren, too) on this one.

For starters, we tried the $5.99 Fried Curry Potato Triangles, which were truly just latkes mixed into samosas (see photo). They were all right, just quite bland for the excessive calories we were accumulating from the deep-fried treatment. The $8.50 Kung Pao Tofu was way too saturated with the all-too-familiar mystery brown sauce for us to appreciate the spiciness of the dish (see photo). We also would have preferred our tofu sauteed rather than fried, but there was an abundance of stir-fried vegetables to complement the tofu cubes. The most intriguing dish we had was the $8.50 plate of Sliced Fatty "Pork" with Sweet Mustard Greens and Napa Cabbage (see photo). You have to understand that I was a heavy-duty pork belly junkie before I turned my back on meat.

I think I was in rehab with a couple of butchers and a bulimic, so any semblance to pork was something I needed to try. The mock-pork so obviously came out of the can because it had that gelatinous sheen to the faux-meat, and the fat was, I believe, pure gelatin shaped to look like gristle off a pig. It kinda worked but maybe more because I hadn't had real pork for three months at that point. Mixed with the cabbage and the greens, I could almost feel I was satisfying a carnivorous craving. Almost but not quite. The place was quite crowded, so obviously it has a following. Service was on the perfunctory side - and of course, everyone was skinny. But I think I'll go back to my steamed chicken at Hunan Homes. It may be too "meaty" for my diet, but it's probably better than digesting canned fake-meat.

FOOD - 3 stars...not as good as CNNGo would have you believe
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...speed is an addiction for the staff here...I mean the pace, not the drug
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...standard Chinatown decor and rather noisy with pay toilets available for non-customers
TOTAL - 3 stars...Enjoy was not all that enjoyable
author: Ed U.

description: Very nice different food.  The nice thing is it is not drenched in calorific sauces! My girlfriend loved it too. I was surprised at the vegan "fatty pork" - it had a very surprisingly meaty texture based on my memories since I've been Vegan for a number of years.  Will definitely come back as it's close by.  The portions are very large too.
author: Craig M.

description:
I DUNNO

In SFO for the Nike Women's Half Marathon (my wife is running...not me...hold the jokes please. 

With all the rave reviews I expected this place to be busy.  When we arrived at 1115 Saturday morning it was empty. Ruh roh...

Ordered based on what others said was good.  And honestly, everything was ok.

The dish that stood out was the steamed dumplings...they were really good.  Everything else was ok...not bad...not great.

What wasn't good was our server.  She speaks very little English, and after we ordered drinks and food, a Chinese lady comes in with 3 kids, orders, and her drinks come out first.

Not cool.

So I get our server's attention and point that out. Nods of the head and apologies ensue. Drinks come right out. Amazing how that works. 

The prices seemed to be higher than what others had said in their photo descriptions. Maybe it was weekday vs weekend?  I dunno. 

Now...I would like to believe that we as a society have evolved beyond racism.  And I'm not saying this was.  But when you consider the facts as I experienced them, let's just say I wont return...except maybe for an order of those dumplings....to go.
author: Randy S.

description: I'm so glad I found this place! I'm a vegetarian, so it's nice that I can eat everything on the menu. I had the eggplant tofu basil with satay sauce, pinenut and spinach fried rice, and the hot and sour soup. The first two were amazing and super fresh and flavorful, but next time I'll skip the soup. I want to try their fake meat next.  This place is awesome!
author: Madeleine M.

description: Had the Singapore noodles, steamed dumplings and kung pao tofu.  All were quite good.  Nothing was greasy.  Every thing tasted fresh.  Veggies were cooked perfectly, not over done.  Portions were good, as was the service.  I'm looking forward to coming back!
author: Jim L.

description: Meh, was much better the first time we came here a few months back. The spartan crowd on a Sunday evening should have been our first warning. There are better choices in Chinatown no doubt.
author: Marc M.

description: Found this place near my hotel in Chinatown and stopped in for lunch.  The service was a bit slow in taking my order but the food was pretty tasty.  I started with fried tofu cubes that were salty and with black pepper; this might have been my favorite dish.  I also tried cilantro bean curd (served in sheets) and a vegetarian won ton soup.  Both were decent if unspectacular.  I then has spicy ma po tofu - not the best I've had, but still quite delicious.  The menu is full and varied, and there is a $10 lunch special.  I will make it a point to visit on return trips to SF.
author: Tom M.

description:
I tried Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant for lunch Sun 3/11/12 since CCNGo named it one of the top 50 Chinese restaurants in the US.  I thought it was ok.

They have a good lunch deal M-F 11-2:30p which includes soup of the day, main dish, brown or steamed rice, & spring roll for $7.50!

No Msg, garlic or onions in any dishes, Buddhist don't eat those things.

Since it was Sun I couldn't get that deal.  FREE hot tea brought to the table.

I got Eggplant Tofu Basil $8.50 - It's a plate of eggplant, fried tofu squares, & a few basil in a brown sauce.  I liked it ok.

Brown rice $1.25 for a small bowl - have to order that separate, doesn't come with the entree.

Bathrooms: Separate Woman/Man, singles.  There's a sign for Non-Customers it's $2 per person to use the bathroom!

Charge cards accepted: Master Card, Visa, Discover

FREE books like "The Life of The Buddha"; "What the Buddha Taught" available near the window other dining section.

Hrs:
Daily 11-2:30p; 5-9p
author: Ann L.

description: Delicious tasting food!! The tofu veggie soup was pretty tasty, the spinach and pine nut rice was soooo good, and the noodles were just as tasty.  The veggie sticky rice dumplings were nasty and the service was not up to par.  But hey overall it was worth it.  100% vegan Chinese food.
author: Tiffanie T.

description:
'Meh. I've experienced better.' pertains strictly to their deteriorating service.  During my latest and anticipated last visit, I'd had enough.

I brought my friend and her 4 month old. If you know anything about motherhood, one fact is the strain it renders on the human body.  This said, I grabbed an extra chair for her to rest her foot on as she nursed and entertained her baby at the table. Baby was getting fussy. That evening, the restaurant was 1/4 to its capacity and the chair wasn't a safety hazard or upsetting fellow diners.  The tyrant hostess walked up, grabbed the chair without permission right in front of my friend as she held her child in her arms.  What a ghetto, insensitive b****!!!  

Above is just one example of the increasingly bad service provided by the hostess and waitresses.  Other times, I literally had to stand or walk-up to flag the waitresses down for additional tea or other services. One time, a waitress gave my guest and I the check midway through our meal.  What about asking 'Would you like anything else?' or 'Would you like the check?'.  Is that too much to expect when dining-in?!?! Also, when dining-in anywhere besides a fast-food joint, what type of waitstaff idles behind the counters or around the kitchen areas, muttering amongst themselves??  Also, how about greeting guests when they come in and seating them instead of smirking 'Sit anywhere.' and tossing the menus at patrons??

I've been dining at this restaurant/chain for years. Can they treat their regulars who bring guests with a little more respect and dignity?? The service keeps getting scarcer and worse.  At their other location (the Sunset) the staff are much more polite.  What's with this inconsistency with such a small chain??
author: Honest J.

description: Super yummy fresh awesome!! Perfect spice, not too greasy. Attentive service. I left feeling satisfied yet energized. Highly recommended from a seasoned vegan.
author: Harlow H.

description:
Nasty tasteless food. 
Food is frozen or out of a can.
Was here once before. Thought I wouw try it again. To no avail. Took one bite of "Thai style" soup. Gross. Waitress did not even ask what was wrong. 
Really?
If I could give zero stars I would.
Tried pumkin curry. Gross. Taste like the cubes of brown curry you get out of box.
Never ever again.
author: Shelby H.

description: Lucked out when our party of nine stumbled upon Enjoy Vegetarian for Christmas dinner. We were able to be seated quickly, split five appetizers and five entrees between us and we all left satisfied, including some picky young diners.  Some of the favorites were the dumplings, lemon chicken, the sweet and sour pork, spring rolls, Mongolian beef, and my personal favorite of the fried wantons.  Would definitely recommend, even meat eaters, as we all forgot we were eating vegetarian!
author: Erin R.

description: Love the spinach and pine nut fried rice but customer service sucks!! The receptionist and waiter were rude. Almost like a "why are you here" type rudeness. It made me feel uncomfortable but I decided to stay and order. So many good reviews I thought it was just a bad day. So, I recommended to a friend and we returned and ordered the spinach and pine nut fried rice and split some fragrant crispy 'chicken'. Well the food was great but the customer service was absolutely worse the second time around. It made me want to ask the waitress if someone had urinated in her coffee, perhaps every morning!!! Because her attitude reeked garbage during both visits. It's two strikes and you're out with me. Why return a third time to see if I'm treated more worse? I'll make my own spinach and pine nut fried rice for that matter.
author: Makeda A.

description:
We loved it!  It was a delightful surprise for me to learn: 
1.  They are 99% vegan--only one dish had mayonnaise, which contains egg.  
2.  They don't use any garlic onion, shallots, leek, chives. Yay!--I really dislike the smell of that family and especially don't  like it on the breath.
The waiter (in the Sunset Branch) was the nicest man..explained things patiently.

Looking at the less positive reviews here, esp the woman who found the food insipid. Maybe it's the lack of garlic? 

Thanks for reading my review.  Cliche though it is, it is *so* refreshing to have expectations so exceeded.
author: Francois T.

description:
Our favorite Chinese veggie place for years.  Wonderfully quiet!   Such a relief to find a restaurant where you can meet friends and talk.  Thank goodness there is NO TV -- 
Staff is friendly and courteous.  Food uniformly good.  Especially like the steamed dumplings, veggie hors d'oeuvres, green beans and beef -- well, lots of dishes.
author: K H.

description: Always im very satisfied when I have my time at the place my favorite salads is hookipa and resolution bowl
author: Lucas D.

description:
Enjoy Vegetarian continues to be 1 of my fav lunch spots.  I've been able to venture out & try a few different dishes - even though it's so hard b/c when I think I've found a go-to item, the new item ends up on my list as well..... they've all been winners

For example, my latest craving is for their String Beans w/ Soy Beef in a basil sauce.  The beans are consistently cooked perfectly so they still have a bit of crunch & the sauce is super-flavorful w/out overwhelming the beans.  The beef is completely reminiscent of its "real" beef counterpart but w/ none of the guilt!

I've also been experimenting around w/ their String Beans w/ Dry Shredded Tofu and their Walnut "Prawns" & again, both winners.  I like the dry tofu - it's cut into strips & are the same size as the string beans so it's easy to skewer a forkfull for the perfect bite

The "prawns" have a smoothness & creaminess from the mayo-like dressing & when paired w/ their delish nutty brown rice, makes for 1 satisfying lunch indeed

No meal has been a disappointment & the more I venture out to try new things at Enjoy, the more dishes are added to my go-to rotation & my biggest problem is deciding what to choose....and that's not a bad problem to have at all!!!
author: Adrienne G.

description: Great selection of faux-meat and tofu dishes. So perfect if you're vegan! The food is well prepared and for only $10 you get a spring roll, a choice of a main dish, rice and tea for lunch. It's busy, but the staff do there best to help everyone and nothing else but busy should be expected in the FIDI. If you're vegan/vegetarian I would really recommend this place.
author: Julia L.

description:
Awesome vegetarian chinese restaurant.  They have most of the standard chinese dishes to be found in an authentic Cantonese restaurant in America, but with tofu, gluten, or yam based substitutions for meat.  To give you an idea of their menu coverage, they have imitation shark fin soup.


I've had two dishes from them so far, and their imitation meat, cha siu and ham, were pretty spot on.  I normally dislike American based meat substitutes that use really scary sounding artificial processed ingredients.  Chinese style vegetarian substitutes start with something simpler like tofu and let the seasoning do the work.

Dishes are generally less greasy than normal.  Menu says no msg onion or garlic.  They offer brown rice.  They have vegan ice cream.  All pluses.

I've found the first authentic Chinese restaurant I actually like since becoming vegan!
author: Matt T.

description:
Clean restaurant with good service and a large $7.99 and $8.99 lunch menu.  All lunch dishes come with an Egg Roll, Entree, and choice of White or Brown rice.

My favorite dish is the Braised Lamb with Dried Bean Curd strips in a fermented Shang-Hai red bean curd sauce.  So tasty......The Braised Lamb (Faux Meat) had a nice chewy texture that will satisfy the carnivore in you!
author: Scott L.

description: Sooooo fresh! My pumpkin, taro and tofu in coconut sauce felt like farm to table. Exactly what I was looking for in this culture rich city! The pot stickers were super flavorful too. Don't forget to get dipping sauce though! I forgot to ask, and they forgot to put any in. Didn't change my mind about how tasty it was!
author: Kristin N.

description:
I love vegetarian restaurants that serve faux meat! Enjoy Vegetarian was not a disappointment. 

My favorite dish was the mongolian beef - the beef texture was perfectly chewy and they don't skimp on the "meat" which made the whole dish extremely delicious till the last bite! 

Other pros:
+no waiting time on a friday evening
+delicious miso soup- def recommend it 
+well priced! 

I will be back!
author: Anu P.

description: Casual Chinese vegan dining in the heart of Chinatown!  I've been here 3x, and have enjoyed different dishes from their $7.99/$8.99 (depending on choice of main dish) set lunch offerings. For the set lunch, the main dish comes with spring roll and brown or steamed rice, along with hot tea. There are also a la carte options. The miniature fried sticky rice balls filled with sweet red bean paste make me homesick for Beijing. I don't usually like fake meat and have been pleasantly surprised by the flavor and texture - it's good, but I haven't eaten 'real' meat in decades so I can't speak to how well it recreates that experience. The rooms are clean and simple, with relaxing music playing quietly.  The only drawback I've found is that service can sometimes be brusque, depending on which of the servers comes to your table.
author: A N.

description:
It feels more cafeteriaey than its Kirkham Street counterpart, but its Kirkham Street counterpart also feels more like it's in Chinatown, even though this Enjoy feels right at home in Chinatown.  Maybe it's the fact that all the windows are on the east side?  I don't know what that's all about.

The service wasn't up to par with all my experiences on Kirkham Street.  It wasn't bad, and it was an off hour, but I do expect to be checked on more than twice in an almost completely empty restaurant with only one other party dining and three employees working.

I think the menu is bigger at this one, but I can't be sure.  Maybe they just had a separate specials page?  The food was what I've come to know and love from Enjoy.  

It might actually rate three stars, but where else in Chinatown are you going to get vegetarian food that you know is actually vegetarian?

I'm waiting for your answer.

. . .

Still waiting.

. . .

I didn't think so.
author: John S.

description: The chow mein is good, wish there was more noodles than vegetables though. The broccoli in the broccoli beef was very good. The sweet and sour chicken was the best meat there. Second time coming here and I'm still a fan. Don't remember what I had the first time, but must've been good because I came back!
author: Emily X.

description: The food is delicious and reasonably priced!! We got the veggie soup and Kung pao tofu. You get free hot tea when you first sit down. The waitress was nice. This is a good Vegan, Vegetarian and non restaurant.
author: Margaret P.

description:
My Fav without sugar n oil :)
I sometimes order it on postmates sometimes pick up myself.
there r not really anyplace else as I know can find Thai food in san francisco. This is more likely a Asian (Chinese) style of vegan food that with so many kinds of soy made food (full of proteins and iron) However. Love it!
author: D C.

description: Great veggie food.  I wish they didn't close down during the day-- check the hours before you go.  They have quality soups, noodle dishes, fake meat, and appetizers.  My favorite dish was the vegetarian duck appetizer.  I have no idea what duck tastes like but this was a savory tofu-mushroom dish.  Recommended!
author: Clementina S.

description:
One of my favourite vegetarian restaurants anywhere...and I travel far too much. 

I have probably been 5 times up to date...and fully enjoy it every single time. With so many choices it is hard to not find something that pleases you. Especially if you like the chewy kind of food. Often when visiting fully vegetarian restaurants (which I avoid) you still get wet lentil pate or soups (at least in Northern Europe). That was the kind of vegetarian that was served 35 years ago...before much knowledge of this field. This place though make every kind of 'meat' you can think of. Mongolian beef, curry, chicken, duck and on goes the list. I have only had this extensive selection of vegetarian meats in any other city than Beijing. 

The restaurant itself is very basic, simple but clean. So if not looking too much on the design and focusing on the eating experience I select 5 stars. I enjoy often being able to dine in the company of orange robed Buddhist monks as well. 

The sesame balls are delicious too so don't stuff yourself too full on the main course. 

Can't wait to visit San Francisco again soon so I can go back to the Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant :) Yumm!
author: Kazemaru Y.

description: One of my favorite restaurants! Everything I have tried here has been delicious. The veggie spare ribs are amazing. Also, the medicinal mushroom soup is so good on a cold and foggy day. Love Enjoy!
author: Mylie T.

description:
Let me first establish being quite the tyrannosaur; practicing vegan behavior is not naturally in my nature. My attendance was honoring my date's annual Buddhist vegan recognition. However, I was surprised how convincing their faux meat items tasted in comparison to the real things.

We ordered Braised Spareribs with Daikon & Vegetables, Twice Cooked Pork with Dried Tofu & Veggie Pork, and the Golden Bucket which included chicken. All meat imitations were apparently reconstructed with wheat gluten, though I have no idea how the fine-tuning in their kitchen replication processes goes. Still distinguishable, but comes pretty close.

Also had a good lychee boba drink.

While I would not eat here regularly, I will admit that if you desire or require a meat-lacking diet, this place might just fit your fancy.
author: Garett T.

description: Love this place! Their lunch specials are my go-to. $10 for a huge lunch that lasts me two meals in the Fidi district is great! It comes with an egg roll and brown rice and a huge dish of your choice. Their food is also msg free and always fresh and delicious! Can't beat their price and food.
author: Priscilla L.

description: We have been vegetarians for well over 40 years and eaten at many vegetarian restaurants all over the country. This place is not gourmet, but it is excellent value for your money. We were waited on immediately and brought tea which is included in the $9.99 lunch special. There are lots of vegetable options and we were not disappointed in any of our selections. It was great to have good nutritious Chinese food in Chinatown.
author: Thea W.

description:
This is a great place to dine alone if that's what you like to do - that's what I did.  And I noticed many people coming in to dine on their own as well.

I had a strange experience in terms of service, but I have a feeling it was a fluke and could be attributed to a communication barrier.  So I'm not going to dock them a ton for that.

I ordered the mongolian beef with broccoli and enjoyed it although I didn't think it was spicy at all (it was  noted as being spicy).  The food also came out within 5 minutes of me ordering it, I was shocked.  At the end of my meal, I really felt my food was average and that Golden Era is still #1 in my book when it comes to vegan Chinese.  I'd eat here again though.
author: Christina M.

description:
A couple months ago, I was eating vegetarian.  Over one weekend, I watched way too many PETA videos and I started feeling guilty about eating meat.  During the two months that I was vegetarian, I frequented Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant.  As a person who has had her fair share of meat, and reveled in her carnivorous ways, I was really impressed that this restaurant was able to fool my tastebuds. My favorites are: Lemon Sauce Fried "Chicken", Sweet and Sour "Chicken", House Special Fried Rice, Eggplant in Spicy Chili Sauce.  You can't go wrong with those dishes.  I know they labeled the eggplant dish as "spicy" but it was not spicy at all.  The eggplant is so creamy and this is absolutely my favorite out of all the dishes I mentioned.

I wasn't too big of a fan of the braised spareribs with daikon. The faux meat was a bit chewy for me and there was a type of spice that I can't pinpoint that I didn't like too much.  It kind of tastes like cinnamon, but it's quite not the same.  I just felt the spice they used made the sauce taste funny.  The Singapore style rice noodles tasted great but it was kind of dry.  

Sadly, I am not a vegetarian anymore.  My body didn't like being deprived of meat (my hair started shedding more and I would rather eat a chicken than walk around San Francisco looking like Homer Simpson). I would definitely come back here, especially on days when I'm avoiding meat.  Moderation is the key!
author: Shirleyanne A.

description: It was my first time here and I thoroughly enjoyed it. My friend and I started with appetizers: fried spring rolls, fried taro cake and fragrant crispy chicken. I recently switched to a vegetarian diet and it's nice to see and discover the options one has. Fried taro has always been a favorite for me when out for dim sum and it was great to find a place that serves it just as tasty but without the traditional pork filling. The fragrant crispy chicken was just as delicious, they were bite sized nuggets that tasted just like fried chicken. Their lunch plates are reasonable, at $9.99 which includes a spring roll and there is quite a selection of dishes to choose from. I had the black bean sauce with string beans and veggie chicken, delish! I will definitely go back, I brought a menu home so I could plan ahead for my next meal there. Good food, friendly wait staff and clean dining areas. All big pluses in my book.
author: Kim L.

description:
I used to work at the 5000 block of Geary, a.k.a. the hidden hidden culinary mecca of the Richmond district, where everything is magically authentic and tasty in the most unexpected way. 

I used to walk past the Geary location (at 5344 Geary Blvd.) during my "lunch break" during which Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant would always be closed. Passing by this vegetarian restaurant brought back memories of temple food, and that one time in college when I became a vegetarian for a year at UCSC because of my hippy vegan ex-girlfriend, so I vowed to give the restaurant a try if an opportunity were ever to arise. So when I discovered that there was yet another location downtown which remained open during my lunch breaks at my other gig at Union Square, it was like music to my ears.

So moving past my usual methodical formula of a  personal anecdote followed by an actual semi-informative review, I tried the Soy Basil Chicken and the Sweet and Sour Pork and could not believe either was not meat. Or soy. Or butter, for that matter.

Every lunch entrée you order comes with your choice of white rice or delicious brown rice; service here is prompt and efficient -- the food usually comes out within six to seven minutes of ordering; I usually spend twenty minutes walking here from my workplace at Union Square, about ten minutes eating, and then twenty minutes back to work, leaving me just enough time to put a smile back on my face for work.

Back to the food itself. The Soy Basil Chicken actually takes like any kind of regular basil chicken that you find at a Thai restaurant. It does come with a healthy serving of broccoli and carrots, which I didn't care too much for. The actual "chicken," along with the basil and choy are cooked in a delicious yet light soy sauce, so not to overpower the actual taste of the vegetables themselves.

There was nothing special about the Sweet and Sour Chicken, except that IT'S NOT CHICKEN! Until I tried the Sweet and Sour Chicken here, my expectations of vegetarian cuisine in America was either Tofurkey or Seitan; Enjoy takes what should be painfully bland and mediocre into something that's deliciously mediocre, kind of like watching the paralympics on TV.

For those of you concerned solely on taste and not about how many animals died to provide your delicious meal, Enjoy is closer to a three-star than a four-star--The food here tastes like any other Chinese restaurant two blocks away in Chinatown. But given the fact that they were able to take something that is shunned and shuddered upon at the very mention of its existence, and turn it into something close to a dish of candy coated excrement, they deserve the extra star.
author: Scott S.

description:
I decided to try this location over the weekend based on Yelp friend Adrienne G's recommendation.  I had eaten at the Kirkham Street location and liked the foods I tried, but I had no idea the Kearny Street location served the exact same menu.  This location is much more modern than the Kirkham Street address.

This was a rather early 5:30 PM dinner for me so I didn't order as much food as I might normally do since I had eaten lunch just a few hours prior to visiting here.  I started with the Fried Spring Rolls which was also recommended by Adrienne.  I only ordered one main entrée selecting the Bean Curd Rolls w/ vegetable and a bowl of steamed brown rice.  In addition to the complimentary hot tea I ordered an iced peach green tea.

Unlike the Kirkham Street location a meal here begins with a complimentary dish of pickled greens.  I thought the greens had a nice crunch and a good, tart pickle flavor but these were a bit tough to chew.  The iced peach green tea I ordered had very good peach flavor but it also seemed overly sweetened.  I would have preferred more green tea flavor instead of the syrup flavor I tasted.

The kitchen works quite quickly and soon I was brought the Fried Spring Rolls (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/XKj8_4QdoBMeYcg6OoespA?select=xWk0I0S9KWMB06wKUEDYxg).  Fried up golden brown the crispy, thin wrapper was stuffed with a hot (in temperature) cabbage, carrot and bean thread filling that almost seemed creamy.  These were very good spring rolls with or without the sweet and sour dipping sauce which accompanied it.

The Bean Curd Rolls (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/XKj8_4QdoBMeYcg6OoespA?select=vVS_mxjcKdhopgpADsaInQ) looked fabulous.  These were served over steamed spears of perfectly cooked Shanghai bok choy in a tasty sauce accented by strands of Chinese black moss.  The Bean Curd Rolls are chewy soybean sheet layers stuffed with napa cabbage, mushrooms, strips of sweet soybean sheet, carrots and other fungi.  The taste was excellent and paired quite well with the nuttiness of the brown rice.  So good, in fact, that I ate everything that was brought to me.

A complimentary dessert of fresh orange wedges and sweet, dark burgundy bing cherries arrived with the check.  Much like their other location the service here was very friendly and efficient.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: I love this place!!!  Seriously delicious vegetarian food with something for everyone.  Try the fragrant crispy chicken if you're skeptical about vegetarian food for a delightful surprise of delicious flavor and texture!
author: Megen M.

description: Came with friends at 8:40 pm, 20 minutes before closing. They let us in but were extremely unfriendly and rude, every several minutes reminded us to leave. Terrible experience. Did not leave the tip on credit card, they started demanding the tip in a very rude manner. I don't think such places should exist vegetarian or not.
author: Dennis Z.

description:
I am usually pretty skeptical of vegetarian restaurants (probably unfairly so), especially ones that offer fake meat dishes. After my experience at Enjoy however, I think I need to change my mind...

Food here was great, we had: nian gao which had fake pork in it that really tasted like pork (more like ham than the normal pork you get with nian gao but still, for fake meat I was impressed!), Mapo doufu - I guess Enjoy follows a particular Buddhist tradition that stays away from stronger flavors so this was more sweet than spicy but actually really tasty (just don't expect your normal mapo doufu), a basil pineapple broccoli dish that was more Thai than Chinese but really good, Eggplant/green bean with blackbean sauce - different than I'm used to since it didn't have any garlic but surprisingly good, and the "chicken" drumsticks which again for a total fake meat dish were really tasty!

The only negative from our experience was when they took our tea away and didn't bring it back until we finally asked them for it, I mean seriously, what the heck? :P

Overall a great place, I'm excited to try the Enjoy in inner sunset as well and will definitely be back here in the future.
author: Ely L.

description:
Actually, I got terrible at being my own chef since I've lived in San Francisco. There's just so much to try out. But I also have an obligation to all my friends that opt on visiting SF, they need to be able to get food at the best places and not be disappointed.

So, I read the reviews for Enjoy before I went to try it out myself. 
I got the Fried Spring Rolls and the Veggie Chicken Chow Mein in Black Pepper Sauce to go. 
The service was very friendly and patient, since I did not know yet what to order. The waitress offered me tea or water to drink while I was waiting, which was very nice.
Once I got my food, I quickly went home because what was on the plates of the other restaurant guests looked very good.
Well, i was a little bit disappointed by the first bites (and the following ones). Even though, it said on the menu that the dish would be spicy, I did not feel anything of it. Now I know that spice is relative but for my taste it was not spicy at all. (there you go sriracha sauce). 
All in all it was a decent noodle meal with crisp vegetables but the vegetarian "meat" had a strange aftertaste that did not quite pleased my tastebuds.

The spring rolls were perfectly crispy but at the same time they did not taste like anything - I definitely had better ones.

All in all there is to say that I was a little disappointed by what I got because I did expect more. Nevertheless, I would definitely give them another try since nothing was bad but just mainly lacking in spice and flavor. Large portions though and nice that there is an entirely vegetarian restaurant within walking distance of my place!
author: Vera H.

description:
The Beef & Tomato Noodles are not bad. I've never really had anything like it before. It's kind of like spaghetti ish, but pretty good. I'd get it again.

Vegetable Deluxe Vermicelli - not as good as the regular Vegetable Vermicelli. It was way too much for me. I actually didn't finish it like the other one.

What I do like: you can order To-Go on their online website. Nice and easy!
author: Jade F.

description: Was in chinatown for the afternoon with a large group and came here and it was really good. My friends werent vegetarian and they really enjoyed it. Everything was fresh and staff was friendly.
author: Erica B.

description:
Chicken nuggets:  What, this isn't chicken?!  Then again, I think anything fried ends up tasting the same. 

Beef and string beans:  The string beans were fresh and delicious.  The beef didn't really didn't have the same texture of beef, but overall, the string beans were crisp and the dish was good. 

Sweet and sour chicken:  My favorite dish of the night. Again... I couldn't believe I wasn't eating chicken. A sweet combination of "chicken," pineapple chunks, and bell peppers that is delicious over a bowl of rice.

Basil friend rice: Speaking of rice, the basil fried rice was delicious. You have to order it. Lightly fried rice with pine nuts and chopped basil. As opposed to typical Chinese restaurant's fried rice dishes that tend to be overly salty and heavy, Enjoy's basil fried rice is light and actually will make you feel good!

The interior is nicely done: very contemporary and clean. 

Overall, Enjoy puts a nice vegetarian spin on traditional Chinese-American fare. Vegetarians and carnivores looking to take a break from their meat-devouring ways alike will enjoy Enjoy!
author: Matt S.

description:
Yes that's right Enjoy! This food is absolutely delicious! 

However when I got home strangely I didn't want the left overs. I wrapped my chicken drumsticks in cellophane and my basil chicken was in it's little white box. The next night I still had no interest in eating it. I found this odd because I sure did enjoy it at the restaurant. A week later I had forgotten all about it and noticed the drumsticks hadn't gone bad. At this point I was intrigued and I decided to ride this out and see what happened.

No joke, a month later the drumsticks were the same. I hesitantly opened the box with the basil chicken in it, fully expecting to find some moldy mush since I was in a way conducting a science experiment at that point but guess what?

It looked the same. Even the bright beautiful green and red bell peppers were the same. Not a wrinkle, no shrinkage, nothing. It was like it was from yesterday.

So anyways, I won't claim to know what is preserving the food or even if it's food at all, I'm just doing the right thing and saying what happened. Don't take my word for it though, try it yourself. If you are still okay going there after you watch your leftovers NOT go bad. More power to you. Personally I only want good things in my body. I'd rather never taste chicken ever again than eat something that defies the laws of nature. I'll pass.
author: Mel B.

description:
I'm so glad this place doesn't buy into the model of Asian vegan by way of boring steamed vegetables and bland firm tofu chunks!  Enjoy Vegetarian does a delightful job of simulating, and sometimes surpassing, meat-based Chinese dishes.  I'm an omnivore that doesn't mind eating vegan dishes every now and then; I'm easy going and open minded like that.  I mean, it's not like I proclaim "I'm an omnivore!" at every restaurant I enter and then proceed to grill the server with 20 questions to verify what I am about to order is truly omnivore-friendly.

Fragrant Crispy Chicken: Way better than Popcorn Chicken!  Stochastic structured crispy exterior, way crispier than what you get at KFC.  Juicy and chewy interior.  A light sweet and sour sauce for dipping.  If you're gonna have mysteriously shaped deep fried protein chunks, better to have it be vegan than from pink chicken goo!

Veggie BBQ Pork: The only dish I didn't care for.  It looked like slices from those red pigs you see in Chinatown butcher shops, but the taste was not nearly as good.  There was no texture differential to simulate lean meat, fatty chunks and crispy skin.  Instead, it had the one texture of fish cake and the taste of bland seitan.

Taro, Seasame Veggie Chicken Cooked w/ Coconut Sauce: The coconut sauce was so rich and savory, they could have put anything underneath and made it taste good!  I really enjoyed the taro chunks since that tuber is often absent from menus despite being so yummy.  The chicken impostor tasted like heavily marinated dark meat but had the appearance and texture of thickly sliced deli chicken log.  But given how bold the coconut was, appearance/texture of the chicken wasn't so important.

Twice Cooked Pork: Looked, tasted and felt like thinly sliced pork used in Chinese stir fry.  If anything, it was better since it didn't have that not-so-fresh pork after taste found in many Chinese restaurant that use lower grade pig products (I prefer Kurobuta or Ibérico).  There was a bit too much cabbage in the dish for my tastes, but I made sure to uncover every last piece of fake pork!
author: Adam B.

description: The chicken nuggets were amazing! The spinach fried rice with pine nuts was delicious. The eggplant with green beans was ok, not super flavorful and greasy.  Looking forward to trying a few more dishes
author: Shayla S.

description:
Although I'm giving this place a 3 for now, I'm definitely going to go back at least one more time to give it another chance. Because it's possible I just got a bad dish, and I may have to do some searching for a better one - especially since I've been craving vegan asian food recently.

That being said, the dish I got (one of the beef dishes) ended up just not being very flavorful. The protein had a good texture and the sauce was decent, but the actual bites of fake meat didn't really wow me. Hopefully next time is better!
author: Amaresh S.

description: This is the worst place to eat food for vegetarians. We ordered veg chowmein which was so bad it literally gave us stomachache. There were no vegetables in it and oil they are using is not good. They fry stuff in oil and then use the same oil to make noodles which makes it pretty toxic and bitter. I have no idea why people are raving about this one. Even their tea is watered. Don't waste your money here.
author: Archi B.

description: I truly enjoyed my meal but the service of the waiters is the reason I would only give this restaurant 1 star. The service alone would keep me from visiting this place again. They act as if you are invisible, very unfriendly, may be better suited as a take out. Oh but you are truly visible when it comes to paying for the meal then they will get loud if you don't include a tip for such lousy unprofessional service. The absolute worse service!
author: T G.

description: The food was delicious, as always. =) A delight for vegetarians. We had the Kung Pau Chicken (best dish of the night), Twice Cooked Pork, Roasted Duck and were given complimentary Sesame Balls. We also got prompt and polite service.
author: Jayanthi P.

description:
This was a friggin' delicious meal, and I'm saying that even as a born-and-raised omnivore who likes at least some poultry or fish at every meal.  We got a bunch of dishes, but the eggplant with "sea bass" was my favourite.  Spinach and pine nut fried rice was tasty too.


---- PROTEIN DISHES ----

Soy Chicken, Taro, Pumpkin: 4.5 stars 
Tasty fried gluten puffs, naturally sweet like a Thai coconut milk dessert. Yum!

Golden Knots: 3.5 stars
Beancurd wrappers stuffed with cabbage and mushroom, on a bed of bok choy. Not particularly flavourful (esp compared to the taro pumpkin), good for a 清淡 light bland meal.


---- VEGGIE ----

Eggplant Tofu Basil: 4 stars


---- STARCH DISHES ----

Curry Fried Rice 咖喱炒饭: 4 stars
With soy chicken.

Fried Rice Cakes 酒菜年糕: 3 stars
Pretty bland and the rice cakes were not as soft and gooey as I like. Served the purpose of rice (or fried rice, to be charitable) in my meal.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Excellent Vegan options, 3 choices of protein (mock meats) and one of them is yam!
Brown rice on the menu gets them another star.

Sweet servers and quick service. I highly recommend.
author: Jimmy F.

description:
Wonderful place. It's packed in here (which is always a good sign). The combination platter of "BBQ", sweet and sour tofu, and a bunch of other vegetarian food was delicious! 

The staff was very friendly. The atmosphere is happy and lively. And the food is exquisite. Leaving full and quite happy.
author: Kristina L.

description:
I had serious thoughts regarding this place at first. After all, most of us like to have at least a little bit of meat in our food. Moreover, fake meats usually do not taste very good; they are bland and taste like cardboard. 

NOT THE FOOD HERE!

The place was packed on a weekday, and justifiably so! The food was EXCELLENT! There is a lot of flavor, but at the same time, they do not use garlic, onions, or MSG. It is not salty or greasy. In fact, it is very healthy. 

I had a rice vermicelli, a vegetable & tofu stir fry, and stir fried rice cake (nian gao). None of the dishes disappointed. All were very delicious, but not extremely filling. 

The only downside is that the restaurant is located in Chinatown, which means parking will be a pain. Supposedly, there are other restaurants located in Sunset and Richmond. I look forward to trying the food at those locations very soon.
author: Willk W.

description: WOAH! I happened to be in Chinatown this morning and stopped by here for one of the $9.99 lunch special. I got #41, which was delicious! And, an order of sesame balls - DELICIOUS. Please, please open one of these along Ocean Avenue.
author: Michelle S.

description: I've been here about 8 times now since I stumbled upon this place a few months ago. I'm definitely a fan. Well priced (especially for downtown,) meal comes with tea and a tiny appetizer fried roll and enough food for leftovers. I've had mostly soup and noodle dishes and everything has been excellent
author: tess e.

description:
I love eating meat, so one of my criteria when judging vegetarian food is how much is doesn't make me miss meat. I don't necessarily need the protein to fool me into thinking it's meat, but it should be hearty and savory enough to satisfy. But in both flavor and texture, I thought Enjoy fell way short.

Maybe 2 years ago, I wouldn't have been so harsh in my judgment of Enjoy, but with the rise of places like VeggieGrill and other meatless options, the dry, unappetizing chunks served here are disappointing.

I ordered the Hot and Sour soup, which was bland and required large amounts of salt and pepper to make palatable. Also got the green beans and chicken, which was dry and flavorless. The faux chicken was dark and looked more like beef strips, but turned out to be dry and chewy like beef jerky.

I would say the gold standard in vegetarian chicken has to be the Stir-Fry Black Pepper Vegetarian Chicken. That thing is so good I've tricked my friends into thinking it was real.

PROS
- Clean place with decent service

CONS
- Vegetarian options fall way short of regular dishes
- Food is flavorless and requires lots of salt and/or pepper

TIP
- Do not take meat-eaters here - they will hate you.
author: Drew P.

description:
Unimpressive.
Vegetarian sharks fin soup is a lethargic disappointment and that's usually the standard bar of measurement for any good vegetarian restaurant.
Walnut shrimp is limp and soft. Lacks the tangy feel. 
Basil soy chicken is so bland that I have no words for it. It's like a painting that doesn't leave any trace in memory once you walk past it.
Braised lamb is slightly better - in my opinion- but overall still mediocre.
Let's just say I have definitely eaten much, much better vegetarian food elsewhere. This is definitely not the standard I expect from a restaurant with a four-star yelp review.

By the way, went to the Kearny one.
author: Rachel H.

description:
This is my first time here. Ordered my food, it was great. Came out on time and everything. Had the veggie beef stir fry with green beans, and crispy tofu (can't go wrong with tofu).
Only one issue that got me going though hurdles. They swipe my credit card twice. I am going to have to say it was probably an accident. From what I remembered, I only signed one receipt?
My bank had me call for the restaurant manager to see if I could dispute the problem with them.
So I called. Couldn't get the manager over 5 different times and eventually gave up. 
The employees that kept picking my calls didn't want to work with me. Maybe they were busy. I want to give them some understanding. My experience with the restaurant is low due to this issue.  I will try to come back the next time I visit.
author: Dk N.

description:
Everything here was delicious, but the sweet and sour chicken... I can't remember the last time I had it, the hickey was soy but it was the most delicious sweet and sour chicken I have ever tasted!

My boyfriend had to run out for work real quick and the food came while he was gone- they offered to re serve us when he returned because they were worried he food would be cold when he got back. SO sweet.
author: Azlynn T.

description: Had the twice cooked "pork" with brown rice. So delicious. You also get a pot of tea for free (at least I got one :-) ). Great place!
author: Jo L.

description: Got the lunch special - tofu with broccoli and walnuts. It was kind of gross, even more so after I had eaten it.
author: Nina J.

description:
