I'm sorry to report that my experience at Enjoy Vegetarian has significantly declined.  The food, more or less, is the same, though they have increased the prices.  The problems that I have experienced on more than one occasion are with the service.

The last time I went, they brought me out something different than what I ordered.  When I brought it to their attention, they argued with me about it.  I was taken aback.  The solution was very simple, but for some reason, it wasn't offered.  Eventually, they begrudgingly corrected the problem.  I couldn't believe how hard I had to advocate for a solution so simple.

A previous experience, at a different location, my table was given away while I was in the bathroom, and I was essentially pushed out the door when I returned.  Who does that?

My  patronage at Enjoy Vegetarian has met its useful life.  I won't be returning.  It's sad because over the years, I have been several dozen times, and I've been a strong supporter and promoter of their restaurant.  I'm always delighted to see vegetarian enterprises thrive, and I was happy when they expanded to this location in Chinatown as well as the newest output in the Richmond.  I have dined in all three of their locations.  Not anymore.  Although not exclusively vegetarian, I'll continue to patronize the vegetarian menus at Big Lantern and Wild Pepper in the Mission instead.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description: I like that this was a vegetarian option and they throw in a free spring roll for takeaway lunch orders. I ordered the wonton noodle soup. The wontons are SO delicious but the actual soup and noodles were not tasty and very bland. I ended up just eating the wontons and the noodles because I was so hungry. Willing to go back and try something else though.
author: Ruwanie B.

description:
Pretty good lunch deal.  They have a $7.99 section and a $8.99 section.  Lunch comes with a spring roll and either white or brown rice.

It's always a good sign when the restaurant is packed and busy when it's surrounded by so many other options.

Service is pretty quick and my food was good.  Not overcooked or drowning in too much sauce.  My choice today was the tofu with baby bok choy and mushrooms.  

I will definitely come back again!
author: Lisa K.

description:
Great find!

I'm not vegetarian but I eat very healthy most of the time. Today was my second time here and I ordered the braised "meat" with daikon and veggies. It was so delicious that I almost finished the whole dish on my own (very decent portion). The "meat" (satan) was prepares to perfection with great texture!  

I've also had the sticky rice triangle snack from here, it was also good and healthy as it's made with whole grains and legumes. 

Service was friendly and great! I'm only in the neighborhood one day a week and will probably make it a tradition to come in for lunch. Want to try the lotus veggies next.
author: Sway M.

description:
Originally my friends and I had planned to go to the Loving Hut in Chinatown, only to find out that it's being closed down. Vegan places aren't difficult to find in San Francisco, so this little change of plans ended up being a nice surprise visit to a new restaurant fave of mine.

We went on a Monday evening and it wasn't super crowded. The staff was very friendly and very attentive. Being the only vegan in our group, of course I had plenty of questions about the menu to which they happily answered very well. 

For appetizers we got fried won tons and pot stickers. I'm not a huge fan of celery, so the strong flavor of celery in the pot stickers was a bit off putting but they were yummy nonetheless. The won tons weren't nearly as fried and bubbly as their non-vegan counter parts in most restaurants, but they were very good.

My friends and I got the kung pao "chicken," clay pot soup, and twice cooked "pork." They were delicious. I'm not normally a fan of fake meat, but the chicken was delicious and the pork was surprisingly delightful. I'm not a fan of the clay pot soup because it's a little more bland than I'd like and the tofu was squishy and undesirable. 

For dessert though! Out of this world! We ordered the fried bananas with coconut ice cream and the donut balls. The bananas were phenomenal, whereas the donuts were much like chocolate filled mochi balls but with a weird peanut crusting. Not nearly as satisfying as the bananas and ice cream.

It's not the best Chinese food in the world, but I definitely enjoyed it. I also liked the vegan pamphlets they had available for people to take. I'd definitely come back and it's good to know there's a real vegan Chinese food place in Chinatown for future trips. :)
author: Britney S.

description:
I am a meat eater that loves vegetarian food. I'm so happy that this place exists! It's really great to have a restaurant around that makes so many vegetarian versions of classic Chinese and Asian dishes.

I got the fatty pork belly that was amazing! The texture was great. It was much better than I expected. I also got the wonton soup which was also great.

Service: 5
Presentation: 4
Decore: 3
Food:5
author: T S.

description: Really good vegetarian food and well priced. We got the lunch special for $9.99 and we got rice and springrolls with the food. Even without garlic and onions, this food was filled with flavour! Definitely suggesting this restaurant to friends!
author: Tha S.

description: Came here after a long day of shopping in Union Square because of all the rave reviews we've heard from people. The restaurant had a cozy ambiance which was relaxing, but I didn't really find the food that fulfilling. We ordered the braised spareribs, eggplant tofu & basil in black bean sauce, and the fried rice. I was also disappointed that they didn't serve the BBQ pork that looks amazing in the Yelp photos. Overall the food was okay, but it didn't have me craving for more. Everything just tasted...sweet? My favorite of the 3 was definitely the eggplant though. Not the greatest idea to come here after a long day of shopping and walking...dunno, I guess I just like my meat. Shrugs.
author: Carolyn T.

description: This is my go-to lunch spot in the area. Some weeks I eat here three times. The food is delicious, and the service is lightening fast. I love that you can order and pay for the food online and go pick it up. Super convenient. I love their egg rolls that come with all of the lunch plates. My favorite dish is the spicy eggplant with brown rice, followed by the eggplant and string beans in black bean sauce. The sauce is always good, not too heavy or in need of added salt.
author: Regina L.

description:
I'd recommend Enjoy Vegetarian to anyone looking for Asian food in San Francisco, even if you're not vegetarian. I've tried other vegetarian restaurants in Chinatown, but this one, so far, takes the medal.

The decor here is pleasant and kinda modern. The lighting is good. It's a narrow restaurant that I imagine could get cramped, but I was one of about 3 tables when I was there.

I got dumplings and chow mein. The dumplings were seared and very flavorful with a tasty dipping sauce. The chow mein made me think I could really do this vegan thing. It had "soy pork" in it that was completely indistinguishable from the pork I knew from my meat eating days. I double-checked that I was at the right place. This stuff was tasty.

I've tried a few other vegan/vegetarian restaurants in Chinatown, and since trying Enjoy I've regretted each one because it was not Enjoy.
author: Damon T.

description:
Happy Earth Day! 
To celebrate this special green day, I invited  my friend  to this restaurant to enjoy a healthy lunch. 
For $7.50 you get an entree' with rice, soup and an egg roll. It was so inexpensive that we also ordered some take out items for dinner later.  
I love coming here because it's cheap, delicious and environmentally friendly plus it makes it easier for travelers like me to stick to healthy eating.  
I think switching to plant based foods is probably one of the most positive lifestyle change an individual can make in terms of helping the environment.
I also believe that  eating green creates positive karmic relationships with mother earth and all sentient beings. 
When you do, that positive connection brings blessings, clarity and happiness. Isn't that lovely? :)
We ordered the Ma Po Tofu, Broccoli & Vegetarian Beef, Vegetarian Chicken with Lemon Sauce and also the Pai Pai Tofu with Broccoli. All were pretty delicious, tasty and guilt-free!
author: Michael F.

description:
If I had the choice to choose between this location or the "Original" one, I'd choose the "original" one located on Kirkham Street. The food here is good, but I think the "original" one is better and more flavorful. 

The decor at this location is definitely better than the location on Kirkham. Enjoy Vegetarian on Kearny Street is more spacious and has (I believe) three round tables that's in another room.  It's also clean inside.

I came here with my two managers who treated me to lunch. When we got there, I told the waitress I made reservations and she seated us right away. Not too long after, she brought a pot of tea and gave us a few minutes to decide on our order. 

They have a lunch special where you can choose from about 20 different selections and it comes with a bowl of soup, 1 egg roll, and a bowl of white or brown rice for only $7.50. I'd say that's a deal compared to eating in the FiDi where everything is at least $10. 

To start off, we ordered the samosa which comes in 5 pieces. M ordered their Braised String Beans w/ Spicy Chili Sauce, K ordered the Spicy Ma Po Tofu, and I ordered the Sweet & Sour Chicken. Yes, I said "chicken". Don't worry though, there are no meat products served at Enjoy Vegetarian as it's a Vegetarian/Vegan restaurant. The "chicken" is substituted with a soy product. 

Braised String Beans w/ Spicy Chili Sauce - good, but the chili sauce they used is the kind you would see at a dim sum restaurant. I wasn't a fan of it.

Spicy Ma Po Tofu - good, but wasn't a fan of the chili sauce they used.

Sweet & Sour Chicken - great

Overall, service was great. The waitress was attentive and friendly. I would come back for lunch if I'm craving for some vegetarian food when I'm at work.
author: Candice H.

description:
Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant is perfect for Meatless Mondays.*** 

As you may know, Meatless Mondays "is an international campaign that encourages people to not eat meat on Mondays to improve their health and the health of the planet." (Thanks Wikipedia!) More importantly, it is a good way to recover from my Fatty Fridays, Sugary Saturdays, and Split-my-Pants Sundays. 

EVR has a great lunchtime special. For $7.50 you get: a cup of soup, a veggie spring roll, brown or white rice, and your pick of 30+ vegetarian dishes. The dishes contain no garlic, no onion, no MSG, and no dairy yet still manage to taste good! 

The soup I tried and liked was similar to a Korean Miguk soup with seaweed, tofu, and miso. The veggie spring roll was crispy but not greasy and filled with carrots, cabbage, and mushrooms. My favorite dish so far is the simple but well prepared trio of Stir Fried Mixed Green Vegetables (yau choi, bok choy, broccoli) with a few carrots thrown in. The Preserve Mustard Greens, Soft Tofu, with Broccoli was also a solid choice. I was less enamored with the Kung Pao "Chicken." The spicy sauce had a nice amount of heat but was too salty. The "meat" had a unique texture that was paradoxically both chewy and mushy. I liked the peanuts, red and green bell peppers, and zucchini that were mixed in but I probably wouldn't order this again. Portion sizes are generous. 

Now I'm ready for Taco Tuesday! 

***http://www.meatlessmonday.com
author: Amy C.

description:
I think this place is highly rated as a good place FOR LUNCH.

1 star for dinner eventhough I support vegetarianism. It was completely empty on a weekday evening. All 3 employees were standing behind the counter STARING at us it was super awkward. They don't understand English at ALL and forget that Yelp discount.. they were speaking broken English to me once I mentioned the discount, who knows what they said but I just said "forget it" and they happily omitted the discount.

The tofu (fake kung pao chicken stuff) was UGLY! It didn't look or taste like "fake meat" and the texture was too chewy and it tasted horrible.  Also it was overly sweet. The tea was too sweet too.
author: Kathy S.

description: The food looked really nice but it didn't taste as well. The whole thing was supposed to be warm but parts or pieces were really cold.
author: Jonathan S.

description:
This place is what I expected of Vegan Chinese Cuisine in Chinatown.

Food:
+Steamed Dumplings- super bland and mushy; avoid
+ Crisped "Chicken" Nuggets- a better start to the evening; the dipping sauce was great
+Thai Iced tea with Lychee Boba- the thai iced tea was not sweetened at all but the popping boba with lychee flavor added the burst of fruity sugar flavor
+String Beans with Soy Beef- way too dry; but the beans were crispy and fresh and i loved that
+Kung Pao "Chicken"- the best thing we tasted; DEF order this! the broccoli was also wholesome and tasty
+Eggplant with "chicken"- we kind of concocted this dish because we wanted something as good as flavored as the kung pao chicken but with different veggies and chicken; the eggplant was soaked in oil and just didn't appease the group

Service:
My group of 4 was literally the one people in the restaurant for an hour at 6:45 on a THursday evening. Our waiter was really friendly though and knowledgeable about the menu- she memorized all the numbers and item names!

Ambience:
Very large and spacious restaurant in Chinatown. Seemed clean and quiet.

Came here on a double date with Niket B. and I'd only get one thing if  I came back!

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description:
It's a destination on the cusp of SF Chinatown and North Beach. I've been to the Kirkham iteration of this many, many times.  So now I head for this sister location for reliable food that I like and also a place to sit down ... tables seem to always be available.  The fact that it's not far from City Lights Bookstore is a big plus.  I like visiting both places in one journey.  Note that this restaurant's venue on Kirkham and 12th Avenue is small and crowded by comparison and requires a reservation.  This Kearney Street venue is spacious, and has always had empty tables when I've dined here.  The menus are the same ... both with my favorite resihi Chinese medicine soup. 

I've been here twice, the second time a couple of weeks ago.  The experiences both times were inspiring.  It's not likely that I'll make it through most of the menu in my lifetime which makes this an especially inspiring destination.  I've had no disappointments and many moments of great inspiration with a dish I would not have thought possible.  

Energy-wise, the Chinese medicine soup with Reishi (#24) has never failed to make me feel very energetic the following morning.  To me that's one of the signs of a really great meal.  I'm sensitive to the outcome the following day. 

From this menu: 
http://www.enjoyveggie.com/pdfs/dinnermenu_forweb_ed.pdf 
I find that the Lotus Root dish (#54) fulfills my veggie sensibilities of heaven.  The very next dish with Cordyceps mushrooms, yams and gingko nuts (#55) is powerful fortification for a rainy day.  

There are too many other items that I've tasted with great surprise ... fish dishes that taste remarkable as if cooked with a flavorful fish.  

This restaurant is in the tradition of temple food for Buddhist monks and nuns.  That is, it is truly vegan in every way.  Furthermore it is cooked without onions, garlic or MSG, as stated on the front of the menu.  This latter detail is in support the work of the temple and the mediation of the practitioners  One does not want food that "stirs the qi." ... so to speak.  

I'll be visiting here on a regular basis for all of the above details that I can rely upon plus a reasonable price.
author: Em S.

description: I ordered a lunch special #36 and asked them to make it spicy. And boy, it was spicy! The service was good, and my dish arrived fast. The portion was generous. I will definitely be back to check out other dishes for sure.
author: Anya S.

description: This is my favorite restaurant ever! Ive been here 3 times and I've  absolutely enjoyed all experiences (this is also my first time writing a review for something. Thats how much i love this place!) My favorite dish is the Kung Pao chicken, it's so delicous. Ive ordered it everytime ive gone. Other dishes ive tried are the chow mein with black pepper sauce, beef broccoli, mongolian beef, and a couple others i cant remember. I was shocked to read any negative reviews on this place but i guess everyone has different tastes. Anyway i believe anyone will enjoy the food, vegetarians and non vegetarians alike!
author: Ashley R.

description:
#64 soy sauce chicken is really good. It's full of fragment and flavor. 

Wonton soup was good too . The noodle itself has very good texture. Thats a good sign that their ingredient is of good quality . I was expecting more vegetables.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Huge portions, but because vegetarian does not necessarily imply healthy, it would be nice to see some dishes that go a little lighter on the sauce. What I tried was delicious, but I felt the abundance of sauce negated the health benefits of ditching real meat.

Also: wet veggies + plastic chopsticks = frustratingly slippery attempts to pick up my food. Wooden chopsticks would be a much better choice.
author: Barry E.

description: Good food, friendly service. Very good wonton soup, and loved the chow mein. Vegetables cooked perfectly, flavorful and crunchy. Fake meats were okay - I had the broccoli beef; broccoli was very good, "beef" was fine but nothing special. Drumsticks were very interesting (in a good way). Overall a good experience, would recommend if you like vegetarian chinese.
author: Landon B.

description: Lunch was surprisingly very good.  For those who are gravy fans, they have lots of gravy.  The sesame balls were a nice size and crunchy.  The eggplant was my favorite.  Brown rice was included with our lunch, which was really great to sop up that gravy.  The vegetarian fish really was tasty. The small combination appetizer was a little small but it hits the spot when you only want a taste.  I like their presentation.
author: Helen L.

description:
I go to Enjoy at least once a month. As soon as you walk in, you can see that the restaurant is clean and well taken care of, unlike some of the other restaurants in Chinatown. This is a great place to go to for Chinese vegetarian food. The dishes are fresh, tasty, and not too oily. 

One of my favorites is their eggplant and "sea bass" dish. The sea bass is made out of tofu, but somehow manages to taste like fish, in a good way. Their lunch specials come with a spring roll and you can request brown rice instead of white rice with no extra charge. I also like the string beans and tofu dish. 

The waitresses are very polite and the service is quite fast. I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone in the area.
author: Anne K.

description: I'm a fan because it's a vegetarian Chinese restaurant and being from Chicago, I don't get the flexibility I did here. I got the ma po tofu which was really good and my friends got the chowmein and a seitan beef dish. Food was good overall.
author: Shradha A.

description:
Delicious regardless of your current Veggie state! Definitely start with the lettuce wraps and then share the beef and string beans. Mmm mmmm good and wow the service is the best yet in San Francisco.

This meal will be fantastic on your palet and good for your body and even better on your wallet!
author: Marti H.

description:
I used to date a vegetarian, and making dinner for him was the hardest thing I've ever done.  What could I do with NO MEAT?  Okay, let me boil some plain noodles and fix up a salad.  Woop woop.

Then, Enjoy opened up my eyes, took me wonder by wonder, and showed me a whole new world.. of vegetarian food.

I was pretty skeptical of the "MONGOLIAN BEEF!" and "KUNG PAO CHICKEN!" because they weren't really beef or chicken.  Everything is soy or gluten-based.  Sketch...

I still have to say that I don't really like the texture of the vegetarian beef in the Mongolian form, but the flavors are excellent, the portions are generous (their lunch special is $7.50 for a bowl of rice - white or brown, a crispy spring roll, a bowl of soup, and the dish), the place is clean, and it just all falls into place.

My Ma Po Tofu was yummy.  The sauce was a bit too sweet and not spicy enough for my liking,  but the tofu was silky and soft, and the brown rice was cooked perfectly.  My other complaint is that the bowl of rice they give you is heinously small.  Seriously, it was maybe 1/4 the amount that I would normally eat.  But then again, I'm convinced I'll die of gluttony someday.

They even have yummy-looking desserts (we were too full to try) like fried banana with ice cream, and coconut milk with black sticky rice.  I'm totally a fan of this place, and this is definitely a nice, un-crowded lunch spot on the border of Chinatown and Financial District if you don't want to feel heavy, greasy and nasty after eating a big lunch.

Upon walking out of the restaurant, I told Coworker that I felt clean and not greased up.  Word vomit!
author: Tori S.

description:
There's plenty of places to get vegetarian/vegan asian-style cuisine in SF. For me, Enjoy and Loving Hut in Chinatown are equally close. I am a huge fan of Loving Hut.  It's hard for me not to want to go there when I have some extra money. But every once in a while I'll go to Enjoy instead and I'm usually happy I do.  Enjoy is a little bit different from places like Loving Hut and Golden Era because they are even more restrictive with what ingredients they'll put into the food (for example, there is no garlic or onion.) As someone who loves both those ingredients, it's hard to imagine food tasting good without them.  But Enjoy somehow manages to offer a huge menu of delicious fake meat and vegetable dishes.

I've loved almost everything I've ordered here.  The lettuce wraps and crispy chicken are both particularly excellent.  One item I did not care for was the drumsticks, but maybe that's just because I was comparing it to the drumsticks at Golden Era (which are out of sight.)  I've come here while the lunch special was going on and it was a super cheap deal. All the staff is really nice and don't leave you hanging (which is a huge pet peeve of mine.) If you work in FiDi or are venturing to the depths of Chinatown and/or North Beach, check this place out.
author: Jon T.

description:
The girl who served us was very nice, genuinely, and that always helps.  Always.

BBQ and whatever fried rice:  Very plain.  Only the fake meat was flavorful/seasoned.  Was okay with food, but bland alone.

Lemony chicken stuff:  Sweet.  Lemony.  Chicken had great texture, but lemon isn't my thing.  If you like lemon, I'd recommend it.

Braised ribs:  Magical.  But there's some sort of vegetable that looks like a potato chunk, but tastes like cauliflower.  Something to consider if you're afraid of things you can't identify.

Curry chicken:  Was too spicy for me to enjoy (when things get too spicy, they taste like nothing to me).  Smelled great.  Chicken consistency was good.  Our heat loving friend said it was legit.

Crispy chicken appetizer:  Amazing.  Even our weird meat eating friend (who doesn't like the texture of beans or peas, hates carrots, hates the taste and texture of tofu, and the feeling of wooden chopsticks touching his mouth) loved them.  That's quite the test to pass.  Highly recommend.

It's not that cheap though, unless you're splitting a dish.  Just a heads up.
author: Salem S.

description: It's hard to find a good vegetarian restaurant that my mother likes. She is a very strict vegetarian and this place was perfect. The food is flavorful and still authentic. Their meat substitution is amazing. Most vegetarian restaurants use poor quality, or tasteless options. They also have a second location on Geary in Inner Richmond, which I actually like better.
author: Tiffany G.

description:
I've tried many of the other dishes.  But the lemon chicken is still a favorite when I crave meat, the house special fried rice when I need a heaping of carbs, or the curry chicken fried rice when I want something with a lil kick.  The mustard green veggie ham soup with soba noodles are great when I'm not craving rice.  One thing that never changes is that regardless of what I order, the portions are huge, especially for a lunch special.  (Don't forget the soup of the day and egg roll that also come with the order.)  The pictures don't do them any justice.  The food takes up the whole plate/bowl (their side of rice is skimpy, in a smaller bowl, but probably the right amount if we're talking portion control).  Here, you really get your money's worth, which is notable, when you're typically spending $10 for a lunch in the FiDi.

I still come here at least once a week on my lunch hour when I not only want a relaxed, sit-down meal, but something that's filling, usually on a big mileage day.  I'd give it a four and a half, as they're still solid with consistently good food.  What's preventing an "as good as it gets" is that once in awhile, the service is non-existent, to the point where I have to get up to give/retrieve the check.  It's rare, but it's happened often enough.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I love these folks! I get takeout from this location about once a week. The $7.99 lunch special is great and comes with a (delicious) vegan eggroll. It usually takes ten minutes after calling in your order, and I've never had to wait after arriving. The service is brisk but the staff there are really good at their jobs, just not chatty. 
My favorites: mock beef with broccoli, vegan wontons, fried spring rolls, and the tofu with basil eggplant. 
The only thing I'd avoid are the taro puffs- starchy and kind of yucky after the first couple of bites, but that could just be me.
author: M L.

description: Thoroughly enjoyable! We had the Tom yum soup as an appetizer, twice cook pork and the house special chow mein with veggie pork and ham. The vegetables were all fresh and well presented. There was no reliance on MSG or other flavor enhancers. We left without the heavy oily feeling you get from Chinese restaurants in this price range. Very good dinner!
author: Nathan W.

description:
This place is my go-to lunch spot for my sometimes-"Meatless Mondays" (I tend to stray from it due to my perpetual carnivorous cravings). But I love this place because its vegetarian meat tastes even better than real meat itself! I love the spare ribs with daikon, the eggplant with sea bass, the basil chicken, and the string bean with chicken. All dishes are around $10. Not  only does it taste absolutely delicious, but you are saving the animals!!! That should make you feel better about yourself at the end of the day that you're not eating any dead animal carcasses.

Their Sunset location is also wonderful and just as good if you live nearby. I like to get take-out from there.

Also a great place to take your vegan and carnivore friends if they're fighting over whether to go to a salad bar or a steakhouse. Take it from me, I am a carnivore like no other. I was afraid that I'd be paying to eat grass but the fake meat really is deceiving. Yum!
author: Cheri S.

description:
If you like Chinese food and you want to eat healthy, this place is absolutely perfect!

Tastes just like the Buddhist vegetarian places that I frequent with my parents in HK. And that's pretty much as good as it gets!

Personal recommendation is the walnut prawns with mayo. It's my go-to dish at Chinese restaurants, and the version at Enjoy Vegetarian was just as good! Amazing!

I only wish I could eat here all the time...
author: Elaine W.

description:
I'm not a vegetarian and still think this place is great.  I'm a fan of their golden knots and eggplant with sea bass.

Meat-eaters:  do not go in expecting meat dishes; expect a fresh take on things!  This is one of those places you can close your eyes, experience a palate of new flavors, and not worry about eating something that tastes good but is something your brain might prefer to spit out... (think of some of the exotic foods on that Anthony Bourdain show...).

We came here on a Sunday night, which was perfect -- the restaurant was busy but not crowded, and we were able to find street parking nearby.  I would definitely come back.
author: Bay Area Explorer X.

description: This Chinese food is delicious and all vegetarian! I enjoyed the "cuddlefish" and some "spare ribs." The service was very fast and friendly! Definitely recommend.
author: Hi T.

description:
I was in the area around lunchtime, and I initially thought I was in the mood for some fake-meat stuff.  By the time I arrived, I decided I wasn't all that hungry after all, so settled for steamed buns and a bowl of miso soup.

The basic problem is that none of the food has any savory-ness, and it all also lacks salt.  Both of these are problems in terms of flavor, but also particularly regrettable in a vegetarian restaurant, since one of the main complaints of omnivores is that vegetarian food cannot be satisfying.  I was brought a complimentary spring roll, that tasted like... deep fried rice paper with cabbage inside.  Needs something sesame or peanut, and SALT.  I kept an open mind, and was brought my miso soup.

Now, as with much Japanese cuisine, miso soup is a simple dish that trades heavily on proper technique and ratios.  This soup tasted mostly like dashi, there was not nearly enough miso.  Probably a bit too much wakame, but I wouldn't had noticed if the soup was competent.  Yes, even the miso soup lacked salt!

Finally, the steamed buns.  Same problem.  Really bland, like eating unseasoned dough with some strangely acidic cabbage filling.  Salt salt salt your food, seasoning is like the first thing a chef learns.

It pains me to write a one-star review, but I really do want to discourage people from coming here.  Perhaps their fake meats come already seasoned, which is why others are enjoying those dishes.  If you are going to go here, I suggest at least steering clear of the items I ordered, and trying one of the things people are raving about in other reviews.
author: Nick Z.

description:
This place was bomb! My friend got the eggplant tofu basil satay and it was made the perfection. The infusion of the savory sauce into the stringy eggplant gave each bite a burst of flavor. 

I got the Thai spicy and sour noodle soup (which was probably a mistake at a Chinese restaurant). The soup, however, was spicy with a hint of tanginess that I like. The only problem I probably had was that they have me too many noodles...haha. 

We came in when they were about to close and for a Chinese restaurant to stay open for four people is almost unheard of and it certainly made the ambiance a lot better. Not to mention the cute fans made of fans on the ceiling!
author: Torrence T.

description:
I happen to really like Loving Hut (Milpitas location), so I was using it as my frame of comparison while I was dining here.  I have to say everything was either average or below average.  

Veggie BBQ Pork - I just couldn't get past the texture.  It was not really like BBQ Pork at all.  Maybe I was expecting too much from "pork" tofu.

Crispy Tofu w/ Salt & Chili Pepper - This dish was SO salty, like unbearably salty, which sucked because this is usually one of my favorite dishes when I'm at a Chinese restaurant.  After two bites I couldn't really eat much more of it.

House Special Fried Rice - The only dish I really liked.  Tasted like any other fried rice you'd get at a Chinese restaurant, but at least it didn't taste bad.

Walnut Prawns w/ Mayonnaise Sauce - This was ok too, but way too much mayo.  The wheat gluten crescent moons were good though, once I scraped most of the mayo off.

One thing this place has going for them is that it is REALLY clean and nicely decorated, something you can't really say about most Chinese restaurants.  Even the bathrooms are clean!
author: Angeline K.

description:
Great food, service and hot tea. The sauce for the spring roll is fabulous! 
Its around the corner from work and with all of the different dishes they offer I will have to come back many times :)
author: Alissa C.

description: I like to say that this is a vegetarian restaurant for carnivores. The flavors are so rich and interesting that anyone with tastebuds will enjoy this place (enjoy, get it?). You definitely won't miss meat when you come here.
author: Maveric V.

description:
My labia clenched a little at the thought of this place...I'll admit, I'm a veggie food whore and am very picky about where I choose to eat my fake farm animals! 

They are very strict with their ethics here: Dishes do not contain MSG, garlic or onion. At first, I thought the food would be flavorless but I was wrong!! MMMMMMM....

Their menu is overwhelming to say the least. There are over 100 items on that thing, it's not that serious -_- 

lezbreakitdown:

Samosas - BOMB

Fried spring rolls - BOMB

Pot stickers - BOMB

Drumsticks - Okay, NO. It's bad...the skin is flavorless and this odd texture. It's paper thin, but when you bite into it, it kind of just sits there. YUCK.

Miso Soup - AVOID. I can't do veggie miso soup, I need the fish sauce in there...it just aint the same without it!

Fried chicken with lemon sauce - !!!!!!! BOMB !!!!!!!! My fav thing on the menu

Bean curd rolls - BOMB

Tomato beef chow mein - Disgusting.

Curry Chicken fried rice - Pretty good.

Their ice cream is bomb too! 

The lunch specials here are good too, it's under $10 for an entree, miso, rice and and egg roll.
author: Lydia L.

description:
The restaurant was clean and bright.

My friend ordered the tomato beef chow mein: ketchuppy and sweet, a bit soupy. I got the kungpao chicken: fine, not special. The chicken was a bit salty and chewier than other fake chicken I've had, but not unpleasantly so. The vegetables seemed fresh and nicely cooked.

Nothing was really bad, but you can get tastier food for about 25% less elsewhere. Maybe the onions and garlic are what I'm missing. The service wasn't any better than cheaper, real-meat places. The menu linked from this Yelp page is outdated-- almost everything is now $10+.
author: Juanito L.

description: Not at all recommended. Worse than any food court. The green curry tasted EXACTLY like a dirty kitchen towel. I mean it: exactly like a filthy towel. The chow mein was okay in flavor, but all noodles and no veggies. The noodles were cooked nicely and the flavors were mild but acceptable. Far too many menu options, hundreds in fact, that made me certain that food is not fresh. Take the Muni to Wonderland instead.
author: Sadie T.

description: Decent selection, although I'm not a fan of all the "faux meat" selections.  Opted for the spring rolls, dumplings, and lettuce wraps.  The servings were large and the free tea was a nice touch.  Service was excellent.
author: Candace M.

description:
I tried, I really did but the three times I've gone it's been a fail. I tried to like it because I'm a vegetarian that lives around the corner so liking this place would have been a great asset.

The pineapple fried rice is dry, the Mongolian delight is everything but delightful and the eggplant tofu is too watery.  Overall the food lacks flavor and the consistency of the fake meat is disgusting :(

I am not a fan of leaving bad reviews but sometimes they are needed!
author: Kassandra Z.

description: We love this restaurant! We came to the hotel nearby for a conference and had dinner here and the food was delicious! We're not vegetarians and we loved the food. The place was immaculately clean and the wait staff was super nice. On the way out we bought the sticky rice wrapped in some leaf (banana?) and it was the bomb!  The wait staff took time to explain to us how to heat it up (it's sold from a refrigerated case). What a great place!
author: Louis K.

description:
We had a veggie friend visiting a while back and having past this place a few times, we thought this would be a good place to visit given it has some good reviews.

The service was friendly (to make up for the fact there's no meat - I'm a meatatarian) and left a good impression.

The veggie guest was approving of our choice and the menu tricks you into thinking there is meat when there is more soy and protein replacement type foods.

I was a a little concerned at how this would taste, even if it sounded delicious.
My worry was unwarranted, despite the lack of meat, the food and sauces were excellent. It really means you don't need to have meat necessarily, but I'm all for the meat.

A good place for veggies though.
author: Nick L.

description:
We were a little sick so we ordered their vegetable soup. Overall yummy soup-- can't complain. Only issue was that they were a little weak on the noodles so we asked for more and they said it would be a $5 charge (but then they lowered it to $3. I'm trying to eat my dinner--- not negotiate.) Anyways long story short the soup was $8. Could be a good small meal for 2 people.
** Recommendation: Add extra noodles for $2 on the menu
author: Lee R.

description: My go-to restaurant for lunch in the financial district.  Quality of food is consistently good and even though some menu item made me question if it's really a "vegetarian" restaurant at first, but after a few visits, I finally figured that the "meat" items on the menu are just imitation meat that are made from all veggies!  It's hard to find anywhere else with food that is rich in flavor and no MSG added.  Highly recommended.
author: Carlos F.

description: LOVE this spot.  Eat here about once a week, very clean flavors and not super greasy.  Won ton soup, kung pao "chicken", mixed veggies are my GO TO.
author: laurel f.

description: There were 3 of us that went in for lunch. We didn't realize they closed at 230 pm and so we had come in close to closing time. The waitress rushed us to put our order in before the kitchen closed and seemed moderately annoyed. The food came out in less than 10 minutes, which was surprising. We were pretty disappointed because the waitress didn't ask us for drinks nor were we provided with utensils. Our waitress didn't even come by to ask us if everything was okay or if we needed anything. And when we were halfway through our meal, she left the restaurant's front door wide open, bringing in the super cold air. The food itself was mediocre, portions were small, and nothing too special on the menu. As vegetarians, we were severely disappointed; would not recommend to anyone else.
author: Aanal P.

description: My favorite vegetarian chinese place in the city so far. Have come here twice so far and loved everything I have tried out of their huge menu. They give you some strange tea instead of water, which is kinda cool, but gets irritating after a while (They give you water if you ask for it). Their fragrant crispy chicken (made out of fake meat) is pretty yummy, my omnivorous friend claims it tastes exactly like the real thing. I like the golden knot. Try the Golden Knot entree which is vegetables wrapped up with soy sheets.. pretty yummy!
author: Aditya M.

description:
This place is a gem!!! 
I just discovered this restaurant today. I had a lunch special (about $7.50) which includes rice, soup and a spring roll. 
They offer all kinds of vegetarian options, including veggie beef and chicken. 
I got the Kung Pao Tofu with white rice. Full of flavor! 
The soup is a little weird, but I don't like little corn kernels in anything, so that is probably just me. 
The service was very fast, friendly and accurate!!! I am pretty sure the person who took my order called me sweetheart. 
Love!!!
I can't wait to try more dishes!!!
author: joanna r.

description:
I'm not a vegetarian but thought this place was delicious! The dishes resemble many of the common dishes you find at Chinese restaurants but are made with soy protein, yam or wheat. It's hard to find a good Chinese vegetarian restaurant but I would have to say that this is one of them! The service is great (friendly workers and quick service), the restaurant is clean, and the prices are very reasonable. It's located conveniently near Chinatown and Financial District. Now for my food reviews...

Appetizers:

-Combination Platter (Soybean Sheet, BBQ Pork, Tofu, Sweet & Sour Wheat Gluten) - $5.99 (small), $7.99 (large)
(The small is sized so that it's probably only good for sharing with 2. It was still very tasty. The sweet & sour wheat gluten was my favorite out of this dish. Order a large if you're planning to share this with more than 2 people since the small only has about 3-4 pieces of each variety.) 

-Fragrant Crispy Chicken - $5.99
(The "chicken" is made with soy but it tastes just like chicken! It was fried perfectly with just the right amount of crisp. I would recommend this appetizer.)

Entree:

-Black Pepper Sauce w/ Steak Meat & Green Vegetable - $8.50
(Great taste!  The soy protein doesn't have the same texture as real beef but it was still very good. This dish is generously portioned and the sauce was very tasty.)

-Taro, Sesame Veggie Chicken Cooked w/ Coconut Sauce - $8.50
(Highly recommend this dish if you like taro or coconut milk! The taro was cooked just right and the coconut milk made the dish so creamy and tasty. The soy protein tastes just like chicken. Order this and you won't be disappointed!)

I can't wait to come back to try more of their other dishes!
author: Angela F.

description:
Being one of the few vegetarian restaurants in the downtown SF area, I expected a lot out of this restaurant, maybe too much. I have been here twice now and the food just kind of confused me - maybe the dishes I tried weren't that great (a chow mein dish and a pumpkin & taro clay pot), but either way, I was disappointed each time. The servers are pretty nice, though they did forget my order one time; I kindly reminded them that I still had an order when all my friends' orders had already come out, and by the time I got mine, most everyone else was done. I wish I could have gotten a discount or something, but then again, I don't mind supporting any local vegetarian eatery. 

A lot of my friends recommend this place though, so maybe it's just me. The location is a bit sketchy come evening time (edge of Chinatown/FIDI), but there is a lot of room inside.
author: Julia H.

description: I ate in this restaurant several times. Ordered some "meat" dishes (all made of soy products). The flavor is good and the price reasonable. The place has a peaceful atmosphere. Relaxing after shopping in the busy and crowded Chinatown :).
author: judy m.

description: Truly amazing food. If you don't try their tofu and hot sauce, you're missing something special.
author: Patrick H.

description:
Oh yes, fake meat. I once raved about Golden Era (speaking of which, I need to get there, pronto!), so my coworker said I will "enjoy". As in, Enjoy Restaurant. Hmm, will I?

Enjoy's vegetarian offerings is slightly different than your usual veggie fare. They do things the Chinese Buddhist way - no garlic and no onion. Supposedly, chives are part of that too, but that's not on Enjoy's no-no list. Hmm.

"Oh no! What am I gonna do without garlic?" another coworker exclaimed. "I love garlic." He came back anyways.

I never leave this restaurant without having a good ol' "drumstick", followed by a good helping of Mongolian "beef" and "fish". I haven't had everything, probably because Enjoy have a lot of dishes, and they're all too good for me to pick favorites. But maybe skip the fried rice. I never was a fan of fried rice in restaurants; they just don't have Mom's special touch.

As you can probably tell by the number of check-ins I have, I do "enjoy" this place.
author: Hannah H.

description: LOVE their food soooo much. You would not know you have no meat on your plate and you will learn how to love it just like me.
author: Sweetie Joanna A.

description: Most delicious!  I'm always happy with the food they serve. Perfect hot and sour soup. Wish they had a location in the North Bay.  You don't have to be a vegetarian to enjoy their food!!!
author: Mar I.

description: Healthy Chinese vegetarian food, replacing the supposedly bad stuff with tofu and gluten.  Nice lunch option (soup, egg roll, white/brown rice + entree) for $7.50.  We got the tofu balls and gluten + black mushroom.  http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=l-zgWG-brcQ4iRev-pfrsg&select=BANn030kFeqmnc3guMaccw  Plenty of sauce and greens - a light feeling meal.  Yes, I felt good about myself after eating here.  Yes, I was hungry an hour after I ate here.
author: Peg S.

description: Loved all the food we ordered! Decent portion and price. Service is kinda slow (we were there between 12-1 and it wasn't even that busy...
author: Cindy C.

description: As we walked in, we were greeted by the friendly staff. The vibe in the restaurant was great; very relaxing. The vegetarian chow mein, the spring rolls and dumplings were all very tasty. It was definitely worth the walk from Union Square.
author: Mai B.

description: aweful tasting food. absolutely bland. all the wrong flavors in the wrong places.  and i'm a vegetarian so i have tasted these chinese vegan/vegetarian dishes up and down the peninsula and the south bay.  and in san fran as well.  was pretty crappy. or maybe it was what we ordered. but we ordered two dishes and both were awful.
author: Helper P.

description: Absolutely out of this world! I had the vegetarian Mongolian Beef dish and I was amazed at the taste and consistency of the vege beef... really flavorful, all with a wonderful spicy chili sauce, bell peppers and more. I love that style dish over rice. I would highly recommend this place for any folks who love vegetarian Chinese food... or those who want to try it out.
author: Ashley T.

description: I'm seriously obsessed with the food here. I randomly stumbled into this place on Chinese new year 3 years ago and crave their food everyday . This place has become one of my " I'm super depressed and I know what will make me happy places"! Not only is this place great for vegan and vegetarians, I've even brought in my meat eating friends and they loved it, which is hard to do. Plus the staff is super friendly. So now that I'm done obsessing about this place I'll get to the best dishes that I can't stop dreaming and drooling over. The curry friend chicken is so yummy, to me it's like crack. The other two are the string bean with beef and the sweet and sour chicken. The string been and beef melts in your mouth, it's crazy that this place doesn't use any dairy,meat, garlic, or onion and it still kills it when it comes to Chinese food.
author: Isabella E.

description:
Enjoy Vegetarian, a feel good restaurant. A place where you do good for your body, for the environment and for your palate.  

I've driven by their sister restaurant (same name) in the Sunset District many times, but hadn't gotten around to trying it.  Fortunately, this 2nd location is conveniently close to work.

I was glad my meat lovin' colleagues were keen to try EV. They had the Mongolian beef and sweet and sour chicken.  They liked it, even though the meat was fake - was told the chicken tasted better than the real thing.  I had the eggplant, tofu, basil stir fry. Delicious!

We enjoyed their Lunch Special (Tuesday through Friday, 11a - 2p). For $7.50 you get the soup of the day, an entree from their special list, spring roll, and your choice of white or brown rice. For some reason, we were all happily full after consuming 1/2 our meal.  Great leftovers for Round 2.

EV uses Buddhist veg. principles - they don't use any animal products, no egg nor dairy.  They also don't use MSG, onions, nor garlic and cook with reduced oil. So it really is good for you (and for your present company - no mints needed).  Most of their fake meat are created out of soy products.  

I've been to this space when it was a different restaurant, and what a transformation! Stone tiles, warm walls, feels clean and comfortable.  Nice service. I look forward to coming back.
author: Cathy K.

description:
Wow! Delicious. What more can I say. Coming from Florida, I am easily impressed by vegetarian restaurants, but this place stands out even in Bay Area California. Wonderfully cooked soft and tender "pipa" stuffed tofu is not found in many restaurants, but it is delectable here. The "spare ribs" were also quite interesting and delicious. Most dishes are very healthy with vegetables, but of course there's fried delicacies too - just gotta have that fried sometimes. The fried taro cake was different from what I am used to - here it is a lot more taro than at many other places. For dessert, crispy sesame balls with red bean filling were crunchy and just sweet enough without being overly sweet, and cute size at it (small but tasty! In this case, size doesn't matter!) And if that weren't enough, you can get to-go "tzong tzi" which is banana leaf wrapped sticky rice with filling such as mushrooms, chestnut, and veggie-ham, to take home to eat the next day - just steam or microwave. Mmmmm. Yummy.

The restaurant itself is decently decorated, a good size, and clean. Not the fanciest place in the world, but definitely above average style wise. Prices are great for the location in San Francisco, and service is friendly. Public transportation is easy to get to. I would definitely recommend this as one of the top Asian vegetarian places to eat at in the country - so what are you waiting for, eat up!
author: Em S.

description:
too expensive for vegetarian food.

I liked the taste of the food and its flavors were okay but I can't get over the overpriced tofu fake meat I'm eating.

Ordered the chicken nuggets for $6.99 for 8 pieces...I could get 20 for $5 @ mc donalds.
Ordered the fatty pork which had great flavor but it was overtaken by the the different spinach that were present on the plate.  The pork tasted like tofu like fake mean and had a "fatty" portion that consisted of some glutinous like looking jello part, it had pretty good texture.
This is a great place to try but I will not be coming back here.
author: Steph Q.

description: I love this place! As a Cantonese, I found many authentic options here, and the dishes are definitely hearty! As a picky foodie who seldom reviews, I give it five stars, and I am going to revisit this place before I leave SF!
author: Laura L.

description:
GO ELSEWHERE.
Worst vegetarian asian food in the city. The food tasted like they washed it before serving it. I have no clue how they are open and making money off selling what they call food. This was some of the most flavorless food I've ever tasted in my life.


PS: If you're vegetarian and want good asian food, you'll have better luck trying a chain like Loving Hut than at this place.

Anyone who gives this place over 3 stars must be paid by yelp or has never had food with flavor.
author: Ryan P.

description: The fatty pork belly with cabbage and mustard greens was pretty awesome. Soy and yam, yumm. Fast and friendly service, nothing to complain about!
author: Julia W.

description:
I come here pretty often during the week for lunch.  Normally right around 2 (they close at 2:30 until dinner time). Always get seated right away and the place usually isn't busy at that time. The staff is friendly and remembers me and my typical order, which is nice. It's a bit of a rushed feeling at that time but the service is pretty decent nonetheless.  Occasionally they'll forget to bring me something like ice water (they bring tea to the table automatically instead of ice water) but they are always apologetic. 

The lunch special is a fantastic deal, it's around $7.50 and you'll get a spring roll, soup, rice and a decent sized meal.  Try and beat that in the area! They obviously serve a lot of lunch specials and the food does come really fast (particularly the spring roll and soup), but it doesn't effect quality. I sometimes get the feeling that they are rushing me out the door, but to be fair to do come in right around closing time. They never have a problem if I stay after closing, but they're busy cleaning away when I'm finishing up.

The food is pretty damn good. As a vegetarian I was always missing good Chinese/Vietnamese food by my office and was super happy when I found this place (a simple Siri search for vegetarian joints on the iPhone, Apple FTW!). Everything I've had has been fresh, tasty and relatively authentic (as authentic as possible for fake meat products). I normally get the Mongolian beef and it's fantastic. The soup is basic but tasty and the spring roll is pretty good. The food is not quite up to the quality of Central Vegetarian in Alameda or Golden Lotus in Oakland (for you East Bay'ers), but it's pretty damn close (hence the 4 stars and not 5...I'd probably give this 4.5 if I could).
author: Mike P.

description:
Oh man, do I enjoy this place!  

Favorite dishes:
 * Drumsticks (every time - all my non-veggie friends love these too)
 * Beef and Green Beans
 * Sesame balls and Mango ice cream for dessert

Everyone should check this place out, veggie or not!
author: Jon M.

description: Simply amazing!  Wonton soup was out of this world!  Dumplings were great, as was the spicy basil soy chicken and Lotus root plate!
author: May P.

description: Discovered this awesome restaurant recently with some work colleagues.  OMG.  Everything we ordered was so delicious and combinations of ingredients I had never tried -- like Lotus Root with snow peas, ginkgo seed; Stewed Pumpkin with taro, bean curd sheets in black bean sauce.  The textures and tastes - delicious and wholesome.
author: Nisi H.

description:
I love Chinese food. I really only eat it once in a blue moon because it's not the healthiest with all of the heavy sauces and salt that comes on so many dishes. However, Enjoy Vegetarian has a fairly large menu with plenty of lighter meals to choose from; and I've gotta say, the healthier menu items are pretty damn good. I love that they serve complimentary tea as soon as you sit down. It makes you feel cozy and welcome. 

A few other things that I appreciate about Enjoy are the convenient location, cheap prices, and friendly service!
author: Madeleine R.

description:
This is one of the BEST vegetarian restaurants in the Bay Area (only two are good, both in San Francisco). I go to this place tons of times. Everytime, perfect no complains! If you have a group, order their group dishes which you can pick out your own appetizer, main dishes, veggie shark fin soup, etc. Alice, the owner, is really nice I know her for a long time. I live in the East Bay, and I don't mind spending a bit more to go (gas and toll) to have a good meal. This place is a strict vegetarian restaurant, as in no onions, garlic. And of course NO seafood, strict vegetarians do not eat seafood. There are too many dishes to name that are good, you just have to try it! I'm a vegetarian for 27+ years (29 years now), I've tried a lot of restaurants, trust me! 

I also order togo during lunch hours at their other location, good price, soup, egg roll, one dish, brown or white rice. Can't beat it. 

**Parking, you can park in front of the restaurant in the yellow zone during dinner hours, they paid to have those reserved for their customers, I have seen them call the SFMTA/SFPD to have the cars ticketed in front, they were warned a head of time but refuse to move their cars.** Or you can park in the indoor garage next door which has good rates, and you can walk around Chinatown after. 

They have other locations such as on Kirkham and a new location (hint) coming soon. For their menu go to enjoyveggie.com
author: Charles W.

description:
Came here with a good friend during late lunch/early dinner as a recommendation from his family. I always feel stupid entering vegetarian restaurants like these where EVERYTHING is made without meat because I always realize this fact after I place my order, having scoured the menu for anything without the words "chicken," "lamb," "duck" or any other animal you can think of, preceding the dish. 

It's a very casual sit-down venue with a lot of great food options and a welcoming staff. Portion sizes vary, though most entrees are on the larger side, while the appetizers could do with some beefing up - I'm so funny. Between my friend and I, we couldn't even manage to finish off the three dishes that we ordered family style. And by the end, all we had energy enough to say was how full we were. 

We ordered the Veggie BBQ Pork and Fragrant Crispy Chicken as appetizers, followed by Mustard Green Veggie Fried Pork with Rice Cake and what I believe was the Black Pepper Sauce with Steak Meat and Green Vegetable. The chicken tastes like chicken, the pork like pork, though I'm not sure the steak (if that's what it was) tasted all too much like steak. Everything was enjoyable though and left me wanting to come back the next time I make a stop in SF.

The Thai Iced Tea was also good and I am dying to try their house special Sweet and Sour Chicken.

In Chinatown, as a vegetarian, I know how hard it can be to eat. But this is the place to go, even if you're not vegetarian.

Enjoy (haha)!
author: Ben D.

description:
I'm a vegan and I brought my meat-eating family here. The food was fairly tasty but unremarkable. The soup, appetizer and entrees were also all brought out at the same time. We ordered rice, but didn't get any and we were unsuccessful in flagging down a staff member to bring the rice until the meal was over.

We were all really disappointed with the service. The servers were extremely rude (my dad actually got "the hand" when asking for a glass of ice) and not attentive in slightest. 

The whole experience was really hard for me to stomach, especially as I'm always trying to educate my non-veg family members on the joys of eating veg. It'll be that much harder to get them to try a vegetarian restaurant in the future after this experience.
author: Jenn V.

description: Great food. Im vegan and my friend who is an omnivore invited me there. There were a good choice of tofu and vegetable dishes as well as soy meat and fish. Recommend the soy chicken with string beans, and the eggplant. Very affordable too, two dishes were enough for the two of us plus leftovers to take home.
author: Elly K.

description:
Food is OK, Service is very bad!!!!!  I had an awful experience for their service!!! Because these is a Chinese waitress who is discriminated disabled person!!!  
She is very impolite, bad mouth and disrespect to disabled person!!! Being a good restaurant, food and service are very important.  If you don't have a good service, there are no one would like to come back again!!!
author: Yy X.

description:
The lemon "chicken" and schezwan green beans are worth traversing completely across town = 5 stars.

For ambiance, a little music would be nice. It feels a little sterile / cold otherwise, but not that important when yummy factor gets better with every bite.
author: Theresa G.

description: The vegetarian dishes are authentic.  The taste is good, not too oily.   It's a restaurant worth trying even you are not a vegan.
author: Stink C.

description:
Family recommended this place and as we were walking down Kearney we decided to stop in and give it a try. The missus enjoyed the food, I on the other hand was neutral. 
I may have to give it another try.
author: Paolo B.

description:
After juggling for several days to eat vegetarian with a couple of meat-eaters friends I was craving a place where everything was vegetarian. After walking around a lot in SF area I was starving, so I yelped a place that was close to where I was and had only vegetarian food. This place was listed in the top and had really good reviews so I decided to give it a chance. It felt a little awkward initially because I was there super early (5 pm) and probably the first and only customer. I sat down and the first thing they brought was jasmine tea :) I then proceed to get a plate of dumplings as entree and then sweet and spicy "chicken". The dumplings were soft and juicy. The "chicken" tasted good and the sauce was what I was just looking for. The food didn't taste extraordinary but it was a nice change. the soy sauce that came with the dumplings didn't taste good and the main plate didn't have the "it factor" that would have give this place 4-5 stars. 
The service was ok, but they never thought on bringing me water and they rushed things a little bit. If I go back to SF, would try other places..
author: Sol A.

description:
(Wrote this a while ago... Baby is 4 months now. Too late to post?)

Lately I have had a real repulsion to meat. It is so bad that I can't watch Outback Steakhouse commercials without gagging. Oh the joys of pregnancy.

Thankfully, Enjoy comes to the rescue! Non-meat meat dishes please both the man (a carnivore) and me on a regular basis. Easy take out and affordable large portions are exactly what I need.

We have had some real hits. Most notably the "chicken" with green vegetables and the kung pow "chicken" were delicious. The broccoli "beef" on the other hand lacked flavor and I wouldn't recommend it. Also, it looked too much like real beef strips! I had to coax myself into eating it.

All in all, Enjoy is great and I am so grateful to have it in my neighborhood.
author: Hayley W.

description: Although there are plenty of vegetable options in Chinatown, this entirely meatless restaurant is a welcome addition. My daughter and I had lunch here, and we both enjoyed it. I had Soy Beef & String Beans and she had Mushrooms, Broccoli, & Soy Chicken. We shared the Golden Dough Balls for dessert, though I expect that the Sesame Balls are also quite good. We would definitely return.
author: Charles L.

description:
This is a good place to take a group, especially if the group is not very picky about food. This is the scenario in which I visited. 

Fragrant chicken - great 
Spring roll - gross, like a food court offering
Steamed Dumpling - bland 
Hot & sour soup - bland 
Cashew chicken - good
Veggie fried rice - good, not greasy
Kung Pao chicken - eh
Lemon chicken - eh

I'm sorry, but this is the type of place that gives vegetarian food a bad name.
author: Shal J.

description: the difference between oily, msg, salty, garlicky food and enjoy vegetarian food is like night and day -  quite astounding.    My favorite was the lemon chicken and eggplant see bass.
author: Wakako U.

description: Their menu has different types of dishes than your average vegetarian Chinese restaurant. They have pretty good service here. I recommend this restaurant.
author: Jenny H.

description: Delish!!! I chose eggplant with tofu n basil. It was fast,hot, flavorful and a decent portion. The service was pleasant. I'm a foodie and pretty picky so, I would come here again.
author: ELLA B.

description: Meh. After reading all of the positive reviews for this place on Yelp I was super excited to try it. I'm a vegetarian and I hadn't eaten all day so I stopped by around 8.30pm. The staff weren't very friendly and I felt a little rushed, I was still clearly looking through the 4-page menu when they were asking me if I was ready to order (probably less than a minute after they even handed me the menu) I went for the tofu, eggplant and basil dish with a side of steamed brown rice. I got home and opened my rice..they gave me white rice instead of brown (which I don't eat, so it was a waste of money) The satay sauce was mostly oil/water consistency and disappointing. The tofu was okay, I mostly enjoyed the eggplant which was cooked just right. Overall I wouldn't rush back again, it was okay but very underwhelming and for the price I expected more.
author: D S.

description:
My husband and I have been going to Enjoy for years, now with our son at the Kearny location. It is our favorite place to eat, the food is always fresh and delicious and the beautiful family that owns it are the sweetest people. They treat us like family and we always leave beyond satisfied.
I can't say enough, it's the best Chinese food in town and the best service.
Our favorites are the spareribs, sweet and sour chick,Mongolian beef,house special fried rice or chow-main. Fragrant crispy chicken, lamb in clay pot, kungpow chick,
Broccoli beef, lemon chick.
Love, love, love!
author: Erica P.

description:
It's one of the better vegan restaurants in the city. I forget what things are called because my Chinese is horrible. Plus when I order here it usually involves a lot of pointing at pictures. 

That lettuce wrap thing is a must try. My other favorites are the eggplant and seabass and the salty fish fried rice.
author: Simon L.

description:
E - Ever so tasty, even without meat!
N - Nicely priced and neatly arranged dishes
J - Just about has every Asian-style dish you can think of (lots of menu options)
O - Open for lunch! ($7.50+tax includes soup, egg roll, main dish, and side of brown or white rice!)
Y - Yellow walls, newly painted and remodeled? Clean interior. 

Come visit Enjoy when you've been too carnivorous this past week or want to try some really delicious vegetarian dishes. You'll really be amazed everything tastes so good without meat!
author: NickJess S.

description:
Whoa, a huge lunch that actually turns into two meals for me that's close to my office for less than $10? Sold.

Get the lunch special. For $7.50 ($8.20 after tax) you will be given a feast! Entree, rice (brown or white), spring roll, soup. Hello dinner via leftovers!

If you're ordering to-go, go straight to the register in the back instead of awkwardly hovering inside the door like I did on my first trip. And you only wait a short amount of time before your food is ready, such a plus.

I had the lemon chicken, which was yummy, but I'll definitely branch out when I go back. So many choices! Something I've gotten maybe a little too used to as a vegetarian is only having a few options on a menu, so the choosing process isn't too difficult. But here, choices galore! Not only do I get lots of good food, I also get to work on my laggy decision skills. Double whammy!
author: Kim B.

description: We discovered this place by accident while walking around North Beach and Chinatown with an out of town foodie friend. Our original intent was to eat at an Italian restaurant, but he wanted to try this place. It was a great choice. M and I have returned many times. We usually order three dishes and take home leftovers. Life is good.
author: D L.

description: The vegetarian won ton soup and basil soy chicken was sooo good!
author: Katie B.

description:
3.5 stars

I'm here pretty often during lunch.  The food is spotty at times, but good overall.  The service is not bad for a restaurant in Chinatown.  The lunch time deals are very fairly priced for the area.   Some of my favorites are the sweet and sour chicken, eggplant and tofu satay  and the curry chicken fried rice.  Everything tastes very authentic and is a great alternative to the typical Chinese.
author: E C.

description: Great vegeterian Chinese food - they have meat imitations of all kinds :) Very clean, super friendly, bright and colorful. Also pretty cheap and lunch is a decent portion with a spring roll. I try to eat there every time I'm in SF.
author: Arek K.

description:
I don't hate vegetarian food. In fact, I tried the veggie-life for a few months and didn't writhe in agony during meals. (Chicken satay just knocked on my door one night, and I couldn't turn her down. Temptress.)

The folks at Enjoy Vegetarian really know what they're doing with veggie dishes. I live near their other location, but found myself stumbling around the Financial District after a couple of drinks craving some salty food. Salty food found. That's one thing I love about my herbivore-happy buddies, they know how to salt the heck out of everything. 

Here's what I do: 
-If it's your first time, ask the waitress for suggestions. The menu is pretty daunting, and if you're used to eating meat centered meals, you need all the help you can get. 
-Order the Fried Curry Potato Triangles, they have just the right amount of curry. 
-Order the House Special Fried Rice. It comes with veggie bbq pork and veggie ham. This was awesome, it tasted like bacon. Real bacon, made from pigs. 
-Enjoy the orange slice they give you to end the meal (Maybe it's just me, but orange slices after meals always remind me of my glory days - being the worst player on my youth soccer team, who always volunteered to sit out).
author: Chanti B.

description:
Great food, quick service. Friendly staff. What more can you ask.
House fried rice was really good.
author: Dinesh D.

description: Descent Chinese vegetarian food. I liked it. And their dessert menu is nice.
author: Jeremy Y.

description: This place is amazing! The menu is very large and they bring free green tea to the table. Would definitely come back again, also the customer service is wonderfully pleasant. The special fried rice is my favorite item on the menu.
author: Shelby E.

description:
Thank you sweet baby Jesus!

Not only does Enjoy have a location near my house, but now one within walking distance of my office! Somebody up there has got to love me (or at least wants me to eat Pia Pa Tofu balls every day, all day) 

The lunch special is huge and best of all, cheap. As we all know, finding lackluster lunch specials are a dime a dozen, but $7.50 here gets you an entree, brown or white rice, a small cup of soup, as well as an egg roll. The eggplant with tofu and satay sauce blows me away, but it's hard for me to walk away from their tofu balls surrounded by a crown of broccoli.

Either way, if you haven't visited the Kirkham location of this restaurant, definitely hit up this FiDi/Chinatown gem.
author: Clarissa S.

description: Clean lunch time ambiance.  I wanted some healthy food so I came here.  ordered eggplant w/ green beans in black bean sauce.  it was deep fried and oily.  I told them and they told me I should get it sautade next time.  Something to think about.
author: Prez M.

description:
I was never a fan of veggies...salads...carrots...and the like, so when my friend took me to Enjoy Vegetarian, I was skeptical and only went because his cousin works there and hopefully we would get some free food. His cousin was not, but the manager/owner recognized him and gave us some free crispy chicken on the house. Awesomeness!

First of all, the manager (and I think owner) of the restaurant is super nice and personable. She always has a smiling face and constantly asked us how we were doing. 

When I looked at the menu, all the food items looked so delicious and tempting but in my mind I thought, "This is not real Mongolian beef and walnut shrimp...it's fake!" Indeed it is fake but the taste is absolutely genuine and to die for. We ordered the Mongolian beef, walnut shrimp, and mapo tofu. The mapo tofu wasn't very special as I've had that everywhere else but it was the beef and the shrimp that amazed me. Although the Mongolian beef was too salty, the food tasted so novel and so foreign but tasted so damn good. 

Also, make sure to order the pearl drinks! They are less than $3 and the pearls are amazingly fun to drink. Unlike tapioca pearls, these pearls are covered with a thin skin filled with sweet juices inside that pops in your mouth. Kids will love doing this.

Overall, this restaurant alone changed my perception of eating "vegetarian." I used to have an ignortant perception of what vegetarian food now but this restaurant has opened me up. I definitely will go eat vegetarian from here on out.
author: David W.

description: Yum.  We ate here twice on our recent trip.  Wings and nuggets were hits with our kids.  My wife and I liked the cashew-chick-un dish.  Friendly staff, good service.
author: Bethany F.

description:
Delicious, cheap, vegan Chinese food.

An excellent lunch spot - I don't think there's a bad item on the menu.
author: Evan M.

description: For 3 years straight I believe, I celebrated my birthday here. :) I am vegetarian and this is my happy place. No matter how many times I go there I always get the same thing: vegetarian chicken with string beans in a black bean sauce and wonton soup without mushrooms or bok choy....I ask them instead to add in broccoli. Can you tell I'm a picky vegetarian? The waitresses are super nice too!
author: Lisi G.

description:
With this new 15% yelp deal, I will definitely come here more often.

Is it me, or are there people out there that think eating meat on a regular basis for too long makes you feel groggy or tired?  I've eaten some pretty heavy breakfasts and lunches where towards the end of the day, I'm just beat.  Average Americans do not consume enough water and vegetables also.  

Enjoy Vegetarian is an alternative.  Notice more energy after your meals.  I love their Pei Pa Tofu Dish, the Pine Nut Fried Rice and Tofu Knots...yummm!  

Healthy never tasted so good.
author: Roland L.

description:
Not quite as good as the "other"/"original" one. But still pretty good.
Has a better ambiance than the other, but also feels more "expensive" and "selloutish" than the other.

Food still good. No MSG, No garlic, no onions, food still very good.
Had the stuffed cabbage, one of their specials, very very tasty - 5 stars
Kung Pao Chicken, also quite good - 4 stars
Good service as well :)
author: Parag K.

description:
AMAZING!  I never knew Vegetarian dishes can taste as good as this.  My co-worker recommended this place and boy, oh boy, the lunch dishes were so good, I am craving for more.  

I read some mixed reviews here and I'm wondering why?  Everything I've had was so delicious.  The lunch menu only cost $7.50 and it comes with a soup, rice (choice of white or brown rice) and a spring roll.  

We got the coconut sauce pumpkin, taro and gluten puff, and that was excellent.  It is so rare to find pumpkin, taro and gluten puffs cooked with coconut sauce, it was light and surprising, and simply mouth-wateringly good.

The sweet and sour chicken was also really tasty with sweet tangy tomato sauce, bell peppers and pineapple, I'm sure this dish would cater to the taste buds of many.

The Pai pa tofu with broccoli was also amazing.  It is tofu made with bits of stuffing.  
I also heard that the eggplant in spicy chili sauce is also worth trying.

The selection here is just amazing, and it is so delightful to find how creative vegetarian cooking can get.  The taste of the dishes here, I can say, far excels many other non-vegetarian Chinese restaurants I've had in the city.  Many of the dishes and flavors are not found anywhere else in San Francisco.

In my opinion, it is not just a fantastic vegetarian restaurant.  It is a fantastic Chinese restaurant period.
author: Nip Y.

description: Love this place, ever since golden era closed its been my go to for vegan chinese.  Everything is always super tasty and inexpensive.  I wish they would deliver, though.  Service is always very fast, lunch especially.
author: CC C.

description: Not really impressed by the fake meat concept. I found the food heavy but not really tasty. From now on, I will either go for real vegan or go for a place that prepare real meat.
author: Bruno D.

description: Soooo good.  If you are okay with vegetarian, but not enthusiastic, try the green beans and dry tofu.  Toasty goodness.  It seems there are many other adventures here I must try.  My meal buddy also loved the tofu skin vegetable wrap.
author: Michael E.

description: I really wanted to love this place. I dragged my meat loving boyfriend here for lunch in hopes that he would learn to appreciate the joy that is meatless meat! Unfortunately we both found the food lackluster and flavorless. I got a Taro & Chicken with coconut sauce, he had a green veggie fried rice dish and we shared Samosas as a starter. The Taro/chicken/coconut was lacking any flavor at all and the Taro chunks were large and mushy, and uncooked in the middle. The "chicken" was rubbery and did not have the texture of chicken at all. The sauce was thick and flavorless. My boyfriend's fried rice dish was lackluster at best with very little flavoring. The samosas seemed to be pre-frozen and nothing special and over priced at $6.99. The meal came to about $33. I've given it 2 stars instead of 1 star because they serve tea as part of the meal which is great, the decor is nice, and the bathrooms clean (though there was no soap in the ladies room).
author: Sonya S.

description: We came here on a Sunday night, August 4. This is the Kearny St location in Chinatown. It was past 8 PM when our first choice restaurant had over an hour wait. We found yelp's review of Enjoy and decided to give it a try. There were only 3 tables with customers when we came in. We were the last to leave before they close. The service was good. Waitress was helpful and answered all questions. We ordered 2 dishes and were very happy with our choices. All items are vegetarian. There is no MSG, garlic, or onion. Imitation meat and fish products are made of soy, yam or wheat products. Dishes are perfectly seasoned, not greasy like some Chinese restaurants. We had #45 Eggplant with seabass and # 54 lotus roots, lily, vegetables, snow peas, ginko nuts. Both are not the usual dishes made in most Asian restaurants we've tried. If we go back to SF we'll definitely come back to this place again.
author: Cathy T.

description:
Stopped by on a Monday night - felt like some healthy vegetarian food.  I don't get much fake meat where I live, so looking forward to a treat.
The restaurant is CLEAN.  Not crowded, no background music, so the ambiance is not much.  The waitress motioned me to a seat when I came in, and brought some tea.  
I ordered Beef with Broccoli and brown rice.  It came within a few minutes of ordering, and looked just like the picture on the menu.  It was a generous serving. The broccoli was excellent - plenty of it, and barely blanched.   So nice crunch and flavor.  The beef slices looked just like beef, and had the same texture as beef.  The brown rice in a small bowl was very well cooked - fluffy and not mushy.
So why not 5 stars?  The flavor was lacking.  Overall the sauce was pretty bland but not bad, and the beef didn't have much flavor either.
I added some chili paste and soy from the containers on the table, and finished it all. I'll probably be back to try a different dish the next time I'm in town, but I wasn't wowed.
author: Bob P.

description: Unique food that is clean and calming to eat.  Everything is vegetarian though there are meat-like dishes.  I ordered the String Beans w/ Beef, Ma Po Tofu and Hot and Sour Soup.  All the meat that should be in the dishes were replaced with lookalike substitutes.  Will it replace meat? Not at all, but it's delicious nevertheless.
author: Erica D.

description:
My favorite dish to order is always #90 Bean Curd Rolls.  The price $8.50 might be high but the portions are large.  Big Hint:  If you don't know what to order, order the "pictured" entrees in the menu.  The only thing that didn't appeal to me was the coconut TARO, and Sea Bass Eggplant-yet my friend loves it.
