If you're on a budget and want to try as many items inexpensively; go for their weekday lunches.  For $7.50, You get way too much food.  You get entree, soup, egg roll, brown or white rice and tea.  I recommend even bringing your own take out containers for leftovers. ( If you a light eater, like some females, this can be two meals.)

I do whatever I can to save them money so they can keep their prices down.  I love seeing Enjoy and Loving Hut serving Brown Rice in Chinatown. 

I hope these 2 restaurants will make Lucky Creation workers a bit less "loud".  They are more blunt and gruff cause some Chinese culture are like that. (not all)

(Lucky Creation workers also love to talk across the room, and you're in the middle of the room trying to munch your chow)

In summary, ENJOY  is definitely a good, clean, healthy place to go eat.  I don't have to worry about oily hydrogenated oil or cotton seed oil, MSG food which is too common in some Chinese Restaurants.   

For the past 40 years of my life, I was told, you MUST have MSG in Chinese food or it will be tasteless.... or that's the only way Chefs know how to make food and they won't listen to you!  BAH!!  humbug

If I want good food without that crap, finally I can find a restaurant that can cater to my needs.   As you can see I want this restaurant to stick around,,,,,so I can have another place to eat out.
Since this is a Buddhist establishment, ENJOY does not use garlic or onions.   Even without these two ingredients the restaurant knows how to make the food flavorful.
author: Sunny O.

description: I was a little disappointed. The food here was just okay. I ordered the lettuce wraps. They were good, but not superb. My sister ordered the lemon chicken. Don't waste your time. The lemon didn't taste like they actually used the citrus fruit and it was neon yellow. It looks like we just didn't know what to order and we should have read some reviews before going.
author: Katie L.

description:
$7.50 - for lunch!....in the FiDi, or a stones throw away from it.  I ordered their lunch special; miso soup, spring roll, rice and entree.  The service was SO fast - I called in and it was packed up, ready to go when I walked in the door.

I ordered the #4: Coconut Sauce w/ Taro, Gluten Puff & Pumpkin.  It was ok.  I think it was prepared correctly, just wasn't what I thought it would be...completely my fault.  Next time I will order something that I have had before at another resturant so I have a reference point.

The miso soup was a small portion, but had a ton of tofu.  The spring roll was a spring roll - good, not amazing.

I am defintely going back and will write an update on the next item I try out.
author: Megan H.

description: I tried this place for lunch with a friend. However, the food was not as good as the food available at Loving Hut (nearby vegan/vegetarian restaurant).
author: Sid P.

description:
I stopped eating Chinese food years ago because of MSG, grease, and you never knew if it was really vegan.
I was surprised last night to have some of the best eggplant I've ever eaten.
author: heather l.

description: Decided to try this place out on a whim. Ordered the hot and sour soup with wontons and eggplant with string beans. Both were so delicious and I will definitely be going here again. The service was also friendly and quick.
author: Niro D.

description:
Since there are so many vegetarian/vegan options in SF, I had to take my vegan friend to eat around town. I wanted to try another Asian vegetarian place, and what better source of info than a Yelp search!

Me and my friend came here for lunch and I again gorged myself with food. We ordered BBQ Pork for an appetizer, Hot and Sour Soup, Singaporean Rice Noodles, Sea Bass with Eggplant, and Pi Pa Tofu. 

The BBQ pork was definitely an interesting dish for me. Of all the fake meats I've experienced thus far, this one looked and tasted almost like the real BBQ pork you'd see at a Chinese gourmet shop! The other thing that totally got me was the Singaporean Rice Noodle. I was scared that this was just going to be a curried veggie rice noodle dish. But it wasn't. It literally tasted like the real thing, except they put fake ham instead of BBQ pork. 

This place really wowed me with their incredible selection. Best of all, all of that food and a bowl of brown rice came to freakin' 35 bucks! Cheap, delicious and healthy. It can't get better than this!
author: Diana C.

description:
They have a big menu, and lunch specials! Also I think all the dishes are vegan!! 

I had the bean curd roll- which I thought would be soft tofu wrapping the chopped up mushrooms and cabbage but they just use tofu skin... Some dishes tell you they use the tofu skin... well it was good so I'm ok with it.

I also got brown rice, because I read the reviews here and it's multigrain or something but I didn't like it because it was mushy, the kind of rice that lacks luster-moist but firm texture. 

The portion is large, and I think lots of veggies in every dish.
Recommended!
author: 0 L.

description: I'm not a vegetarian, but I found the food here tasty.  The simulated meat dishes were very well made - the mongolian beef looked and felt like very tender beef.  I would definitely go back for more.
author: Mark P.

description:
I'm kinda torn between giving this place 3 or 4 stars...but since I come here so often (b/c it's so convenient for lunch) I'll give it 4.

I've been to their sister store in the Sunset, but as I mentioned in my review, parking is difficult.  So I was really excited to see this place open up in Chinatown, which is really easy for me to walk to from work.

The lunch specials are great: for $7.50 you get: one spring roll, a bowl of soup and an entree with either white or brown rice.  There's never a wait for tables and the food comes out pretty fast (a good option for people who need to get back to work).  

I usually get the Ma-Po Tofu which is spicy, flavorful, and goes well with a bowl of rice.  The tofu is also really silky.  If I'm not feeling like something spicy, I'll opt for the Sweet and Sour Chicken.  The sauce is a bit thick, but I really like the taste/texture of their soy chicken.  Another one of my favorites is the Salty Fish, Chicken, Soft Tofu in Clay Pot.   

As I mentioned in the review of the original restaurant, there is a lot of variety.  So why not 5 stars?!  I feel like the service at this place can be hit or miss.  One time we ordered the Walnut Prawns to go and got home only to find they forgot our walnuts...true story!  Another time I ordered the Ma-Po Tofu and the waitress brought the food out and was like here's Kung-Pao Tofu (and then caught herself before I had to say anything and said, "oh! didn't you order the Ma-Po? Sorry..." and so I ate it...I mean, it was good, but it wasn't what I ordered!

Despite all that, I know I'll be back.  Solid food, convenience, and affordable.
author: Alvina W.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by how tasty the dishes were. We came with a friend who is vegetarian. 

We ordered the string beans in black bean sauce and "pork", braised "short ribs" with napa cabbage and daikon in clay pot and the eggplant and "sea bass". 

If you're looking to try something different in chinatown, I would check it out.  

I also found it amusing they charge $2 to use the bathroom if you're not a customer. I guess if you're in the area and are desperate for a bathroom - it's something good to know because it's actually a pretty nice bathroom. lol.
author: Annie c.

description:
Solid little Chinese restaurant just a block outside of Chinatown.  Some strange part of me was deeply desirous of some ham and pineapple fried rice and Enjoy did not disappoint.  
Tasty Thai iced tea, good fake meat, wonderfully flavored sauces, and very polite (and quick!) service.  
Get down with your vegan self!
author: Heather W.

description: Clean, busy, everyone seems to be happily enjoying huge amounts of food.
author: Lady B.

description:
This place on average is very good, but there are some items that are just horrible, and one of that is the curry. Never ever order curry here please, no taste at all.  The lunch menu is a good deal, $7.99 and it come with soup & an egg roll.  Some special items are $8.99.  

This place makes very good, walnut shrimp, which is not on the lunch menu & it is crazily expensive, $14.95 & that's the entree all by itself & it's not even real shrimp.  Those are pretty much made from soy & tofu, so I just can't understand why it is so expensive.  The overall price is on the expensive side but the portions are big.  I would rather see smaller portions and small price, at least that way people can order more varieties.... anyway, you'll catch me eating fake shrimp for $15 ever again.
author: Sasa L.

description: Amazingly simulated chicken, ham etc! Charming servers. Very attentive and helpful with suggestions and translation.  Best ham fried rice I've had in decades. Clean, open nice cheerful ambiance.  Cannot understand why anyone would give a negative review below 4!
author: Frank D.

description: My friend and I decided to try this place when it first opened.  I was really excited as I've had vegan food before.  The place looked nice and clean and when we looked around at everyone's food, it looked so yummy.  The food wasn't all the good and didn't have any flavor.  I felt like i was tasting paper.  I've had vegan food before but this place didn't make my "go to" list.
author: Joyce F.

description:
I've been to a few veg restaurants and liked the food. I've got dietary restrictions so I lead a vegetarian/pescetarian lifestyle, so I'm pretty okay with the fake meat deal.
The chicken here is okay, I've had much better at other restaurants (New Age Veg in the Tenderloin or Merit Veg if you're ever out in the Santa Clara area). However, I definitely like the Mongolian Beef dish. The soy beef is textured very similar to real beef, and the taste is really good. I also tried the beef broccoli but found it be bland and the gravy to be an odd consistency.  So, I just stick to the mongolian beef which hits the spot every time. Try it out, you won't be disappointed!
author: Shafaq C.

description:
I have been eager to try this newer, downtown location of my favorite restaurant, and was finally able to do so this rainy afternoon. I ordered the number 4 lunch special which is taro, pumpkin and wheat gluten in coconut sauce. Also included was rice of your choice (I was good and got brown rice), soup of the day (today was miso), and a spring roll. All of this goodness for a mere $7.50! 

Just like the Kirkham location, the service was warm, prompt, and the food was hot and delicious. The bathrooms were immaculate and was glad to see they charged $2 for non-customers to use the facilities.
author: C P.

description: Possibly the best vegetarian restaurant I have ever been to (and I am vegetarian). And the iced tea was like delicious, with a hint of cardamom.
author: Beth B.

description:
I've been here a handful of times and the food is always great.

Highly suggest the tomato beef and the lemon chicken.  The lotus root with mushrooms is also really good.

The staff is very friendly and the wait is pretty quick (around 10 minutes and food starts coming out after ordering).

The place is reasonably priced as well.  The only thing that bothers me is the weird hours where they close between 230-5 so if I want ENJOY in between those times, bleh.
author: Kameron K.

description: My second time eating here is way better.  The to go portions are huge.  I'm a happy fatty
author: Fatty A.

description: When the restaurant is called "Enjoy Vegetarian" - stick to the veggies. Its not called "Enjoy Faux Meat." I am a pretty prolific lover/consumer of tofu/bean curd/soy products  and the imitation meats here are pretty subpar. Their veggies are tasty (especially the eggplant), b/c they are basically oil transport mechanisms. The people are nice, the restaurant is peaceful, and the service is good, but stay away carnivores, there's nothing for you here. And Vegetarians, eat the faux meats if you want, but why on earth do you want to eat stuff that tastes like bad meat if you don't even like meat???
author: Snuffles B.

description: I like that I don't have to search for veggie options on the menu, and that there are so many choices.  Bummed that they changed their lunch special and removed the cup of soup (still comes with rice and an egg roll) since that was one of the big draws for me.  You can't even order a cup or small bowl of soup.  I wish they had removed he egg roll instead :(
author: melita s.

description:
I have yet to try something I didn't enjoy here and I come often for lunch.

Their lunch specials are great--I usually get sweet & sour chicken or lemon chicken. Their pai pa tofu balls are also delicious and also their #90 (stuffed tofu wrap/rolls).

Aside from the lunch menu, their sea bass with eggplant is also amazing. A bit pricier than lunch but a huuuge portion and I love the faux sea bass texture.

FYI I'm not a vegetarian. :)
author: Melody S.

description: Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant was a great place to take some new employees for lunch on their first day. It's a very easy walk from the financial district to China Town. The menu has many many choices! We were seated promptly and the service was excellent. The green vegetable fried rice, sauteed green beans and kung pao tofu were all delicious! Note: Some of the dishes on the menu offer meat substitutes. While that can be slightly disconcerting to some vegetarians, they are clearly marked for people to avoid or enjoy as they choose.
author: Ted C.

description: The best veggie Chinese food in town but it is a bit pricey.  The prices were ok for a while but now they have raised all of them.  $2 for a bowl of rice.  Really?  What happened to Chinese that would include rice with the meal?  Kinda lame and not old school.  The food is good and the ingredients are good.  I grew up with Chinese food being affordable and this is not the worst but it is bit much for a plate of veggies in some cases.  Still recommend for the veggie and vegan folks.
author: Bucky W.

description: Taste 5 health 4.5 interior 4 price 5 location 4
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I went here during the Chinese New Years parade a week ago with Tessie, boyfriend Smosh, Tessie's sister and their friend. It was a bit difficult to fine but that could be because of the massive crowd trying to get a peak of the end of the parade. We made it, after a bit of  difficulty pushing our way from the swarm. 

I made a reservation and they seemed to remember, even though I had made one the night before. Pretty cool. The service was good. Our server was nice and gave us plenty of time to think over our options. We ordered a number of things: chow mein, tofu, shanghai style rice cake, some pork thing, sea bass with egg plant, and spinach fried rice with pine nuts. Everything was delicious! 

The crazy thing was... the foods that were supposed to be meaty but was soy tasted like what they were supposed to. As a result, I pushed all the faux ham to the side (much to the enjoyment of my friends) because it tasted too close to ham and I'm not a fan. The sea bass tasted and had the texture of real fish. I don't know if it tasted like real sea bass but it tasted like fish! 

There was so much food left over that it was insane how little of a dent 5 people could make. The bill came to about 45 dollars, which is good considering the amount we got. Tessie and crew took the left overs and we left with a full belly. 

Oh yeah, and if you aren't a customer it's a nice $2.00 to use the bathroom. Just fyi!
author: squishy b.

description:
ordered $60 worth of food for 4 people and we were stuffed and had a lot left over. 

we got their healthy herbal soup.. yummmm.. good taste! 

the sweet sour tofu soup... a little boring and bland.... but cheap.

satay beef with string beans.. yummm.. but the beef didn't taste close to the real meat, but loooked like the real one

mongolian beef... not quite sure what this dish is supposed to tasted like... but it was yummy...

basil chicken... the basil taste was lighter than the traditional true chicken dish, but i liked how they had a lot of other mixed veggie in this dish. the sauce was dense and heavy though..

brown rice... always the healthy choice and they did not charge u more fro this. cool deal! this was free with lunch special 

egg rolls came with the lunch special, which ranged from 7.99 to 8.99. 

the house stir fry noodles........ SUPER YUMMY!!! best tasting dish compared to everything we ate today!!!

the cashier was super nice. we left $3 tip for to-go... not sure what the tipping policy is for to-go....

they would also give u validation if u eat there in the restaurant, u get 2 hr validation, which saves u $6 at the porthsmouth square parking plaza!!!

overall, do recommend this place to everyone, but next time, it may be a good idea to ask them to cut down the fast and the sauce to make all the dishes super healthy and skinny!

side note: the fake meat tasted good, but u could tell they are not "real meat."
author: Jennifer H.

description: The food comes out quickly and is abundant.  Great place to grab lunch if you're short on time and cash.  I've dined here alone, but would definitely bring friends if everyone's craving a meatless meal.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
The dr. and I wandered away from the the dregs of the Pride party last weekend in search of food.  After spending a couple of hours in the sun showing loving support for my gaggle of homos I was hungry, tired and hungry...and yeah, um, hungry.

I'm glad we went in the direction of Enjoy.  The North Beach/Chinatown area seemed sparse (except for the crowd outside of House of Nanking, which always always surprises me).  I needed some space.  Being able to freely walk down the sidewalk without bumping into a jockstrap was welcome.

The restaurant was fairly empty. A+, this meant food would be quick.
The menu was reeeeally extensive.  Crap.  This meant it would be hard to decide.

After what seemed like forever we decided on the "Beef" w/ Stringbeans and the Golden Knots.  Spring Rolls too, at my request since I wanted fried. 

I felt like I deserved some fried after doing well in the massive crowd at Civic Center.  I usually don't survive too long in those things.  Being 3 apples high, being in a crowd smells like armpit, you can't see the stage and inevitably someone will spill beer on you or try and steal your wallet.  

The "beef" was convincing without being too disturbingly close to the real thing.

The Golden Knots were different but good (think thin tofu sheet filled with tofu and veggies then wrapped up and shaped into a knot).  

Both dishes with brown rice and spring rolls came to a reasonably priced dinner and left me happy and recovered from the festivities.
author: Jen I.

description:
So I wish I could give this place a 3.5; it was pretty decent, but not enough that I think "Yay, I'm a fan." Well, not yet - I'm sure they'll have another opportunity to improve their score.

We ordered the lemon chicken, bean curd rolls, and fatty pork slices. Needless to say, it was an interesting experience. Lemon chicken was fried-wanna-be-chicken-half-moon-nuggets with a thick and clear sauce (..that's what she said?)  Bean curd rolls were pretty good, but I felt they could have been hotter, temperature wise. Fatty pork slices was crazy interesting to try, I'm undecided how I feel about it. 

Still not sure how I feel about the place aside from "OK" but the place was clean, and the service good. Worth a try.
author: Vicki L.

description: King pao chicken was da bomb. Veggie BBQ pork...not so much. Ma Po tofu was okay. Service was very quick and friendly.
author: T K.

description: Lunch special was good:brown rice, mild curry and an eggroll.  Big portion.  Place looks clean and is friendly enough.  Very big vegetarian menu.
author: Abigail J. M. M.

description:
I must say, I really did enjoy.
I love good vegetarian food and this place hits that mark.
The flavors were detailed and the portions were large.
I suggest trying their vegetarian lettuce wraps. 
There was a patron sitting next to us that was ranting and raving about the combination fried rice. I will try that next time.

The staff was incredibly attentive and grateful for our business.
One addition they could use is some music on a stereo. I enjoy the quietude of libraries but for a restaurant? It felt like the people 10 tables down from us could hear every word we shared. 

God forbid you have a verbal argument or disagreement with your significant other in here; the patrons will know your vegetarian story!
author: M E.

description:
I always enjoy Enjoy. I make it a point to come here whenever I'm in the Bay Area. I love their vegan Chinese food. Service is fast and friendly.

This location is nicer than the Kirkham Street branch, but they share a common menu. The wonton soup and mongolian beef are both good.
author: Derek M.

description: Just what I was looking for!  Simple meal at nice enough family restaurant.  Service was on point and food was fresh and delicious.  I had the bbq pork appetizer and entree of chicken and green vegetables. My stomach is smiling.
author: Rob Z.

description:
one star for the pot stickers 
one star for the clean bathrooms
one star for service.



***Food was not so great sorry. End of story.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Delicious!  
I am so please to find a yummy faux meat lunch spot.  Everything here is vegetarian.  Today was my first time at Enjoy and I will definitely go back.  I ordered a lunch special: fried chicken w/ lemon sauce (under $9)--includes the soup of the day (I had the corn chowder with tofu--Yum!), a veggie roll,  and rice (brown or white).  

I had take out, and it was very quick!  You may want to bring cash with you because they said today they were not accepting credit cards... maybe this happens often?  At any rate, don't let that discourage you from eating here.  I am very excited about Enjoy being my new lunch spot.  If you are vegetarian who likes faux meats--this is a great place for you!  
Service - speedy & friendly
Restaurant quality- minimal decor, clean & casual
Food quality - good
Parking - not sure, I walked.
author: emilie p.

description:
It's nice to have a vegetarian restaurant near Chinatown-FiDi. I've been here a couple of times. The service is good and the place is clean. The food is good but nothing to rant and rave about. Lots of faux meat options and the no-onion & garlic thing is interesting. 

Will I be back here? Absolutely. I'd say go here if you want a vegan meal if you are in the area as the options in North Beach/China Town/FiDi are limited. It's reasonably priced too.
author: saurabh S.

description:
I'm confused by all the high praise of this restaurant. Is this part of that Yelp scandal? I'm veg (and have been for 17 years)  and I found the food to be heavy and greasy. 

I had the sweet and sour chicken. I'm guessing it was made with gluten rather than soy, because it had the consistency of glue. I've had a lot better at many other places.
author: Kay H.

description:
Came here with family a couple weeks ago to try this place out. To my surprise, the food was really good! I didn't expect that from a vegetarian/vegan place.

All the food we ordered tasted just like it would if it were cooked with real meat. Their portions are decent sized and will keep you full.
 
Clean and neat restaurant, friendly wait service, good food...I'd come back again. They also have another location in the sunset area.
author: V M.

description:
The name is true.  I enjoyed it.
It's all vegetarian and there's lots of creative flavorful taste treats that I thought were really, really good.
Just based on the name of the dish, Fatty Sliced Pork, I order it.
It tasted great and looked like a slice of pork belly.  No, it wasn't really porky, but it's texture pleasing and flavorful.
And the other dish was: Coconut Sauce w/ Taro, Gluten Puff & Pumpkin.
Another wow, in my book.  Wow, because I'd never tried pumpkin with coconut sauce.  And it's good over rice.  Looks weird, tastes good.
I didn't miss the meat.  No beer or wine though, so party after or go here the next morning for some healthy rejuvenation.
And this place isn't nearly as weird as the last purely vegetarian place I went to called the Loving Hut, which has this freakish cult video playing in the background.
author: Kev M.

description: I'm not a connoisseur of veggie food - but was very impressed by the wide selection and flavorful food offered here.  We had the string beans beef (asked them to make it spicy) and it was delicious.  The house special fried rice with BBQ Pork & Veggie Ham was yum.  We couldn't get enough of the hot & sour soup.  All 3 dishes for under $25 and the portions were huge (enough for doggy bags)!  The restaurant is clean and the service was decent.  Will be back to try out their other dishes....
author: Bhavnak K.

description:
Very excited to find Enjoy!  Since Lu Lai in Milpitas closed in early 2008, I've been searching high and low for a place that can do the veggie version of walnut prawns that taste like crack (just need ... one more ... hit...).  And until now, I've been sorely disappointed.  Then I came across Enjoy's...   FIRE UP THE PIPE BABY.  The only problem is that it comes with a $13.50 price tag, which is almost double the rest of their dishes.  Which I guess is a good thing, 'cos I don't *really* need to be eating mayonnaise sauce on fried goodness with any sort of regularity.

Their other stuff is good too.  Also had a really fresh bitter-melon and beef with black bean sauce (their beef is better than most -- it's made of tofu skin, rather than textured soy protein).

I'll be visiting this place regularly, since I'm often staying at the Hilton across the street.
author: Vince T.

description:
Since my favorite vegetarian snack place was driven out of business by Quickly's...this is the 2nd best, even though I can't get to it as often as I would want to. (I'm also not vegetarian)

I enjoyed the selection they had, everything was lip licking good. I'm actually getting hungry thinking of the food again. Although if you're a usual omnivore this might be a bit light for your stomach, we had to eat a lot of food before we felt full. The fake chicken drumsticks are cute tiny things but were not filling and it didn't fulfill it's value.

Compared to it's other location, this had a lot of variety, seating was a bit hectic, there was always someone waiting to be seated. (possibly because there was a big meeting of old women in the connected room who were just chillin')  no free dessert either... but still good over all.
author: Kimberly S.

description: Great lunch menu, interesting choices. Took a non vegetarian here and he was pleasantly surprised by the variety and low price. Great service as well.
author: Amy D.

description: I've been to the Inner Sunset location and I like this one much more. I'm not a vegetarian, but my husband is, so we were happy to learn of a location closer to where we live. I really enjoy the food here. It isn't greasy like other Chinese restaurants, and they have a very wide selection of items.  I especially like the twice cook pork, which is spicy (although not too spicy). I also like their noodle soups. Their lunch specials are a really good deal and the portions are large.
author: Natalie S.

description: Fine, good, excellent food. I really enjoyed the food, but I think the absence of any garlic made it less memorable. *I love garlic.* I definitely recommend a visit.
author: Tracy H.

description:
Home from work late last night and HUNGRY!  Decided to call for take out from Enjoy...I had my choices all picked out from the menu, but when I called to order, the waitress convinced me out of 2/3 of my choices and into her recommendations, then told me it would be ready in 10.

Sent S.B. on his way to pick up our grub, he was back in a flash.  When he came back, he said the waitress told him a joke while he was there - he asked her what kind of hot sauce was she giving him...Her answer - vegetarian!  Then she proceeded to laugh at her own joke.  Sweet!

Here is what we ordered:

1. Eggplant w/ Sea Bass - (recommended) hmmm, not so much, the Sea Bass had the texture of fish, but the weird part about it was that they imbued it with a fishy smell as well...I don't like fishy smelling fish, which makes it safe to conclude that I wouldn't enjoy fish smelling fake fish.  Plus the whole dish was drenched in way too much oil.
2. "Bai Ying" Mushroom w/ Yam Leaves (recommended) - not too salty, simple and delicious, I would order this again.
3. Mustard Green Veggie Pork Fried Rice Cake (my pick) - My fave!  Next time I'll order just this and some veggies.  Rice cake (chewy, check!), preserved mustard greens (great flavor, check!), fake ham (smoky flavor, check!), goodness all around (check!).

Only problem, 30 minutes after stuffing myself silly, I was fully digested and hungry again.  Ah, such is the life of a veggie...
author: Burrito M.

description: I am a big fan of lunch specials and part-time vegetarian so it's natural that I like this place. The portions are hearty while staying away from meat is good for the heart. While many people have mixed feeling over soy based "meat," I'm a huge fan. My favs here at the King Pao "chicken" and the Mongolian "beef." Service is fast and professional as well.
author: Jones E.

description: I am not a vegetarian but went there for a friend.  They had fake meat flavored dishes.  Oh boy, I did not enjoy that at all.  I would just order vegetarian dish and none of fake meat dish.  Especially sea cucumber dish, yikes!
author: K L.

description:
Don't bring that slab of roast pork and roast duck you just bought on Stockton Street into this place.  This is a vegan restaurant that follows Buddhist principles, so they may politely ask you to leave.  This also explains why garlic and onions are not used, as they are plants that would die when harvested.  The eggplant with sea bass is amazing, with seaweed wrapped seitan that even looks like the real thing.  Close your eyes when you eat it, and your brain will tell you that you are eating fish. The bean curd rolls with bok choy are flavorful.  Other favorites, the House Special Fried Rice and Beef Stew in clay pot.
I think I could almost be a convert if I were able to eat this every day.
author: Arlene C.

description: 3.5 stars. We ordered lunch specials, mapo tofu, veggie with vermicelli and something else. The food was decent, but not outstanding. I'd go back and try different stuff.
author: Yoko S.

description:
My vegetarian friends have been trying to get me to this restaurant for quite some time.  Since I'm not vegetarian, I've resisted until a couple of weekends ago.  I'm so glad they didn't give up on me.  This restaurant was wonderful!

The first thing I noticed was how clean and modern the restaurant looked!  Next, I was delightfully shocked to see they don't use garlic, onions or MSG in their food.  I'm not a big fan of those ingredient and this was the first restaurant that I've ever been to that doesn't use garlic or onions.

Then I worried, would the food be any good?  I LOVED our dishes!

We had several dishes starting with the Salt & Pepper Fried Squid.  Tasted just like sliced calamari.  We then had the lettuce wraps with a mushroom, veggie chicken, vegetables and pine nut filling.  This dish is a favorite of my friends and now I know why!  Nice large leafs of fresh lettuce, some hoisin sauce, and plenty of the filling (which they give you a HUGE portion) - so refreshing!

We also had the walnut prawns.  The imitation prawns almosted tasted like the real thing but something was not quite.  However, the dish was still tasty.

The tomato beef chow mein was fabulous!  The slices of imitation beef looked and tasted like the real thing.  The best part is that the restaurant did not use any bell peppers and onions like you'll usually find at other restaurants as a filler.

We also had the sliced fatty pork with sweet mustard greens  and napa cabbage.  Pretty good!  I'm not quite sure what the imitation slice fatty pork tasted similiar to in a regular Chinese restaurant.  Not quite like chao siu (not as sweet).

My favorite dish of the evening was the bean curd rolls stuffed with mushrooms and cabbage.  They put the generous serving of the rolls in the center of the platter then surround with fresh baby bok choy.  One of my favorite dishes when I go for dim sum, this veggie substitute tasted just as good.

Finally, the waitresses couldn't be any friendlier!  We stayed until closing and they didn't rush us at all, but kept stopping by to tell us about the dishes and other items on the menu.  They then surprised us with a complimentary dessert which was freshly cooked and amazing!

Oh!  I also have to really point out the portions were so generous!  We ended up with so much food to bring home.

In all, I'm so happy to have been introduced to Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant.  I can now have Chinese food without any concerns about eating healthy!  Now to try Enjoy's Kirkham Street location.
author: Keefe C.

description:
Not the best vegetarian/vegan Chinese joint in the city.  In my opinion Golden Era and Loving Hut are much better.

The dishes here are almost all vegan, with no onion, garlic, MSG, or flavor.

I didn't dislike anything I got, but I didn't love any of it either.

Update: I got the Mongolian Beef lunch special for my second visit and it was nice and spicy, the egg-less roll was great, and the soup was OK too.  

The service was really fast, and the place is really clean, but if you want great vegan food in north beach, walk 3 more blocks north and hit up Loving Hut.
author: shannon d.

description: Vegetarian Restaurant with all types of meat flavors. Not pricey. It's a must try and a fun experience.
author: Pan P.

description: This was my first experience with a fully vegeterian menu and initially I was a little reluctant.  I was short on time with an important presentation due the next morning so I needed something light but fast.  Eventhough my diet primarily consists of vegitable, beens, fish and rice the host saw my hesitance in ordering and encourage me to try it.  Wow! I have to say it was fantastic.  I had the soybean fried chicken (appetizer) and singapore noodle (main dish) and was pleasantly surprise.  I followed up the next night for dinner and was just as happy with my meal.
author: Oscar L.

description: We eat here so often. We really enjoy it. Prices aren't too bad. I should mention that we aren't even vegetarian. The food can be sometimes a bit oily but it doesn't bother me. Love the house special fried rice. Yum!
author: Cynthia L.

description: Just thinking about the RIDICULOUS walnut "shrimp" I had at Enjoy makes me want to hop a plane and show up in time for dinner. I have never had better shrimp, real or fake, in my life- and having been a vegetarian for not too long, but a while now, I know how unsatisfying some mock shrimp can be. The vegetarian salmon sashimi was amazing. Spongy, not quite spot on texture- wise, but definitely satisfying as well. I went twice in two days, and while there were items I wouldn't order again, it's not because they weren't good- just less amazing. I could drop loads of money here and be very content.
author: E P.

description: Really good food.  Mostly vegan.  The menu is incredibly long so definitely look through the Yelp reviews for ones to try.  I really liked #90 bean curd rolls and bok choy, the lemon chicken, and the combo platter.  My friend had wonton soup which was also good.  I got a vegan thai iced tea and their hot tea was also good.  My other friend got prawns with cashews which was a little on the bland side.  All in all, I really liked it and want to go back to try some of the other 95 items on the menu.  Update: I now work nearby and have gone many more items.  My recent faves are pie pa tofu balls and golden knot.  Their lunch special is an unbeatable deal at $7.50 for soup, spring roll, and entree with brown rice.  I highly recommend it.
author: Bill D.

description: food is still unevenly brought to table and sauces just plain yuck!  Why do my office mates still insist on going there?  I'd rather lick the sidewalk!
author: Greg R.

description: It's alright.  I've had better vegetarian.  Hot and Sour a little bit too sour.  Egg rolls okay.  $7.50 lunch special.  Wifey ordered the Curry Chicken Fried Rice and I had the Mongolian Beef with brown rice.  Okay.  Here's the deal.  I know it's veggie meat, but--Where's the Beef?  There was so much carrot and squash in the Mongolian Beef dish, but not enough "fake" beef.  Jeez!  Where's the beef.  Otherwise, the place was packed and the food came fast and was hot.  Tasted good, but not the best veggie I've had.  I'll try again another day and report back.
author: Andy L.

description:
I am rather disappointed by the quality of food. We ordered three different dishes of varied styles, but none of it really turned out well. 

The lettuce dish was watery and without much flavor (supposedly spicy with a some flavor of the preserved tofu). The walnut shrimp dish was okay, but the texture was a bit off. The clay pot dish was supposedly the best, but it was a bit dishonest that they stuffed half of the clay pot with lettuce. I would go to Golden Era for vegetarian food, which was good consistently in my every single visit. 

They also remodeled the place. The ambiance is fine, but the food quality is just not there yet...
author: Kai L.

description:
I've had dinner and lunch here with different people including two kids and they all love the food.  
The restaurant is clean and neat and service is terrific.  
Price is great,  lunch special $7.50 includes main course,  egg rolls and soup.  This is a deal to shout about!!

My lunch today.... BBQ pork and Veggie Ham friend rice.......Yummy.
author: Jeni F.

description: It's vegetarian, has menu variety, and Chinese. Decent atmosphere and food.
author: Joyce L.

description: Food that tastes like meat but it's vegetarian! I definitely suggest getting a few different dishes with your friends and do it family style. You can try various dishes. I ordered the thai style noodle soup last time I was here. I am not a fan of that.
author: Forest T.

description: The soy fried chicken legs are tasty here and the texture of the soy beef is great. I wish the had more small plate dishes. We stopped in for lunch and its always hard to have big dishes and rice for lunch for two people. Pretty good food though.
author: Timothy L.

description: Great selection of vegetarian and vegan Chinese food in a nice setting. Not a dive in any respect, it's clean and well kept.  I've never seen so much vegetarian/vegan food at a restaurant before. This place specializes in "mock" meats so it looks almost like th real thing down to the texture, but it's all vegetables! if you're allergic/abstain from soy and/or gluten, you can substitute and they tell what's in the "mock" meats, so you can choose something else.
author: Flynt I.

description:
Have to say, went in with low expectations and were impressed.  We don't love Chinese but keep thinking we should eat it since this is the largest China town in the world, outside of China.

They did a great job with the food and were friendly.  Good prices, we will be back.
author: michael d.

description: it's not meat. it has maybe 65% of the flavor of meat. and it's not entirely vegetarian tasting. the eumami is just way off.
author: Anu K.

description:
Cute little yellow-painted restaurant just outside Chinatown. I've been here a couple times, and I remember liking it more when I was here last year. My most recent visit, I ordered the tri-spice 'chicken' in a clay pot. During my first few bites, my impression was more 'this tastes strange' than 'this is amazing', and I don't stray from faux meats (I have an addiction to whole foods' soy popcorn 'chicken'). The taste grew on me, though, and I can definitely say the meal was enjoyable. I ordered brown rice instead of white, for which I believe there was a small charge, but it's always nice to have that option. My boyfriend, an omnivore whom I recently converted to tofu by cooking it for him, ordered the kung pao tofu and wasn't much of a fan. He said it was 'too soft'. Whatever. He's basically the opposite of a tofu expert. But it's tough to say that Enjoy is a great place to convert a staunch omnivore.

My favorite part of the restaurant is the bright yellow decor. It's a cheery place that's perfect for lunch.
author: Holly U.

description: This place has great food, at a great price. First, the menu is huge and all vegetarian/vegan, there is no MSG and guess what... the food tastes great. We have been here many times and the staff goes out of there way for the customers. We ordered here at closing time and they went out of there way to stay open and make our take out order. If you go you I strongly recommend the lettuce wraps and dumplings. The chow mein and curry is also a standard order.
author: Marc C.

description: Best vegetarian chinese food I've had both on the east and west coast. The texture of the fatty pork is really well imitated. The food was not greasy, and yet flavorful. I would definitely go back there again next time I'm in town. ^.^ yummmm....
author: Weili Z.

description: Service was fast and food was cheap. Food was not prepared fresh, they were out of brown rice, and waitresses were unfriendly. Food was not very good, probably would taste better if prepared fresh. Would not go here again.
author: Becky A.

description: Did not like it. All tofu all day - meat-flavored tofu (not my idea of vegan).  Thick gravy-like sauce (too thick).  unappetizing
author: Doc G.

description:
The food was great!  My party ordered 3 lunch specials which included:

1.  Satay sauce with eggplant, tofu, and basil
2.  String beans and mock beef with Chinese satay sauce
3.  Coconut sauce with taro, gluten puff, and pumpkin

All of the dishes were very flavorful.  These lunch specials included an egg roll, soup of the day, and your choice of brown rice or white rice.  This is definitely a wonderful place for vegetarian dishes!
author: Yan M.

description: Went by here by accident with my daughter-in-law and grand daughter.  Very nice and tasty,  the black bean chicken satay was the best and the combo rice.  we'll be back.
author: pochini m.

description: I love this place. It is in walking distance from my house. The waitresses are very nice and can help answer any questions of substitutions you may have. I wish they would use a higher quality rice cake in their shanghai rice cake dish ( one of my faves) but the rice cake falls apart and gets gross if you take leftovers home. I love the lemon chicken and their fried rice is pretty good for not having egg. Some dishes can be bland because they do not use garlic or onions because of some buddhist reason I cannot remember sorry! I am a regular here and I wanna try Lucky Creation on washington st. but they have weird hours so this place always wins my wallet love.
author: Courtney M.

description: Enjoy I did! ***LUV*** this vegetarian restaurant. So happy this location opened up here in downtown, (was going to the one in the Sunset). This place blows any other vegetarian restaurant outta the water, (I'm talkin' to you Greens! You and your mediocre, sub par overly-priced food, with a small selection of choices to match). The amount of choices on the Enjoy menu can be overwhelming, and the resemblance to real meat is uncanny. Gotta try the chicken lettuce wrap! D*Lish.  For 2 ppl, the lettuce wrap, and an entree were more than enough. Portions are beyond substantial. Service is fantastic. Our waitress was so nice, and went into depth about the type of tofu used in each dish, (a special type of tofu from Taiwan). Come starving, and roll yourself out. Can't wait to go back! Waitress told me to come back for lunch. Only $7.95 for a main dish with tons of sides.
author: Rebecca S.

description: I've  never been a fan of Chinese food.  I am now!  The portions were huge.  So delicious.  They know how to cook!  I'm back to eating Chinese again.  Super affordable, too!
author: jennifer s.

description: We loved everything we had here -- chicken and black bean sauce, soy sauce chicken, and sautéed pea shoots.  Excellent vegan Cantonese cooking and friendly service. We will be back the next time we are in town.
author: Christi W.

description: Tasty, healthy food at a good price. Friendly staff, restaurant is very clean and nice. Highly recommended.
author: Dapper C.

description: I am very impressed with the variety of veggie dishes.  The place also is very clean.  Love the fried curry dumpling.
author: Cynthia Y.

description: I really enjoyed Enjoy.  Since becoming a vegetarian (jeez, 17 years ago) I have sat through many Chinese banquets waiting for the 8th or 9th course where the veggies and mushroom dish comes out.  But my exile from the food of my people has ended!  There were 6 of us (well really 5 1/2 but we're good eaters!) so we were able to get the banquet menu.  I wouldn't say any one dish blew me away but it was a delicious satisfying feast of a meal!  I'm a fan!
author: Linda L.

description:
i think me and my friend caught this place on a bad day or this is the first time yelpers have deceived me. my friend is vegan so i yelped for a place where we would both enjoy the food. 

we got a lot of food. we started off with the small combo platter, got the kung pao "chicken", braised "pork ribs" & house special fried rice. BLAND!!!! EXCRUCIATINGLY BLAND!!!!!! we had to add salt to EVERYTHING. it took them 20 min to give us 3 tiny, flavorless cabbage filled spring rolls. the waitress even spilled my friend's thai iced tea drink on the table. the spilled drink was the least of our concerns. oh and i forgot to mention that it tasted like water with thai iced tea mix and sugar mixed into it. terrible. 

we spent almost $50 on a mediocre meal, at best. we had such high hopes because they had such a huge selection.  

we ended up giving a measly $6 tip and to be honest, we were being generous. 

i am hoping and praying we caught them on a bad day because i plan to come back so this place can redeem itself. I HOPE.
author: Alyssa L.

description: I seriously can't believe this isn't meat! It's been years since I've had sweet and sour chicken, but this is hands down the best I've ever had! Really good prices, and absolutely delicious!
author: AlwaysHonest R.

description: Great Cantonese vegetarian food, friendly and fast service, lots of variety on the menu, reasonable prices (especially their lunch special!).  The food here tastes very fresh and the natural flavors of the vegetables come through, not overly flavored.  Dishes can be a bit too saucy, however even my meat-eater friends said they liked it and would come again.  Brought my mom here for mother's day!
author: Teresa C.

description: So i guess the best vegetarian chinese restaurant ever has expanded to a new location on the outskirts of chinatown. I think this location is a little nicer and has more modern decor vs the one in the sunset. My friend and I got the beef spareribs and vegetable chicken dishes along with bowls of white and brown rice. The beef and chicken tasted almost like the real thing as the texture and flavor are very close to real meat.This place is an excellent place for people who want to lower cholesterol or want to go on a diet since the food tastes good and is healthy for you. The prices are on par to any regular chinese restaurant and this place also has lunch specials. If a vegetarian was coming to town, i would bring them here or to the one on kirkham for sure as I would enjoy eating vegetarian with them. They accept visa and mastercard
author: Robert Y.

description: I don't want to eat meat, but it's so delicious. Now I can have all my favorite Chinese dishes sans my cute fuzzy and feathered friends! We need one in San Diego!
author: Mindy R.

description: Started with the BBQ Pork, nice flavor, but a bit too soggy/squishy. Chow Mein had about 5x the bean sprouts as noodles. Veggie tri-spice chicken was tasty, most flavorful dish we had. Lemon chicken had a thick coating of lemon slime (not appealing). Overall, the food could have used more flavor/spices. Very bright inside, lacking in ambiance.  Not sure I would return as there are many better options for veg cuisine in the area.
author: Dana P.

description: Went here for lunch today.  Dishes tried, fried tofu balls with broccoli and curried tofu with vegetables.  Both were excellent, large portions and fairly priced.  Nice clean restaurant with pleasant efficient staff.  Are you an angry and bitter person? Part of the cure might be coming to Enjoy as the light meal, free of msg, and other nasty ingredients will make you feel so much happier!  I can't wait to go back!
author: Ron T.

description: They draw you in with their cheap lunch special but then don't have any of it left.  That was annoying but still loved the vegies and fake chicken
author: Briana B.

description:
Menu: extensive and enticing!
Service: very friendly and fast... you won't have to wait long!
Lunch Specials: come with tasty soup and great veggie spring rolls for less than $8
Atmosphere: clean, elegant, but not stuffy

My bf and I wondered past Chinatown and didn't want to walk back up the hills to go to Loving Hut (where we really had wanted to eat) so when we came across Enjoy Vegetarian and read the menu on the window we thought it would be a safe bet.   I had vegetarian chicken in lemon sauce and ate every last bit of it AND my soup AND my spring roll!  he had broccoli beef and said it was really good.  I can't comment on it since I'm not a big fan of faux beef :\ but I'm a huge fan of faux chicken!

I would definitely eat here again and am excited to take friends and family into the city with me sometime just to try it
author: Angie M.

description: There are some really great dishes here. I actually had to ask the server if everything really is vegetarian, because items like prawns and sea slugs sound a little questionable! The wait staff is really helpful though, they gave each of us recommendations and tried to make sure we'd like what we were ordering. All the prices are very reasonable and I would have no problem taking a date here.
author: Tim R.

description: It was a good lunch special at $7.50. Inside of the restaurant was clean and staff was nice. I did not try any "fake" meat menu, so I do not know how good they are. I will go back there and try some more. I have some bad experience with Chinese restaurant in China town but this one is pretty good I must say!!
author: Daisy A.

description: Alas! A Chinese Vegetarian Restaurant that I have no reservation about giving 5 Stars to! We had a dinner party of seven (7), we decided to order the 7 Course  Prix Fixe Dinner for $68. The portions were very generous, even had left overs. The wait staff was very attentive, the dining area was spotless. Each dish had its own individual flavor-not like some restaurants that uses the same sauce with different dishes but they all taste the same because of the same boring soy sauce and corn starch concoction. The dinner started with Hot and Sour Soup, then moved on to fresh steamed pot-stickers; vegetarian minced oyster chili w/fresh crispy lettuce cups for wrapping the chili (a favorite new years banquet dish); basil w/stir fried Japanese eggplant; taro root, pumpkin w/curry sauce; stir fried tofu w/brocollini; Chinese "Dirty Rice" w/spinach, chives, and pine nuts-All MSG Free! The thing that cinched the 5th Star was the immaculate restroom (A rarity in many Chinese restaruants)! Oh, I almost for got the 2 hr. parking validation at the nearby Portsmouth Parking Garage. I plan to be a steady customer at Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant.
author: Kailey W.

description: Definitely one of the best-kept secrets in FiDi. It's a low-maintenance restaurant for sure--no fanfare, no crazy ambiance, and the waitstaff, while efficient and attentive, will not fawn over you (as is also the norm for pretty much everywhere in China town). I actually discovered this place on yelp when I needed to find good veggie take-out for a friend I wanted to bring dinner to. So glad I did--their food is awesome!! The lunch special is a very reasonable deal, and the sweet corn-tofu soup that comes with is super yummy--great for those colder city days. Don't miss anything with fried tofu; I heartily recommend the tofu chow mein--the noodles are also VERY tasty. Basically you get a TON of good food for an extremely low price (especially in THIS city).
author: Kaitlyn L.

description: I had been a regular at  Lucky Creation, and then switched to Loving Hut when they opened.  Let me just say that Enjoy blows both of  them out of the water!   They have such a huge selection of dishes, and I've only had one so far that was just ok.  Everything from the lettuce cups to the walnut prawns, to the chow mein, and the sweet and sour chicken, oh and the PEPPER STEAK!  That dish was amazing!  The food is so fresh, and prepared with care.  Oh my god, I forgot about the calamari appetizer.  A must try!  The value is great and they even do a lunch special for $7.50. You get soup, eggroll and an entree.  Unbelievable!  Enjoy has won me over with their amazing food and good service.  I'm so happy to see that they are doing well....
author: Jocelyn C.

description: The service is wonderful. The joint is ultra clean and spacious (for a Chinese restaurant).  I had the Spicy Ma Po Tofu lunch special. It wasn't all that spicy although the serving was more than generous.  As part of the lunch special, you are giving a choice of a side of white or brown rice as well as a soup and an veggie egg roll. All that for around $7.00. This is definitely not the best ma po tofu I had but I will definitely come back to try the other items that are on the regular menu.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Lovely atmosphere! Love the variety on the menu! We ordered the Enoki, Dried Mushroom & Bamboo Pith w/ Soft Tofu, and some kind of tofu skin hot pot with napa cabbage and taro. It was on the edge of being bland, but otherwise very refreshing and healthy-feeling. This is the place for faux meat dishes for vegetarians!
author: Jenn C.

description: Excellent Chinese vegetarian. Fast, cheap, great quality, good service. Looking forward to return on a weekly basis....
author: L S.

description: I thought this restaurant was AMAZING!!! It tasted like the real thing!!! The salt/pepper calamari was delicious along with the green beans, and lotus root dish I ordered! The only draw back was that it was super cold in the restaurant.
author: A G.

description: Very tasty vegetarian restaurant. My husband is a meat eater and we come here often since I brought home a take-out dish from here. The taste is good and mild. Not too strong as many Chinese restaurants do. What I like the best is it stays very clean. Sometimes some restaurants look and feel not as clean after some months or years since they were opened but every time we come to Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant, it's always very clean.
author: V L.

description: I ordered the sweet n sour chicken and beef and broccoli. The sweet and sour was smothered in sauce and had more pineapple chunks that fake meat. I beef and broccoli was not memorable either. Both portions were super small for the price you pay. Also the waitress is very rude and seems like she's pist off about something. If you want good quality vegan chinese food go to GOLDEN ERA! TEN TIMES BETTER AND BETTER CUSTOMER SERVICE!!!
author: Josie M.

description:
I admit, I'm not vegetarian.  But I do enjoy vegetarian "meats" from time to time.  

While the food is far from terrible here, my overall experience was notably lackluster.  Possibly due to the fact that it was the Grand Opening week, the food took longer than expected to arrive.  This was evidenced by the fact that the waitress had to apologize to both myself and the woman next to me for the order taking so long.  

I had ventured there during lunch, and their lunch menu, for a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown had a pretty slim one-page menu, featured fake meat dishes such as Kung Pao chicken.   From what I could remember, the "meat" dishes were not stated explicitly as vegetarian, so I ordered the above stated, and assumed it was vegetarian.  I wasn't sure though.

The fake meat was tasty, and the vegetables were moderately fresh.  Possibly a hint of MSG...

The service was poor.  They seemed more intent on drawing customers in rather than focusing on the customers in the store.  My dish was $8, not particularly bad for the adequate serving size.  Nonetheless, they accept only cash, and when I placed my ten dollar note, I was surprised that they didn't bring back any change or a verbal "thank you."  I knew immediately I would never come back.
author: James D.

description: I came here for lunch one day when I worked downtown over the summer.  It was good - I can see how it would be an awesome place for vegetarians, especially ones who are in denial and actually like meat-like things.  It's one of those weird Chinese vegetarian places where words "chicken" and "beef" still appear on the menu.  I'm not quite sure how they differ - maybe it means "tan gluten product" and "brown gluten product"...  Anyways, I digress.  The food is decent and cheap - wouldn't mind going there again.
author: Fontane L.

description: My favorite thing to order is their pine nut & spinach fried rice. 1) Simple ingredients yet it's so packed with flavor! 2) Filling portions. It tastes even better if you substitute the usual white rice with brown rice. Just ask.
author: Alex N.

description: I ordered Lunch Special #4: "Coconut sauce w/Taro, Gluten Puff & Pumpkin". The price was $7.50 and included brown rice, a bowl of sweetcorn soup, and a spring roll. A complimentary pot of green tea was also served. The meal was delicious and filling,  and my waitress was quick and kind. I left very satisfied.
author: J t.

description: It is super hard to find a Buddhist vegetarian restaurant anywhere in the USA. This is one. Yay! I can eat almost anything on the menu! That alone gives Enjoy Vegetarian a big thumbs up from me! But wait, there's more! The food is varied and good too!  Can't say I've seen a lot of menus with lotus root on it (which I love) I've only gone once so far, but you can be sure I'll be going again, and again, and again so I can be sure to try all the things I'd like to try on the menu
author: Sylvia B.

description:
best chinese veggie place in town!  the place is clean, and tastefully decorated (love the large slate color ceramic tile floor contrasting the mango-y wall color).  because the veggie scene in the city is so limited, and i can only take so many tempah or beans, i go there at least once a month to satisfy my asian taste buds.

my fav appetizers are the "Combination Platter" (a real chinese veggie must-have that is hard to find in the city), and "Fragrant Crispy Chicken".  fanstastic selection of entree (almost too many).  the "salty fish and chicken bits fried rice" is very light yet tasty.  they have a wide variety of greens as well, for those who are skeptical of faux meat.  my recommendation aside from the usual bok choi is ""Bai Ying" Mushroom w/ Yam Leaves".  

some people may find their food a little too bland, which i was surprised by my very first visit in their original restaurant out in Sunset.  but i'd rather have my food too bland and add my own seasoning then too salty or sweet, then there's really nothing i can do!

we love the staff.  very friendly and knowledgable.  they have 2 parking spaces reserved from 7-11p, tho often taken, you can park at the CTown u/g garage, and they'll validate your parking (i think only $3 for the whole stay).

also, $1.90 bubble drinks (add 50c for explosive bubbles, lychee bits).  what a deal!  overall the price is reasonable.  i'm an advocate for good hearty chinese food and not stereotype them all as cheap.
author: D M.

description: I haven't had better vegetarian Chinese food in San Francisco. Prices are a little high, but I can understand why. They put thought and consistency in their food. Selection is outstanding. Check out the medicinal soup! Good and good for you.
author: André C.

description: Wasn't feeling on top of it today while on my walking tour. I wandered around Chinatown/North Beach not really wanting just anything. Then I found Enjoy and am now thankful I ate there. No meat, garlic, onion or MSG..just great gluten-soy products blended together is a tasty, healthful way. I ordered the Reishi,Supremen Mushroom Medicine Soup which reminded me a little of a beef broth with mushrooms. And I felt better afterwards too. Also had the Braised Bean Curd with Baby Bok Choi and Mushrooms..that and hot tea. A very filling, healing meal. And it was only $20 and change. Nice place to recharge before you continue your journey!
author: michael s.

description: We found this place via yelp while visiting San Francisco. Being vegetarian we are always on the look out for veg friendly places and we were not disappointed with this one. We are not always big fans of fake meat, but we enjoyed everything we ordered. A dish with gluten, tofu and greens was delicious, even my two year old loved it. The eggplant and chilli dish was also delish and the eggplant was cooked perfectly. The restaurants was not busy and the service was pleasant and helpful, they were willing to give some recommendations which I liked. They are kid friendly and my two year old was happy with his special plastic plate and fork.
author: Nim S.

description: Yummy Chinese Vegetarian Food!!! I was excited when they opened their second location in Chinatown because it would be just close enough for me to go for lunch. I love going there for the lunch special which includes soup, egg roll, entree, and rice. It's a great value for a wonderful vegan meal which is also really delicious. I've brought co-workers, friends, and family here and everybody has really enjoyed it. The people there are also very friendly. They noticed that I was a regular so they greet me by name now each time I go there : )
author: Lisa M.

description:
This place is very creative for a vegetarian restaurant.  They have a huge selection of popular chinese meat dishes but in a vegetarian version with fake meat that taste pretty good.

I love their bai ling mushrooms and smooth silky tofu.

It's a bit over priced and can use a little more taste or salt on their dishes.

A plus that they take credit cards and the waitress lady is super nice.
author: Kate L.

description:
everything is veggie but it's low quality. the tofu chicken has an unpleasant texture reminiscent of meat. the entire reason i went veggie was to avoid the meat texture. if you're in to tough and flavorless fake meat, then go ahead and eat here.

the only redeeming quality is that they use no msg and no garlic, a rare find in chinatown.
author: Lizzie O.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  I moved to Germany a year ago, but I came back to SF last month to visit.  I told me parents that I need to pig out on some good Chinese food (the Chinese food in Germany sucks!) and to my delightment, I found out that Enjoy just opened in Chinatown.  I love how convenient the new location is.

The decor is really nice and sleek.  The staff speaks English as well as Cantonese (and probably other Chinese dialetcts too).  They were also very nice and offered my mother and I ice water because it was a very hot day.

The food is delicious, and fairly priced.  They offer a huge variety of Chinese dishes, more than most vegetarian Asian restaurants (such as Golden Era or Shangri-La).  The best part?  Vegan Thai Ice Tea!
author: Jolene L.

description: Had delicious vegetarian food to go. Try the hot and sour soup. The veggie deluxe noodles were also fantastic!
author: Maria G.

description:
Fast, friendly service, good food. Ok, I can barely understand the chinese order taker, but that's ok, we've managed to get around that... :)
I've had the spicy Ma Po Tofu, which was good, but its only for people who really, really like tofu... there was a lot of it. 
I just had the Veggie Tri-Spice Chicken with Napa Cabbage & Basil, and it was delicious! Strong basil, and very real-tasting fake chicken... I'm not usually a fan of fake meats, but this was good. Will definitely be back to try the other items on the menu.
author: M L.

description:
Veggie fried rice, bean curd pocket and vegetables, drumsticks. The service was top notch and the veggie fried rice was excellent, some of the best I've ever had. They put in fake meat cubes and peas and carrot squares. The bean curd pocket and vegetables was OK - a little bland and not good once it cooled off. Drumsticks were standard. I've been to the one in the avenues and it seems like they have the same menu. 

You have to be careful with this place since they don't use garlic or onion. If you order something that's not fried or spicy it will probably be really bland.
author: Sarah J.

description: After seeing the long lines at R&G and the House of Nanking (and having read the reviews of both, which had plenty of good reviews but also some not so good ones) we walked right into this place and were seated right away. Super friendly wait staff served us tea as we sat down. We shared all our dishes: dumplings, vegetable rolls, spicy eggplant and Kung pao tofu. We all (that includes our two kids) loved all the dishes. A nice veggie find.
author: Bill S.

description: I am so happy that this Sunset restaurant has a branch down here in the financial district.  The food is very healthy, NO MSG.  Before the only other choice is Lucky Creations on Washington Street.  The food may have a little more flavor than Enjoy Vegetarian, but after lunch, I was thirsty as hell.  Compared to Lucky Creations, the new place here is much cleaner, and the service is 100% better.  Those two ladies at Lucky were really mean and nasty.  Thank you Enjoy Vegetarian for providing a better lunch option in the FiDi.
author: susan g.

description: Excellent food. Exceptional service. A pleasant find. The 15% Yelp coupon is an added bonus. Overall, great food for vegetarians. Would highly recommend it. A+!
author: Sachin T.

description: Had to go to the Transamerica building for a meeting and Yelped "Vegan" and the closest place was here.  There were many choices on the menu and since I'm not much of a fake meat eater I went for the Veggie Deluxe which comes with napa Cabbage, mushroom, fungus, broccoli, baby corn.  They told me it was not spicy so I asked to modify with adding chilies.  The wait staff seemed very quick during lunch which I was happy about since parking around here is insane..Anyway my first thought was the brown rice bowl of was tiny and it kind of was.  The main dish was plenty and I was impressed with the two types of mushrooms which were unique and fresh tasting.  I also thought the baby corn was really fresh tasting vs. many times they taste like from a can.  It really wasn't spicy like I wanted but I guess I kind of figured that out when I saw they don't use any garlic and such.  Anyway it had this really original sesame "Chinatown" taste which I guess I can't really describe but I really liked it.  The service was very quick and I even got to pay right after they delivered the dish.  Lunch special comes to about $10 with tip which for SF standards is probably good. Overall I'm a fan and would recommend this if you are in the area.
author: Ron K.

description: The lunch specials are very well-priced at $7.50 for a main dish, eggroll, and rice (including brown rice), and soup. I'm a vegan, and I enjoyed the fake-meat dish that I ordered, but meat-eaters at the table were not impressed -- I suppose the rule is that if you've liked fake meat products before, you'll also like these ones, but they won't change your mind about anything. All in all, I'd say the food was just decent. Nothing was wrong with it, but nothing was really special about it. They claim to use no garlic or onions, which I suppose is a plus to some, but I found myself really missing garlic and MSG! I think in their effort to be really health-conscious and agreeable, they didn't do the vegetables as well as meat-serving Chinese restaurants do when they really go all-out with the seasonings. Service was good, tables were available even at peak lunch hour. Exploding boba were like... a car crash in my mouth. I wasn't sure if I liked the experience, but it was so morbidly fascinating that I couldn't stop doing it to myself over and over again. All in all, I'd recommend it for a visit, but I'm not likely to become a regular.
author: Kendall M.

description: The service was very friendly, the food was good. We loved the lettuce wraps! I would next time choose dishes based on sauce type, I think that's the trick. Will def go back.
author: bhavna p.

description: So good. Loved my dish of string beans and dried tofu. Clean restaurant with great staff and extremely tasty food.
author: Lauren S.

description: This place is awesome, although I much prefer the ambiance of their location in the Sunset (Kirkham at 11th or 12th) over the one in the financial district. There is a lot to choose from on the menu... it takes awhile to decide what you want. My friend got a "fatty pork" dish, which sounds gross but it was actually quite tasty and the way that they created the tofu was rather clever. It was shiny tofu most of the way down but the very end was clear to represent the "fat" - although we think it was agar agar based. I don't know if they make this fatty tofu on site or get it from a vendor, but either way, it is a very clever tofu creation. The beef in the green beans and beef dish was the same that you would get at other vegan restaurants, but it was goood... especially as leftovers the next day. If you go lunch time, they have cheap lunch specials for one. Oh yea, and if there are two of you, two dishes and a soup will be more than enough food for you to eat.
author: Mimi T.

description: I've lived near Chinatown for several months now, but I had always been a little hesitant to eat in Chinatown... somehow the ducks hanging in the windows of restaurants don't make this vegetarian want to eat there. Nevertheless, I stumbled upon this place on my way home from the gym, and knew it would be the perfect place for me to get a taste of Chinatown. The menu was so big, my roomie and I had a hard time narrowing down what we wanted to order... so, we just ordered it all. Wontons, Eggplant & String Beans w/ Black Bean Sauce, Tomato Beef Chow Mein, Mustard Green Veggie Pork Fried Rice Cake. Everything was tasty, fresh, and felt reasonably healthy. Bonus points for brown rice.  Our server was super friendly - she gave us a lot of recommendations, and when we ordered she managed to laugh and say, "wow, that's a lot" without making us feel like total pigs. Also, the place is very clean & decorated nicely. In general, I'm not a huge fan of faux-meat... but it was pretty good here. However, I've never seen faux-fish before... that just seems weird to me... I'll stay away from that... but I will be back to try more of the other entrees!
author: Christine K.

description: I love this place! They have great vegetarian options that are healthy and yet hearty. I left this place feeling stuffed! Their flavors are also very distinguished, not a mishmash of veggies all thrown in with the same sauce. They clearly cooked different veggies in different manners with different sauces or seasonings and then blended them together, as appropriate, for a medley of vegetarian delight where you can savor all kinds of flavor with every bite. The bean curd rolls with veggies was phenomenal! My boyfriend went bonkers for the thick sauce that coated the bean curd rolls. We were absolutely in love with the eggplants, basil, & tofu combo in satay sauce. TO DIE FOR! Asparagus were smoky and hot and just delicious! The basil and the satay made for a killer combination. I got the curry chicken pot which was yummy. It was a bit too sweet for my taste. More on the dripping coconut milk side of curry sauces if that's your thing, but all in all, still delicious! Their brown rice was awesome! I love the mixed grains that they put into their brown rice. The place was clean and updated and the service was low-key but attentive. Wonderful place! Easy peasy!
author: Pamela L.

description: Right on the border between Chinatown and the Financial District, it's a great addition to the restaurant options in the area.  I've tried several other places before, both in the South Bay and in San Francisco - usually they are places I would go only once and possibly not again for a couple years, just for the novelty of eating at one of these Chinese vegetarian places that serves fake meat.  But this place is good!  The food is tasty and many of the fake meats taste and texture is uncannily like the real thing.  Even not counting the novelty factor of the fake meat, I would come hear to eat just because the dishes taste good, and could stand right up to regular non-vegetarian  restaurants.  It's not overly salty or greasy (like some other places I've been to) and I've already been back three times in half a year.  And it's less crazy and chaotic inside than the other places further up in Chinatown.
author: Mai-Sie C.

description: awesome addition to the veggie Chinese world. and defiantly one of the largest selection of items. everything I've had is fantastic, but a few of my favorites - walnut prawns, fried rice with chicken and mustard greens, sweet and sour chicken, pepper steak... with over 100 items, i still haven't tried everything, but look forward to trying something new every time i go. staff is always friendly, fast service, and the restaurant is always extremely clean.
author: Eric M.

description: The food is pretty good except a bit greasy.  The rice cake, lettuce wrap, and singapore noodles are worth ordering.
author: Mary L.

description: Fantastic vegetarian food that never disappoints! Great, friendly, and respectful service. Nice and clean interior. One of my favorite places in the city!
author: Ben H.

description: Definitely a fan of a clean restaurant that serves dedicated vegetarian fare in downtown San Francisco off Columbus. It's a killer location next to the House of N. I don't care for the fake meat names but the food is good with no hint of MSG. Their basic lunch fare seems nutritious without huge portions that makes you feel overfilled. The location is good: Parking is much easier than Lucky Creation up on Washington and closer to the water and Embarcadero.
author: Rrr X.

description: We were in San Francisco a couple of weeks ago, and my husband is a vegetarian, so we always try out vegetarian restaurants when we visit. We tried Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant and loved it! First, it was very clean and the service was prompt and friendly. The menu is extensive, so we asked for a recommendation (I already knew I wanted to try the Mongolian Beef). We got an order of the pot stickers and the "chicken nuggets" to start. The pot stickers were good, but deep fried, which I didn't expect. The "chicken nuggets" were great! Crispy on the outside, moist on the inside, and flavorful. My husband got a "chicken" dish with basil and it was wonderful. I really liked my Mongolian "beef" and we both had beer with our meal. Don't know why it says "no alcohol" in the heading for this restaurant. Because of that info (I found the restaurant on Yelp), I didn't expect any, but was offered, beer or red wine when we ordered. I didn't ask to see a wine list or anything, so don't know what they had, but we had the beer so they definitely had that. Anyway, we really enjoyed our food, the service was friendly and good, and we will definitely come back. We are fans of Golden Era, but I have to say that Enjoy is nicer inside and you don't have to deal with the Tenderloin...
author: Deb W.

description: I am going to gain weight - this restraunant is great. if you are vegetarian this is heaven for you - i guess you have to like chinese food as well - but EVERYTHING on the menu is veggie, all the meat stuff is veggie/gluten/soy based. I have no idea how they do it but it is fabulous.  the staff are really nice and cheerful and the prices are good - portions are big. this is the best addition to downtown/china town/northbeach area in years. highly recommended for veggies and non-veggies alike.
author: Julie J.

description: Very good vegetarian chinese and the lunch special is a value (get soup, egg roll, rice (white or brown), and large entree for $7.50).  Place is brand new and clean.  When I was there, food was served to me in less than 5 minutes and everything was fresh and tasty.  I'm definitely planning to make it one of regulars for lunch.
author: Will O.

description: Parked about half a mile from this cozy little restaurant. Was skeptical at first about how the imitation meat would taste like.... Surprisingly, the Veggie Bbque pork (made of soy) was realll good. It's like a taste of marinated chewy tofu but ggooood! Also ordered spring rolls which is good.. Only thing to watch out for is when you burp it leaves a distinct taste and smell in your mouth (haha! And I knew that was it)... And while eating our new discoveries, we are munching on some Chinese Brocolli (the stalks) oh damn was it goood.... Yummy with the sauce on the side.. Agghh gives me the urge to come back. The lady was nice too and said we should come back and try the other stuff on the menu.... We were just half hungry before we came in and with the few delish items we got and to top it offf soo affordable.... We got ourselves satisfied. Oh the half mile walk to the car was worth it for this néw discovery. Nice!
author: Calyn C.
